LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Good,” said Mr. Fogg. “We have made up for lost time. Now, we must continue without delay.”

Phileas Fogg, the enigmatic and precise gentleman, was known for his unwavering sense of punctuality and his extraordinary wager to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days. With his loyal valet, Passepartout, by his side, Fogg had already overcome numerous obstacles—unexpected delays, a stolen banknote, and a series of misadventures that would have discouraged any ordinary traveler. Yet, he remained undeterred, his calm demeanor and unshakable confidence guiding them forward.

As the train wheels clicked rhythmically beneath them, Fogg’s mind was already calculating the next leg of their journey. He had no intention of losing a single minute. Passepartout, ever the enthusiastic companion, was busy securing their luggage and ensuring they were prepared for the next destination. The two men, though vastly different in temperament, worked in perfect harmony, each playing a vital role in the success of the journey.

The world outside the train window blurred past—fields, rivers, and distant mountains—each a reminder of the vast distances they had already covered and the many more that lay ahead. Fogg’s journey was not just a test of speed, but of endurance, adaptability, and the human spirit’s ability to overcome the impossible. And as the sun dipped below the horizon, casting a golden glow across the landscape, Fogg’s quiet determination burned brighter than ever.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER IV. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG ASTOUNDS PASSEPARTOUT, HIS SERVANT

events.title: Fogg Announces the 80-Day World Tour
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg returns home from the Reform Club significantly earlier than usual, surprising his valet, Passepartout.
Fogg calls for Passepartout, who hesitates to answer as it is not the designated time.
When Passepartout appears and notes the early hour, Fogg dismisses the observation.
Fogg abruptly informs Passepartout that they are leaving for Dover and Calais within ten minutes.
Passepartout, perplexed, confirms if Fogg intends to leave home.
Fogg affirms this and reveals their extraordinary plan: to travel around the world.
Passepartout is visibly shocked and overwhelmed by this announcement.
Fogg specifies the journey must be completed in eighty days, highlighting the need for immediate departure.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Having won twenty guineas at whist, and taken leave of his friends, Phileas Fogg, at twenty-five minutes past seven, left the Reform Club.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “In eighty days,” responded Mr. Fogg. “So we haven’t a moment to lose.”

events.text_segment:
Having won twenty guineas at whist, and taken leave of his friends, Phileas Fogg, at twenty-five minutes past seven, left the Reform Club.
Passepartout, who had conscientiously studied the programme of his duties, was more than surprised to see his master guilty of the inexactness of appearing at this unaccustomed hour; for, according to rule, he was not due in Saville Row until precisely midnight.
Mr. Fogg repaired to his bedroom, and called out, “Passepartout!”
Passepartout did not reply. It could not be he who was called; it was not the right hour.
“Passepartout!” repeated Mr. Fogg, without raising his voice.
Passepartout made his appearance.
“I’ve called you twice,” observed his master.
“But it is not midnight,” responded the other, showing his watch.
“I know it; I don’t blame you. We start for Dover and Calais in ten minutes.”
A puzzled grin overspread Passepartout’s round face; clearly he had not comprehended his master.
“Monsieur is going to leave home?”
“Yes,” returned Phileas Fogg. “We are going round the world.”
Passepartout opened wide his eyes, raised his eyebrows, held up his hands, and seemed about to collapse, so overcome was he with stupefied astonishment.
“Round the world!” he murmured.
“In eighty days,” responded Mr. Fogg. “So we haven’t a moment to lose.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Having won twenty guineas at whist, and taken leave of his friends, Phileas Fogg, at twenty-five minutes past seven, left the Reform Club. He returned home earlier than usual, and as his servant, Passepartout, was not expecting him, he did not hear the bell. Passepartout, who was in the act of polishing his master's boots, hesitated for a moment before answering, for it was not the hour at which his master usually came home. When he did appear, he looked somewhat surprised. "It is only half-past seven," he said. "I know," replied Fogg, "and I have come home to say that we are going to leave in ten minutes." "Leave!" exclaimed Passepartout. "Yes, for Dover, and from Dover to Calais." "To leave the house?" "Yes, to leave it forever, or at least for a long time." "But, monsieur, where are we going?" "Around the world." Passepartout stared at his master in astonishment. "Around the world!" he repeated. "Yes," said Fogg, "in eighty days." Passepartout was overwhelmed. He could not believe his ears. He looked at his master as if he were a being from another world. "But, monsieur," he stammered, "is this a joke?" "Not at all," replied Fogg, "it is a serious matter. I have made a wager of twenty thousand pounds that I can travel around the world in eighty days. And I intend to win it."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Having won twenty guineas at whist, and taken leave of his friends, Phileas Fogg, at twenty-five minutes past seven, left the Reform Club. He was accompanied by his French valet, Passepartout, who had just returned from a brief errand. As they stepped into the foggy London night, Fogg's expression was as inscrutable as ever, betraying no hint of the extraordinary journey that lay ahead. The two men hailed a hansom cab and made their way to Saville Row, where Fogg's carriage awaited. Inside, a single valise and a small satchel were already packed, ready for departure. At precisely eight o'clock, the carriage rolled out of London, heading toward Liverpool, where a steamship would carry them across the Atlantic. Fogg's movements were precise, his timing impeccable, as if every action were part of a carefully calculated plan. Passepartout, though puzzled by the sudden trip, trusted his master's judgment. As the city lights faded behind them, Fogg gazed out the window, his mind already on the next leg of the journey. The world was about to witness the remarkable feat of a man who would attempt to circumnavigate it in eighty days.

events.title: Minimalist Packing and Passepartout's Disbelief
detailed_summary: A stunned Passepartout inquires about luggage.
Fogg states they will travel light with only a carpet-bag containing spare shirts and stockings, planning to purchase clothes en route.
He instructs Passepartout to bring his coat, cloak, and sturdy shoes, emphasizing speed.
Passepartout, speechless, goes to his room to prepare.
Overwhelmed, he sits down, lamenting the disruption to his desired quiet life.
He starts packing automatically, grappling with disbelief and questioning his master's sanity or motives.

He rationalizes the initial legs of the journey (Dover, Calais, perhaps Paris) and finds slight consolation in potentially revisiting France, but remains baffled by the overall venture and the sudden change in his habitually homebound master.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “But the trunks?” gasped Passepartout, unconsciously swaying his head from right to left.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But surely a gentleman so chary of his steps would stop there; no doubt—but, then, it was none the less true that he was going away, this so domestic person hitherto!

events.text_segment:
“But the trunks?” gasped Passepartout, unconsciously swaying his head from right to left.
“We’ll have no trunks; only a carpet-bag, with two shirts and three pairs of stockings for me, and the same for you. We’ll buy our clothes on the way. Bring down my mackintosh and traveling-cloak, and some stout shoes, though we shall do little walking. Make haste!”
Passepartout tried to reply, but could not. He went out, mounted to his own room, fell into a chair, and muttered: “That’s good, that is! And I, who wanted to remain quiet!”
He mechanically set about making the preparations for departure. Around the world in eighty days! Was his master a fool? No. Was this a joke, then? They were going to Dover; good! To Calais; good again! After all, Passepartout, who had been away from France five years, would not be sorry to set foot on his native soil again. Perhaps they would go as far as Paris, and it would do his eyes good to see Paris once more. But surely a gentleman so chary of his steps would stop there; no doubt—but, then, it was none the less true that he was going away, this so domestic person hitherto!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“But the trunks?” gasped Passepartout, unconsciously swaying his head from right to left.

“Trunks?” said Phileas Fogg, with a quiet smile. “We shall travel light, Passepartout. A carpet-bag will suffice. It contains a few spare shirts and a pair of stockings. We shall purchase the rest of our outfit as we go along.”

Passepartout stared at his master, his mouth open in astonishment. “But, monsieur, we are not going on a journey of a few days! We are going round the world!”

“Precisely,” said Phileas Fogg, in the same calm tone. “And I have no intention of being encumbered by unnecessary luggage. Bring me my coat, my cloak, and a pair of strong shoes. That is all.”

Passepartout, still speechless, turned on his heel and went to his room. He sat down on the edge of his bed, overwhelmed by the suddenness of the change. He had just been dreaming of a quiet life, of a home, of a garden, and now he was to be flung into a whirlwind of travel and adventure. He began to pack automatically, his mind in a whirl. Was his master mad? Or was this some strange whim, some caprice of a man who had never before shown the least sign of eccentricity? He could not understand it. He could not believe it. And yet, the evidence was before him. Phileas Fogg, the most punctual, the most methodical, the most homebound of men, was about to set out on a journey round the world. He would have to go with him, of course. He had no choice. He had been with him for years, and he was bound to him by ties of service and affection. He would go, and he would try to make the best of it. He would try to find some comfort in the thought that the first part of the journey would take them to Dover, then to Calais, perhaps to Paris. He had been to France before, and he had enjoyed it. But what of the rest? What of the vast distances, the strange lands, the perils of the sea and the desert? He shuddered at the thought. And yet, he could not help but feel a strange thrill at the idea of it all. He was going to see the world. He was going to travel with Phileas Fogg. He was going to be part of something extraordinary. And so, with a sigh, he closed his carpet-bag and prepared to follow his master into the unknown.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“But the trunks?” gasped Passepartout, unconsciously swaying his head from right to left.

“Ah, the trunks!” said Phileas Fogg, with a calm smile. “They will follow us, I have no doubt. They are already on the train, and will arrive in London in good time. We have no need to worry about them.”

Passepartout looked at his master with a mixture of admiration and bewilderment. It was as if Fogg could predict the future with perfect accuracy. The trunks, which had been left behind in Paris, had somehow been arranged to travel ahead of them, and now, it seemed, they were already on their way.

“Do you think so, sir?” asked Passepartout, still half in doubt.

“I am certain of it,” replied Fogg. “I have made all the necessary arrangements. The trunks will be in London by the time we are.”

Passepartout could only nod in amazement. He had long since learned that his master’s confidence was rarely misplaced. And so, with a final glance at the receding train, he followed Fogg into the next leg of their incredible journey.

events.title: Final Preparations and Departure from Saville Row
detailed_summary: By 8 PM, Passepartout has packed the single bag, though his mind remains troubled.
After securing his room, he finds Mr. Fogg completely ready for departure.
Fogg is equipped with a Bradshaw's guide, containing railway and steamer schedules.
Fogg adds a substantial roll of Bank of England banknotes to the carpet-bag.
He verifies with Passepartout that nothing, including his outerwear, has been forgotten.
Fogg entrusts the carpet-bag to Passepartout, warning him to guard it well as it contains twenty thousand pounds.
The large sum makes Passepartout feel the bag's immense weight and responsibility.
They exit the house, lock the door, find a cab, and depart swiftly for Charing Cross station.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By eight o’clock Passepartout had packed the modest carpet-bag, containing the wardrobes of his master and himself; then, still troubled in mind, he carefully shut the door of his room, and descended to Mr. Fogg.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Master and man then descended, the street-door was double-locked, and at the end of Saville Row they took a cab and drove rapidly to Charing Cross.

events.text_segment:
By eight o’clock Passepartout had packed the modest carpet-bag, containing the wardrobes of his master and himself; then, still troubled in mind, he carefully shut the door of his room, and descended to Mr. Fogg.
Mr. Fogg was quite ready. Under his arm might have been observed a red-bound copy of Bradshaw’s Continental Railway Steam Transit and General Guide, with its timetables showing the arrival and departure of steamers and railways. He took the carpet-bag, opened it, and slipped into it a goodly roll of Bank of England notes, which would pass wherever he might go.
“You have forgotten nothing?” asked he.
“Nothing, monsieur.”
“My mackintosh and cloak?”
“Here they are.”
“Good! Take this carpet-bag,” handing it to Passepartout. “Take good care of it, for there are twenty thousand pounds in it.”
Passepartout nearly dropped the bag, as if the twenty thousand pounds were in gold, and weighed him down.
Master and man then descended, the street-door was double-locked, and at the end of Saville Row they took a cab and drove rapidly to Charing Cross.

```text
Mr. Fogg was already in the hall, his attire meticulously arranged, his demeanor as composed as ever. He carried a Bradshaw's guide in one hand, its pages filled with railway timetables and steamship schedules, and in the other, a small leather case. Passepartout was struck by the precision of his master's readiness, as if the journey had already been rehearsed in his mind a hundred times.

Fogg paused only briefly to glance at the carpet-bag. "Is everything in order?" he asked, his voice calm and measured.

Passepartout nodded, though his brow furrowed slightly. "Yes, sir. Everything is packed."

Fogg then reached into his pocket and produced a thick roll of Bank of England banknotes, which he carefully placed into the bag. "This contains twenty thousand pounds," he said, his tone devoid of emotion. "You will guard it well."

The weight of the bag suddenly felt immense in Passepartout’s hands, not just in physical heft, but in the gravity of the responsibility it now carried. He could not help but glance at his master, who seemed entirely unfazed by the enormity of the task ahead.

With a final check to ensure nothing had been left behind—down to the smallest detail of outerwear—they locked the door behind them and hailed a cab. The city bustled around them, but Fogg moved with the certainty of a man who had already decided the course of his life. As the cab rattled through the streets toward Charing Cross station, Passepartout could only wonder at the audacity of his master’s plan.
```

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
By eight o’clock Passepartout had packed the modest carpet-bag, containing the wardrobes of his master and himself; then, still troubled in mind, he carefully shut the door of his room, and descended to Mr. Fogg.

Mr. Fogg was already in the drawing-room, calmly smoking a cigar. He looked up as Passepartout entered, his expression as inscrutable as ever. “Well?” he asked, his voice calm but firm.

Passepartout hesitated, then spoke. “Sir, I have packed everything. We are ready to leave at once.”

“Good,” said Mr. Fogg, taking a final puff of his cigar and extinguishing it. “Then let us be off. We have no time to lose.”

With that, the two set out, the great journey beginning in silence, each man lost in his own thoughts, unaware of the trials and triumphs that awaited them around the world in eighty days.

events.title: Generosity, Farewells, and Boarding at Charing Cross
detailed_summary: The cab reaches the station shortly after 8:20 PM.
As Fogg prepares to enter after paying the driver, a poor beggar-woman carrying a child asks him for money.
Fogg gives her the entire twenty guineas he won at whist earlier, expressing satisfaction at having met her.
Passepartout is emotionally touched by his master's act of generosity.
After obtaining first-class tickets to Paris, Fogg encounters his five friends from the Reform Club.
He confirms his departure and suggests they can verify his journey's completion by checking his passport upon his return.
Mr. Ralph assures Fogg that they trust his word as a gentleman.
Mr. Stuart asks Fogg to confirm the exact date and time of his required return.
Fogg reaffirms the deadline: 8:45 PM on Saturday, December 21st, 1872, and bids them farewell.
At 8:40 PM, Fogg and Passepartout board a first-class carriage.
Five minutes later, the train whistle blows, and they depart from the station.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The cab stopped before the railway station at twenty minutes past eight.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg and his servant seated themselves in a first-class carriage at twenty minutes before nine; five minutes later the whistle screamed, and the train slowly glided out of the station.

events.text_segment:
The cab stopped before the railway station at twenty minutes past eight. Passepartout jumped off the box and followed his master, who, after paying the cabman, was about to enter the station, when a poor beggar-woman, with a child in her arms, her naked feet smeared with mud, her head covered with a wretched bonnet, from which hung a tattered feather, and her shoulders shrouded in a ragged shawl, approached, and mournfully asked for alms.
Mr. Fogg took out the twenty guineas he had just won at whist, and handed them to the beggar, saying, “Here, my good woman. I’m glad that I met you;” and passed on.
Passepartout had a moist sensation about the eyes; his master’s action touched his susceptible heart.
Two first-class tickets for Paris having been speedily purchased, Mr. Fogg was crossing the station to the train, when he perceived his five friends of the Reform.
“Well, gentlemen,” said he, “I’m off, you see; and, if you will examine my passport when I get back, you will be able to judge whether I have accomplished the journey agreed upon.”
“Oh, that would be quite unnecessary, Mr. Fogg,” said Ralph politely. “We will trust your word, as a gentleman of honour.”
“You do not forget when you are due in London again?” asked Stuart.
“In eighty days; on Saturday, the 21st of December, 1872, at a quarter before nine p.m. Good-bye, gentlemen.”
Phileas Fogg and his servant seated themselves in a first-class carriage at twenty minutes before nine; five minutes later the whistle screamed, and the train slowly glided out of the station.

The woman, overcome with gratitude, kissed his hand, and retired with her child. Passepartout, who had witnessed this scene, was much affected. He had never before seen his master display such generosity. "Mon Dieu!" he exclaimed, "what a man!" "It was a pleasure to meet her," said Fogg, "and I am glad I had the means to assist her." The station was bustling with activity, a hive of travelers, porters, and the ever-present hum of steam and progress. Fogg, ever punctual, consulted his pocket watch with a calm precision that belied the whirlwind journey they had undertaken. The train to Calais was due to depart in precisely ten minutes, and Fogg's expression remained as serene as if he were merely strolling through his London home.

Passepartout, still reeling from the rapid pace of their adventure, hurried to secure their tickets and stow their luggage. The journey was uneventful, and the trio arrived in Calais just in time to catch the steamer that would carry them across to Dover. Fogg's unwavering confidence in his plan was a source of both admiration and frustration to those around him. As the ship set sail, the English coast receding into the mist, Fogg turned to Passepartout with a quiet smile. The world was vast, but to Phileas Fogg, it was merely a series of destinations to be reached with precision and poise.

events.title: The Journey Begins and Passepartout's Costly Oversight
detailed_summary: The train moves through the dark, rainy evening.
Phileas Fogg remains silent and composed in his seat.
Passepartout, still dazed by the sudden turn of events, clutches the carpet-bag containing the fortune.
While passing through Sydenham, Passepartout lets out a cry of distress.
Mr. Fogg calmly asks what is wrong.
Passepartout reveals that, in his rush, he forgot a crucial task: turning off the gas burner in his room.
Fogg responds with characteristic coolness, stating that the gas will simply continue to burn at Passepartout's expense.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The night was dark, and a fine, steady rain was falling.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Very well, young man,” returned Mr. Fogg, coolly; “it will burn—at your expense.”

events.text_segment:
The night was dark, and a fine, steady rain was falling. Phileas Fogg, snugly ensconced in his corner, did not open his lips. Passepartout, not yet recovered from his stupefaction, clung mechanically to the carpet-bag, with its enormous treasure.
Just as the train was whirling through Sydenham, Passepartout suddenly uttered a cry of despair.
“What’s the matter?” asked Mr. Fogg.
“Alas! In my hurry—I—I forgot—”
“What?”
“To turn off the gas in my room!”
“Very well, young man,” returned Mr. Fogg, coolly; “it will burn—at your expense.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The night was dark, and a fine, steady rain was falling. The train, dashing through the gloom, was making rapid progress, and the country was rapidly changing its aspect. Phileas Fogg, seated in a corner of the carriage, was as immovable as one of those statues which are set up in the squares of London to commemorate forgotten heroes. He was perfectly composed, and his face was as impassive as ever. Passepartout, on the contrary, was in a state of the greatest excitement. He was still dazed by the sudden turn of events, and the carpet-bag containing the fortune was still in his hands. He looked at it from time to time with an air of mingled pride and anxiety. As the train passed through Sydenham, Passepartout gave a sudden cry. 'What is the matter?' asked Phileas Fogg, in his calm, monotonous voice. 'Ah! monsieur,' said Passepartout, 'I have just thought of something terrible! I have left the gas burning in my room!' 'Ah!' said Phileas Fogg, 'that is a misfortune. But it is your misfortune, not mine. You will have to pay for the gas.'

Fogg and Passepartout hurried through the streets, their cloaks soaked and their boots splashing in the puddles. The city was quiet, save for the occasional clatter of carriage wheels. Time was slipping away, and every moment counted in their race around the world.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER V. IN WHICH A NEW SPECIES OF FUNDS, UNKNOWN TO THE MONEYED MEN, APPEARS ON ’CHANGE

events.title: Public Frenzy and Skepticism Over Fogg's Wager
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg anticipated his departure would cause significant public interest.
News of his ambitious wager quickly spread beyond the Reform Club, igniting widespread conversation.
The proposed 'tour of the world' became a topic of heated debate throughout England, discussed with great passion.
While Fogg garnered some supporters, the vast majority considered his plan utterly impossible given the time constraints and contemporary travel technology.
Prominent newspapers largely dismissed the project as madness, though the Daily Telegraph expressed some hesitant support.
General opinion labeled Fogg a lunatic, and his Reform Club associates were criticized for accepting a bet seen as evidence of his mental imbalance.
Numerous articles, reflecting England's fascination with geography, analyzed the venture with fervor and were widely read.
Fogg initially gained some followers, particularly women, and his popularity increased slightly when his portrait was published.
A minority, influenced by the Daily Telegraph, speculated that perhaps such an extraordinary feat could indeed be accomplished.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg rightly suspected that his departure from London would create a lively sensation at the West End.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A few readers of the Daily Telegraph even dared to say, “Why not, after all? Stranger things have come to pass.”

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg rightly suspected that his departure from London would create a lively sensation at the West End. The news of the bet spread through the Reform Club, and afforded an exciting topic of conversation to its members. From the club it soon got into the papers throughout England. The boasted “tour of the world” was talked about, disputed, argued with as much warmth as if the subject were another Alabama claim. Some took sides with Phileas Fogg, but the large majority shook their heads and declared against him; it was absurd, impossible, they declared, that the tour of the world could be made, except theoretically and on paper, in this minimum of time, and with the existing means of travelling. The Times, Standard, Morning Post, and Daily News, and twenty other highly respectable newspapers scouted Mr. Fogg’s project as madness; the Daily Telegraph alone hesitatingly supported him. People in general thought him a lunatic, and blamed his Reform Club friends for having accepted a wager which betrayed the mental aberration of its proposer.
Articles no less passionate than logical appeared on the question, for geography is one of the pet subjects of the English; and the columns devoted to Phileas Fogg’s venture were eagerly devoured by all classes of readers. At first some rash individuals, principally of the gentler sex, espoused his cause, which became still more popular when the Illustrated London News came out with his portrait, copied from a photograph in the Reform Club. A few readers of the Daily Telegraph even dared to say, “Why not, after all? Stranger things have come to pass.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Phileas Fogg rightly suspected that his departure from London would create a lively sensation at the West End. He had no sooner left the Reform Club than the news of his extraordinary undertaking spread with the rapidity of lightning. The newspapers, which are always on the alert for anything new, seized upon the subject with avidity. The 'Tour of the World in Eighty Days' became the topic of the day. The clubs, the coffeehouses, the railway stations, the docks, were all agog with the question. Was it possible to circumnavigate the globe in the space of eighty days? The English, who are always ready to discuss anything connected with locomotion, took up the subject with the greatest interest. Some declared it to be an absurdity, an impossibility; others, more sanguine, thought it might be done. The Daily Telegraph, which had always been a little more liberal in its views than its rivals, expressed a cautious opinion in favor of the feasibility of the enterprise. The other journals, however, were unanimous in their condemnation of the project. They declared that Mr. Fogg was a madman, and that the Reform Club had lost its senses in accepting a wager which was nothing less than a challenge to the laws of nature. The public, which is always ready to take sides in any question that promises excitement, divided itself into two camps. On one side were the 'Foggites,' who maintained that the journey could be accomplished; on the other were the 'Anti-Foggites,' who held that it was a mere delusion. The discussion became so warm that it was even taken up in the House of Commons. The Prime Minister himself was asked whether the Government would assist in the enterprise. He replied that he had no means of interfering with the private affairs of any individual, and that he should be sorry to see the public funds employed in the service of a madman. The question was also discussed in the scientific societies. The Royal Geographical Society, which had always been a little jealous of the public's interest in its proceedings, declared that it had no connection with the matter, and that it was not its province to interfere with the eccentricities of private individuals. The general public, however, was not to be put off in this way. The newspapers continued to publish articles on the subject, and the public continued to read them with the greatest interest. The portrait of Phileas Fogg, which was published in the Illustrated London News, was a great success. It was said to be a perfect likeness, and it was copied in all the illustrated papers of the continent. The portrait was even sent to India, and was published in the Calcutta Englishman. The public, which had been so much interested in the man, was now interested in his likeness. The portrait was hung up in the clubs, in the coffeehouses, in the railway stations, and even in the shops. It was said that the ladies were particularly fond of it, and that they copied it in their albums. The portrait was even said to have inspired a new fashion in whiskers. The general opinion, however, was that Phileas Fogg was a madman, and that the Reform Club had lost its senses in accepting a wager which was nothing less than a challenge to the laws of nature. But there were a few who thought otherwise. There were a few who believed that the journey could be accomplished, and that Phileas Fogg was a man of extraordinary energy and determination. These few were the followers of the Daily Telegraph, and they were to be found in all the great cities of England. They were the people who had the most faith in the future, and who were always ready to believe in the possibility of anything that was not actually impossible. They were the people who had the most faith in the progress of science and the development of the means of locomotion. They were the people who believed that the world was becoming smaller every day, and that the time would come when it would be possible to travel from one end of it to the other in a few days. And these people, though they were a minority, were not without influence. They were the people who read the Daily Telegraph, and who were always ready to take up any question that promised to be interesting. And it was these people who were to be found in the greatest number at the Reform Club on the day of Phileas Fogg's departure.

The eccentric gentleman, known for his punctuality and precision, had made a bold wager to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days. As he stepped onto the train at Savile Row, the curious onlookers gathered to witness the departure of the man who had dared to challenge the very limits of time and travel. The newspapers had already picked up the story, and the public was abuzz with speculation about whether Fogg would succeed in his audacious quest. His calm demeanor and unwavering confidence only added to the intrigue. The West End, a hub of fashion and society, was particularly fascinated by the idea of a man who lived by the clock and now sought to conquer the world within its constraints. As the train pulled away from the station, the murmurs of admiration and disbelief followed. Fogg's journey had begun, and with it, the world was watching. The stakes were high, not just for Fogg, but for the very notion of what was possible in the age of steam and steel. The race was on, and the world was eager to see if time could be beaten.

events.title: Geographical Society Denounces Fogg's Plan
detailed_summary: A detailed analysis published by the Royal Geographical Society on October 7th thoroughly examined and ultimately condemned Fogg's undertaking.
The Society's bulletin argued forcefully that the enterprise was completely impractical.
The article highlighted numerous obstacles, both natural and man-made, standing in the way of success.
It stressed that achieving the required perfect timing for all departures and arrivals was virtually impossible.
While acknowledging potential reliability of European trains, the article questioned the feasibility of crossing India in three days and the United States in seven.
Potential issues like mechanical failures, train derailments, collisions, adverse weather, and snow blockages were presented as significant threats.
The article also pointed out the dangers of winter sea voyages, including unpredictable winds and fog.
It reminded readers that even the most reliable ocean liners frequently experienced delays.
Crucially, the piece asserted that a single missed connection, even by an hour, would break the chain of travel and doom the entire attempt.
This authoritative article received widespread attention, being reprinted in many newspapers, and significantly discouraged Fogg's supporters.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At last a long article appeared, on the 7th of October, in the bulletin of the Royal Geographical Society, which treated the question from every point of view, and demonstrated the utter folly of the enterprise.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This article made a great deal of noise, and, being copied into all the papers, seriously depressed the advocates of the rash tourist.

events.text_segment:
At last a long article appeared, on the 7th of October, in the bulletin of the Royal Geographical Society, which treated the question from every point of view, and demonstrated the utter folly of the enterprise.
Everything, it said, was against the travellers, every obstacle imposed alike by man and by nature. A miraculous agreement of the times of departure and arrival, which was impossible, was absolutely necessary to his success. He might, perhaps, reckon on the arrival of trains at the designated hours, in Europe, where the distances were relatively moderate; but when he calculated upon crossing India in three days, and the United States in seven, could he rely beyond misgiving upon accomplishing his task? There were accidents to machinery, the liability of trains to run off the line, collisions, bad weather, the blocking up by snow—were not all these against Phileas Fogg? Would he not find himself, when travelling by steamer in winter, at the mercy of the winds and fogs? Is it uncommon for the best ocean steamers to be two or three days behind time? But a single delay would suffice to fatally break the chain of communication; should Phileas Fogg once miss, even by an hour; a steamer, he would have to wait for the next, and that would irrevocably render his attempt vain.
This article made a great deal of noise, and, being copied into all the papers, seriously depressed the advocates of the rash tourist.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: At last a long article appeared, on the 7th of October, in the bulletin of the Royal Geographical Society, which treated the question from every point of view, and demonstrated the utter folly of the enterprise. The Society, which had at first received the affair with a certain amount of interest, now, after a careful and detailed examination, pronounced it impracticable in every respect. The article was written with a gravity and precision that left no room for doubt. It was a crushing analysis of the journey round the world in eighty days, and it was signed by several of the most distinguished members of the Society. The writer began by stating that the journey was not impossible, but that it was so improbable that it might as well be considered impossible. He then proceeded to enumerate the obstacles that would have to be overcome. The first was the question of time. The journey was to be made in eighty days, and the time-tables of the various railways and steamers were to be followed with the most exacting precision. The writer pointed out that the slightest delay at any point would throw the whole scheme out of gear, and that the chances of such a delay were very great. He then went on to consider the various routes that would have to be taken. The journey would have to be made by the Suez route, and the writer pointed out that the Suez Canal was not yet open, and that the journey would have to be made by the Cape of Good Hope. events.title: Betting Market Volatility and Fogg's Last Supporter
detailed_summary: The English propensity for betting, extending across social classes, became evident.
Significant wagers were placed for and against Phileas Fogg by both Reform Club members and the broader public.
Fogg was treated like a commodity in the betting markets, akin to a race-horse.
Financial instruments called "Phileas Fogg bonds" were created and actively traded.
Following the publication of the Geographical Society's article, demand for these bonds collapsed, and their value plummeted.
Sellers struggled to find buyers, eventually offering bonds in large, discounted packages.
Lord Albemarle, an elderly, immobilized nobleman, emerged as Fogg's sole remaining prominent advocate.
Motivated by personal ambition and nationalistic pride, Albemarle wagered a substantial sum (£5,000) on Fogg's success.
When challenged about the venture's impracticality, Albemarle insisted that if such a feat were possible, an Englishman should be the one to achieve it.
Support for Fogg continued to decline dramatically, with betting odds heavily favoring failure.
Approximately one week after Fogg's departure, a new development effectively eliminated any remaining support for him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Everybody knows that England is the world of betting men, who are of a higher class than mere gamblers; to bet is in the English temperament.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The Fogg party dwindled more and more, everybody was going against him, and the bets stood a hundred and fifty and two hundred to one; and a week after his departure an incident occurred which deprived him of backers at any price.

events.text_segment:
Everybody knows that England is the world of betting men, who are of a higher class than mere gamblers; to bet is in the English temperament. Not only the members of the Reform, but the general public, made heavy wagers for or against Phileas Fogg, who was set down in the betting books as if he were a race-horse. Bonds were issued, and made their appearance on ’Change; “Phileas Fogg bonds” were offered at par or at a premium, and a great business was done in them. But five days after the article in the bulletin of the Geographical Society appeared, the demand began to subside: “Phileas Fogg” declined. They were offered by packages, at first of five, then of ten, until at last nobody would take less than twenty, fifty, a hundred!
Lord Albemarle, an elderly paralytic gentleman, was now the only advocate of Phileas Fogg left. This noble lord, who was fastened to his chair, would have given his fortune to be able to make the tour of the world, if it took ten years; and he bet five thousand pounds on Phileas Fogg. When the folly as well as the uselessness of the adventure was pointed out to him, he contented himself with replying, “If the thing is feasible, the first to do it ought to be an Englishman.”
The Fogg party dwindled more and more, everybody was going against him, and the bets stood a hundred and fifty and two hundred to one; and a week after his departure an incident occurred which deprived him of backers at any price.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Everybody knows that England is the world of betting men, who are of a higher class than mere gamblers; to bet is in the English temperament. The English bet on everything, from the result of a cricket match to the weather of the ensuing week; and this propensity for betting is not confined to the lower classes, but is found in all ranks of society. The wagers placed for and against Phileas Fogg were of a most extraordinary character. The Reform Club, that aristocratic sanctuary of the English gentleman, became the scene of a veritable mania. The members, who had at first treated the affair with a certain amount of skepticism, soon found themselves deeply interested in the success or failure of the eccentric traveler. The public, too, took up the matter with enthusiasm. The newspapers discussed it in their columns, and the betting offices of the city were crowded with persons eager to lay or take odds on the result. Phileas Fogg was treated like a race-horse, and his chances were quoted in the market. Financial instruments called 'Phileas Fogg bonds' were created and actively traded. These were speculative investments, the value of which depended entirely on the success of the gentleman's journey. The issue of these bonds was a new and curious phenomenon in the financial world. The public, always ready to follow the lead of the moneyed men, rushed into the speculation with a fervor that was almost frantic. But the tide soon turned. When the article of the Geographical Society was published, the demand for these bonds collapsed, and their value plummeted. The sellers, who had been so eager to part with them at a premium, now found themselves unable to get rid of them at any price. They were offered in large lots, at a discount of fifty per cent., and even less. Lord Albemarle, an elderly nobleman, who was confined to his house by infirmity, was the only remaining champion of Phileas Fogg. He had made a wager of five thousand pounds on the success of the journey, and he was determined to see it through. When asked if he did not think the enterprise impracticable, he replied that if it were possible at all, an Englishman should be the one to do it. But the tide of public opinion was against him. The odds against Phileas Fogg were now enormous, and the betting was no longer confined to the Reform Club or the city. It had spread to the coffee-houses and the public-houses, and the wagers were made in the most reckless manner. The excitement was at its height when a new development occurred, which effectually put an end to all hopes of Phileas Fogg's success. This took place about a week after his departure, and it was of such a nature that even Lord Albemarle himself was obliged to acknowledge that the game was up.

events.title: Fogg Accused: Telegram Identifies Him as Bank Robber
detailed_summary: The London police commissioner received an important telegraphic message one evening.
The telegram originated from Detective Fix in Suez.
Fix reported identifying Phileas Fogg as the man responsible for the recent major bank robbery.
The detective urgently requested an arrest warrant be dispatched to Bombay.
The news had an immediate and profound impact.
Public perception shifted instantly; Fogg was no longer seen as an eccentric gentleman but as a fugitive criminal.
His photograph at the Reform Club was re-examined and found to align perfectly with the description of the bank robber circulated by the police.
Fogg's known eccentricities—his solitary nature and abrupt departure—were reinterpreted in a sinister light.
The prevailing theory became that the round-the-world journey was merely a cunning ploy devised to mislead law enforcement and escape justice.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The commissioner of police was sitting in his office at nine o’clock one evening, when the following telegraphic dispatch was put into his hands:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The mysterious habits of Phileas Fogg were recalled; his solitary ways, his sudden departure; and it seemed clear that, in undertaking a tour round the world on the pretext of a wager, he had had no other end in view than to elude the detectives, and throw them off his track.

events.text_segment:
The commissioner of police was sitting in his office at nine o’clock one evening, when the following telegraphic dispatch was put into his hands:
Suez to London.
ROWAN, COMMISSIONER OF POLICE, SCOTLAND YARD:
    I’ve found the bank robber, Phileas Fogg. Send without delay warrant of arrest to Bombay.
FIX, Detective.
The effect of this dispatch was instantaneous. The polished gentleman disappeared to give place to the bank robber. His photograph, which was hung with those of the rest of the members at the Reform Club, was minutely examined, and it betrayed, feature by feature, the description of the robber which had been provided to the police. The mysterious habits of Phileas Fogg were recalled; his solitary ways, his sudden departure; and it seemed clear that, in undertaking a tour round the world on the pretext of a wager, he had had no other end in view than to elude the detectives, and throw them off his track.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The commissioner of police was sitting in his office at nine o’clock one evening, when the following telegraphic dispatch was put into his hands:

"Phileas Fogg, the gentleman who has been making such a stir in the Reform Club, is the man who committed the Bank of England robbery. He has already left London, and is now in Suez. I have followed him from Paris, and am convinced of his guilt. Send an arrest warrant at once to Bombay, where he is bound for."

The name of Phileas Fogg was at once familiar to the commissioner. He was the eccentric gentleman who had made the wager of circumnavigating the globe in eighty days. The idea that this quiet, reserved man could be the author of the great robbery was startling. But the telegram was from Detective Fix, a man of energy and resource, and the commissioner had no hesitation in giving it immediate credence. He at once despatched the warrant to Bombay, and the news spread rapidly through the police offices and the city.

The effect of the intelligence was electric. Phileas Fogg, who had been regarded as a singular, but inoffensive, character, was now looked upon as a dangerous criminal. The newspapers of the next morning teemed with the startling intelligence. The portrait of Phileas Fogg, which had been published in the illustrated papers, was compared with the description of the robber, and the resemblance was found to be perfect. His eccentricities, his solitary habits, his sudden departure from London, were all now interpreted in a sinister sense. The journey round the world was no longer a mere eccentricity, but a carefully devised plan to elude the vigilance of the police. The public, which had hitherto been amused by the gentleman’s singular adventure, was now filled with excitement and indignation. Phileas Fogg had become a criminal, and the chase was on.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The commissioner of police was sitting in his office at nine o’clock one evening, when the following telegraphic dispatch was put into his hands: “Phileas Fogg, of London, has been arrested at the Bank of England for fraud. Send a warrant of arrest to the nearest authorities.” The commissioner read the message twice, then rang for his clerk. “This is a matter of some importance,” he said. “Phileas Fogg is a well-known gentleman, and I must be sure of the facts before taking any action. Send for Inspector Fix at once.” Inspector Fix arrived shortly and was shown into the room. “This is a delicate case,” the commissioner continued. “We must not act hastily. If Fogg is innocent, we must not embarrass him. If he is guilty, we must not let him escape.” Inspector Fix nodded gravely. “I will look into it at once, sir.”

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER VI. IN WHICH FIX, THE DETECTIVE, BETRAYS A VERY NATURAL IMPATIENCE

events.title: Detective Fix Awaits the 'Mongolia' at Suez
detailed_summary: The context for a telegraphic dispatch concerning Phileas Fogg is established.
The steamer 'Mongolia', a fast P&O vessel operating between Brindisi and Bombay via Suez, is described along with its specifications and schedule, being due in Suez on October 9th.
Two men are observed walking on the Suez wharves amidst a diverse crowd.
One man is identified as the British consul, who regularly witnesses the success of the Suez Canal despite initial British skepticism.
The other man is introduced as Fix, a detective from England, characterized by his slight build, nervous energy, and twitching eyebrows.
Fix is revealed to be searching for a bank robber, tasked with scrutinizing passengers arriving in Suez based on a description received from London police.
The detective is motivated by the large reward offered and eagerly awaits the 'Mongolia'.
Fix repeatedly asks the consul about the steamer's punctuality.
The consul confirms the 'Mongolia' is known for its speed and adherence to schedule, having already been reported at Port Said.
They confirm the ship's origin is Brindisi, where it collected Indian mail.
The consul expresses doubt about Fix's ability to identify the robber solely based on the provided description.
Fix asserts his confidence, explaining that identifying criminals is more about intuition or a 'scent' than visual recognition, boasting about his past successes.
The consul acknowledges the severity of the £55,000 robbery.
Fix laments the perceived decline in the caliber of burglars.
The consul wishes Fix success but notes the difficulty, pointing out the robber's description resembles that of an honest man.
Fix dogmatically states that great robbers often look honest, considering it an art to unmask them.
The narrative notes Fix's evident self-conceit.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The circumstances under which this telegraphic dispatch about Phileas Fogg was sent were as follows:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fix evidently was not wanting in a tinge of self-conceit.

events.text_segment:
The circumstances under which this telegraphic dispatch about Phileas Fogg was sent were as follows:
The steamer “Mongolia,” belonging to the Peninsular and Oriental Company, built of iron, of two thousand eight hundred tons burden, and five hundred horse-power, was due at eleven o’clock a.m. on Wednesday, the 9th of October, at Suez. The “Mongolia” plied regularly between Brindisi and Bombay viâ the Suez Canal, and was one of the fastest steamers belonging to the company, always making more than ten knots an hour between Brindisi and Suez, and nine and a half between Suez and Bombay.
Two men were promenading up and down the wharves, among the crowd of natives and strangers who were sojourning at this once straggling village—now, thanks to the enterprise of M. Lesseps, a fast-growing town. One was the British consul at Suez, who, despite the prophecies of the English Government, and the unfavourable predictions of Stephenson, was in the habit of seeing, from his office window, English ships daily passing to and fro on the great canal, by which the old roundabout route from England to India by the Cape of Good Hope was abridged by at least a half. The other was a small, slight-built personage, with a nervous, intelligent face, and bright eyes peering out from under eyebrows which he was incessantly twitching. He was just now manifesting unmistakable signs of impatience, nervously pacing up and down, and unable to stand still for a moment. This was Fix, one of the detectives who had been dispatched from England in search of the bank robber; it was his task to narrowly watch every passenger who arrived at Suez, and to follow up all who seemed to be suspicious characters, or bore a resemblance to the description of the criminal, which he had received two days before from the police headquarters at London. The detective was evidently inspired by the hope of obtaining the splendid reward which would be the prize of success, and awaited with a feverish impatience, easy to understand, the arrival of the steamer “Mongolia.”
“So you say, consul,” asked he for the twentieth time, “that this steamer is never behind time?”
“No, Mr. Fix,” replied the consul. “She was bespoken yesterday at Port Said, and the rest of the way is of no account to such a craft. I repeat that the ‘Mongolia’ has been in advance of the time required by the company’s regulations, and gained the prize awarded for excess of speed.”
“Does she come directly from Brindisi?”
“Directly from Brindisi; she takes on the Indian mails there, and she left there Saturday at five p.m. Have patience, Mr. Fix; she will not be late. But really, I don’t see how, from the description you have, you will be able to recognise your man, even if he is on board the ‘Mongolia.’”
“A man rather feels the presence of these fellows, consul, than recognises them. You must have a scent for them, and a scent is like a sixth sense which combines hearing, seeing, and smelling. I’ve arrested more than one of these gentlemen in my time, and, if my thief is on board, I’ll answer for it; he’ll not slip through my fingers.”
“I hope so, Mr. Fix, for it was a heavy robbery.”
“A magnificent robbery, consul; fifty-five thousand pounds! We don’t often have such windfalls. Burglars are getting to be so contemptible nowadays! A fellow gets hung for a handful of shillings!”
“Mr. Fix,” said the consul, “I like your way of talking, and hope you’ll succeed; but I fear you will find it far from easy. Don’t you see, the description which you have there has a singular resemblance to an honest man?”
“Consul,” remarked the detective, dogmatically, “great robbers always resemble honest folks. Fellows who have rascally faces have only one course to take, and that is to remain honest; otherwise they would be arrested off-hand. The artistic thing is, to unmask honest countenances; it’s no light task, I admit, but a real art.”
Mr. Fix evidently was not wanting in a tinge of self-conceit.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The circumstances under which this telegraphic dispatch about Phileas Fogg was sent were as follows: A steamer, the Mongolia, a fast P. and O. vessel, which runs between Brindisi and Bombay, touching at Suez, was expected at the latter port on the 9th of October. The Mongolia was a regular and punctual ship, and had already been reported at Port Said. She had left Brindisi on the 7th, having taken on board the Indian mails. The Mongolia was a fine vessel of 1,200 tons, and was known to be one of the swiftest in the service. She was expected to arrive at Suez at about noon on the 9th. The British consul at Suez, a gentleman of some years in the East, and who had long since ceased to be surprised at the success of the Suez Canal, was walking on the wharf with a gentleman of somewhat peculiar appearance. This gentleman was Mr. Fix, a detective of the London police, who had come out to Suez to look after a certain bank robber, whose description had been sent over from England. Mr. Fix was a man of slight build, with a nervous, restless air, and a pair of eyebrows that seemed to have a life of their own. He was a man of much energy, and of still more impatience. He had come out to Suez with the idea of catching the robber, and he was determined to do so. The reward offered for the capture of the criminal was considerable, and Mr. Fix was not the man to let such an opportunity slip. He had been waiting for the Mongolia for some time, and he was not at all pleased at the delay. He kept looking at his watch, and muttering to himself. The consul, who was a man of more phlegm, endeavoured to soothe his impatience. 'The Mongolia is a punctual vessel,' said he, 'and I have no doubt she will arrive in good time.' 'Yes, yes,' replied Fix, 'but I should like to see her arrive. I have a description of the robber, and I shall know him when I see him.' 'You are very confident,' said the consul. 'I have confidence in myself,' replied Fix. 'I have caught many a criminal in my time, and I know how to do it. It is not by the eye, but by the nose, that one detects a criminal.' 'The nose!' said the consul. 'Yes,' said Fix, 'the nose of the detective. It is a sort of instinct, a sort of scent, which tells him when he is on the right track. I have it, and I shall not fail.' The consul smiled. 'You are a very clever man,' said he. 'I think so,' replied Fix. 'And I think that the robber is a very stupid one. He has committed a robbery of £55,000, and he has not even thought of disguising himself.' 'He may be a very clever man,' said the consul, 'and look like a very honest one.' 'Ah!' said Fix, 'the great robbers always look honest. It is an art to be a great robber, and to look like a great gentleman. I shall find him, and I shall catch him.'

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The circumstances under which this telegraphic dispatch about Phileas Fogg was sent were as follows: On the 21st of October, 1872, at half-past eight in the evening, a gentleman entered the Reform Club in London, and, after a brief survey of the room, walked directly to the bar. He was a man of about forty, of austere and precise appearance, with a pale face, a thin mustache, and a pair of keen, observant eyes. He was dressed with the utmost correctness, and his manner was marked by a singular calmness and self-possession. He ordered a glass of brandy and water, and, after drinking it in silence, he asked the barman for the use of the telegraph. The barman, who was a man of some experience, looked at him with a little surprise, but, without a word, led him to the telegraph office, which was a small room at the back of the bar. The gentleman seated himself at the instrument, and, after a moment's reflection, sent the following message: 'Phileas Fogg, of London, has left this city on the 2nd of October, 1872, for a journey around the world, and will return to London on the 21st of December, 1872, at half-past eight in the evening. He has wagered a large sum of money on the success of this enterprise.' The message was sent to the London Times, and was published in the next day's paper. The gentleman then left the club, and was never seen there again. The name of Phileas Fogg was not known to the barman, nor to any of the members of the Reform Club. He had no card, no letter, no introduction. He was a stranger in London, and yet he had the audacity to make a public announcement of his intentions. The members of the club, who read the announcement in the newspaper, were at first inclined to treat it as a mere joke. But the name of Phileas Fogg was not a common one, and the sum of money involved was so large that it could not be dismissed as a mere trifle. The members of the Reform Club, therefore, took the matter seriously, and a subscription was opened to raise the sum in case Phileas Fogg should fail in his enterprise. The subscription was a success, and the sum was soon raised. The members of the club, however, were not the only ones who took an interest in the matter. The public of London, and indeed of the whole world, became deeply interested in the fate of Phileas Fogg. The newspapers of all countries took up the story, and the journey of Phileas Fogg became the subject of daily comment and speculation. The question was asked in every drawing-room and in every coffee-house: 'Do you think Phileas Fogg will succeed in his journey around the world in eighty days?' The answer varied according to the temperament of the person who gave it. Some were confident of his success, others were equally confident of his failure. The journey of Phileas Fogg was thus made the subject of a great public interest, and the name of Phileas Fogg became known to all the world. The circumstances under which the telegraphic dispatch was sent were thus of the greatest importance. It was the first public announcement of the enterprise, and it was the means by which the world became aware of the existence of Phileas Fogg. It was the beginning of a great adventure, and the first step in a journey that was to take Phileas Fogg around the world, and to make him one of the most famous men of his time.

events.title: Growing Anticipation and Strategic Speculation
detailed_summary: The activity on the quay intensifies with sailors, merchants, porters, and others bustling about in anticipation of the steamer.
The weather is noted as clear and cool, with the town's minarets visible under the sun.
The long jetty extending into the sea and various boats on the Red Sea are described.
Fix, moving through the crowd, habitually scans faces with sharp glances.
The time reaches half-past ten.
Fix voices his impatience about the steamer's delay as the port clock strikes.
The consul reassures him, suggesting the ship must be close.
Fix inquires about the duration of the stop at Suez.
The consul informs him it will be four hours, necessary for refueling coal for the journey to Aden.
Fix confirms the ship travels directly from Suez to Bombay.
Fix speculates that the robber, if aboard, would likely disembark at Suez to seek refuge in non-British territories in Asia, believing India unsafe.
The consul counters that a truly cunning English criminal might find London itself the safest hiding place.
This remark gives Fix something to contemplate as the consul departs for his office.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Little by little the scene on the quay became more animated; sailors of various nations, merchants, ship-brokers, porters, fellahs, bustled to and fro as if the steamer were immediately expected.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This observation furnished the detective food for thought, and meanwhile the consul went away to his office.

events.text_segment:
Little by little the scene on the quay became more animated; sailors of various nations, merchants, ship-brokers, porters, fellahs, bustled to and fro as if the steamer were immediately expected. The weather was clear, and slightly chilly. The minarets of the town loomed above the houses in the pale rays of the sun. A jetty pier, some two thousand yards along, extended into the roadstead. A number of fishing-smacks and coasting boats, some retaining the fantastic fashion of ancient galleys, were discernible on the Red Sea.
As he passed among the busy crowd, Fix, according to habit, scrutinised the passers-by with a keen, rapid glance.
It was now half-past ten.
“The steamer doesn’t come!” he exclaimed, as the port clock struck.
“She can’t be far off now,” returned his companion.
“How long will she stop at Suez?”
“Four hours; long enough to get in her coal. It is thirteen hundred and ten miles from Suez to Aden, at the other end of the Red Sea, and she has to take in a fresh coal supply.”
“And does she go from Suez directly to Bombay?”
“Without putting in anywhere.”
“Good!” said Fix. “If the robber is on board he will no doubt get off at Suez, so as to reach the Dutch or French colonies in Asia by some other route. He ought to know that he would not be safe an hour in India, which is English soil.”
“Unless,” objected the consul, “he is exceptionally shrewd. An English criminal, you know, is always better concealed in London than anywhere else.”
This observation furnished the detective food for thought, and meanwhile the consul went away to his office.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Little by little the scene on the quay became more animated; sailors of various nations, merchants, ship-brokers, porters, fellahs, bustled to and fro as if the steamer were immediately expected. The weather was clear and cool, and the minarets of the town, gilded by the sun, rose in the distance. The long jetty extended into the sea, and the Red Sea, with its blue waves, was already dotted with boats. Fix, moving through the crowd, cast his sharp, inquisitive glances at the faces around him. It was half-past ten when the port clock struck. Fix, impatient, muttered a few words about the delay of the steamer. 'She must be close at hand,' said the consul, who was with him. 'The stop at Suez is only four hours, necessary for coaling for the journey to Aden.' 'And then she goes straight to Bombay?' asked Fix. 'Yes,' replied the consul. 'Then the robber, if he is on board, will probably disembark at Suez and make for some non-British territory in Asia. India is not safe for him.' 'Ah!' said the consul, 'but a really clever Englishman might find London the safest place in the world.' Fix looked at him thoughtfully, and the consul, after a few more words, left him to return to his office.

The sun, now high in the sky, cast its golden rays over the harbor, gilding the masts of the vessels and the domes of the city beyond. Phileas Fogg, with his usual composure, observed the scene with a quiet interest, his keen eyes missing nothing. Passepartout, ever more demonstrative, was less reserved. The steamer, with its cargo of goods and passengers, set sail, and with it, the adventure of Phileas Fogg began in earnest.

events.title: The 'Mongolia' Arrives and Passengers Disembark
detailed_summary: Alone now, Fix feels increasingly restless, strongly suspecting the robber is on the approaching steamer.
He reasons the robber likely chose the less-monitored Indian route over the Atlantic to reach the New World.
His thoughts are cut short by sharp whistles announcing the 'Mongolia's' arrival.
A rush of porters and boats ensues towards the incoming vessel.
The large hull of the steamer soon appears, and it anchors precisely at eleven o'clock.
A significant number of passengers are aboard; some admire the view from the deck, while most proceed to disembark via smaller boats onto the quay.
Fix positions himself strategically to carefully observe every person coming ashore.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Fix, left alone, was more impatient than ever, having a presentiment that the robber was on board the “Mongolia.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Fix took up a position, and carefully examined each face and figure which made its appearance.

events.text_segment:
Fix, left alone, was more impatient than ever, having a presentiment that the robber was on board the “Mongolia.” If he had indeed left London intending to reach the New World, he would naturally take the route viâ India, which was less watched and more difficult to watch than that of the Atlantic. But Fix’s reflections were soon interrupted by a succession of sharp whistles, which announced the arrival of the “Mongolia.” The porters and fellahs rushed down the quay, and a dozen boats pushed off from the shore to go and meet the steamer. Soon her gigantic hull appeared passing along between the banks, and eleven o’clock struck as she anchored in the road. She brought an unusual number of passengers, some of whom remained on deck to scan the picturesque panorama of the town, while the greater part disembarked in the boats, and landed on the quay.
Fix took up a position, and carefully examined each face and figure which made its appearance.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Fix, left alone, was more impatient than ever, having a presentiment that the robber was on board the “Mongolia.” He had already made up his mind that the criminal had taken the Indian route rather than the Atlantic, because it was less frequented and therefore more likely to escape observation. He was still speculating on this point when the shrill whistle of the steamer announced its approach. The porters and boatmen, who had been lounging about, sprang into action at once, and a lively scene of activity commenced on the quay. The Mongolia, a large and stately vessel, soon came in sight, and at precisely eleven o'clock she dropped her anchor. A great number of passengers were on board; some were still on deck, gazing at the city, while the majority were already descending in the boats. Fix took up a position from which he could see every one who landed, and his eyes sparkled with the keenness of a man who feels that he is on the verge of an important discovery.

The game was far from over, and Fix was determined to see it through to the end.

events.title: Fix Encounters Passepartout and Inspects the Passport
detailed_summary: A passenger emerges from the crowd, politely approaches Fix, and asks for directions to the English consulate.
The passenger explains he needs to have a passport visaed and shows it to Fix.
Fix instinctively takes the passport and quickly reads the bearer's description.
He is visibly surprised as the description perfectly matches the one he received for the bank robber.
Fix inquires if the passport belongs to the passenger.
The passenger clarifies it belongs to his master, who has remained on the ship.
Fix insists that the master must personally visit the consulate to establish his identity.
The passenger asks if this is truly necessary.
Fix confirms it is indispensable.
When asked for the consulate's location, Fix points to a nearby building.
The passenger accepts the instruction, mentions his master might be displeased by the disturbance, bows politely, and returns to the steamer to fetch him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Presently one of the passengers, after vigorously pushing his way through the importunate crowd of porters, came up to him and politely asked if he could point out the English consulate, at the same time showing a passport which he wished to have visaed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The passenger bowed to Fix, and returned to the steamer.

events.text_segment:
Presently one of the passengers, after vigorously pushing his way through the importunate crowd of porters, came up to him and politely asked if he could point out the English consulate, at the same time showing a passport which he wished to have visaed. Fix instinctively took the passport, and with a rapid glance read the description of its bearer. An involuntary motion of surprise nearly escaped him, for the description in the passport was identical with that of the bank robber which he had received from Scotland Yard.
“Is this your passport?” asked he.
“No, it’s my master’s.”
“And your master is—”
“He stayed on board.”
“But he must go to the consul’s in person, so as to establish his identity.”
“Oh, is that necessary?”
“Quite indispensable.”
“And where is the consulate?”
“There, on the corner of the square,” said Fix, pointing to a house two hundred steps off.
“I’ll go and fetch my master, who won’t be much pleased, however, to be disturbed.”
The passenger bowed to Fix, and returned to the steamer.

'Is this passport,' he asked, 'in your name?' 'No, sir,' replied the passenger, 'it belongs to my master, who has remained on board.' 'Then your master must come in person,' said Fix, 'to the consulate, to establish his identity.' 'Is that indispensable?' asked the passenger. 'It is absolutely necessary,' replied Fix. 'Then I must go and fetch him,' said the passenger. 'There is the consulate,' said Fix, pointing to a building a few hundred yards distant. The passenger bowed and returned to the steamer, muttering that his master would not be pleased at being disturbed.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER VII. WHICH ONCE MORE DEMONSTRATES THE USELESSNESS OF PASSPORTS AS AIDS TO DETECTIVES

events.title: Fix Expresses Suspicions to the Consul
detailed_summary: Detective Fix promptly went to the British consul's office.
He immediately stated his strong belief that the man he sought, the bank robber, was aboard the 'Mongolia', recounting the earlier encounter with the servant regarding the passport.
The consul expressed skepticism, noting that a clever robber might avoid official channels like getting a passport visaed to avoid leaving a trail.
Fix countered that a shrewd individual, like he believed his quarry to be, would indeed come to get the visa, precisely because it seems counterintuitive.
He argued that passports primarily inconvenience honest people while inadvertently aiding criminals.
Fix urged the consul not to provide the visa, needing to detain the suspect until a warrant arrived from London.
The consul began to state his inability to refuse a legitimate passport if presented.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The detective passed down the quay, and rapidly made his way to the consul’s office, where he was at once admitted to the presence of that official.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Ah, that’s your look-out. But I cannot—”

events.text_segment:
The detective passed down the quay, and rapidly made his way to the consul’s office, where he was at once admitted to the presence of that official.
“Consul,” said he, without preamble, “I have strong reasons for believing that my man is a passenger on the ‘Mongolia.’” And he narrated what had just passed concerning the passport.
“Well, Mr. Fix,” replied the consul, “I shall not be sorry to see the rascal’s face; but perhaps he won’t come here—that is, if he is the person you suppose him to be. A robber doesn’t quite like to leave traces of his flight behind him; and, besides, he is not obliged to have his passport countersigned.”
“If he is as shrewd as I think he is, consul, he will come.”
“To have his passport visaed?”
“Yes. Passports are only good for annoying honest folks, and aiding in the flight of rogues. I assure you it will be quite the thing for him to do; but I hope you will not visa the passport.”
“Why not? If the passport is genuine I have no right to refuse.”
“Still, I must keep this man here until I can get a warrant to arrest him from London.”
“Ah, that’s your look-out. But I cannot—”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The detective passed down the quay, and rapidly made his way to the consul’s office, where he was at once admitted to the presence of that official. "Sir," said Fix, without ceremony, "I have reason to believe that the man I am in pursuit of is on board the Mongolia, and that he is about to sail under an assumed name." The consul looked up with a faint smile. "You are very sure of that, monsieur?" he asked. "I am positive," replied Fix. "I have had the pleasure of meeting the servant of the gentleman in question, and I have reason to believe that he is in possession of a passport which will enable him to leave the country." The consul shrugged his shoulders. "A clever man would not trouble himself with a passport," he remarked. "He would take care to avoid all official formalities, and thus leave no trace behind him." "Ah!" said Fix, "but that is just what a clever man would not do. He would come to you for a passport, precisely because it is the one thing that no one would suspect. He would know that the police would not think of looking for him in that way." The consul shook his head. "You are very ingenious, monsieur, but I must remind you that I cannot refuse a passport to a man who has a right to it." "Then you are a very kind man," said Fix, "but I must ask you to do me a small favour. I must have time to send to London for a warrant. If you will only delay the passport for a few hours, I shall be able to arrest the man before he leaves the country." The consul looked at him for a moment in silence, and then began to speak.
