LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
They stopped, and engaged in a whispered colloquy. Phileas Fogg, ever the composed and calculating man, observed the exchange with a keen eye, though his expression betrayed no emotion. Passepartout, his loyal and ever-enthusiastic valet, was clearly agitated, his hands gesturing wildly as he spoke. The two men had just arrived at the docks of Bombay, where they were to catch the steamer that would carry them to Suez. Time was of the essence, and every delay was a threat to Fogg’s wager to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days.

The murmured conversation between Passepartout and the local agent was brief but intense. The agent, a wiry man with a nervous manner, finally stepped back and bowed to Fogg. “There is a problem, sir,” he said, his voice barely above a whisper. “The steamer is delayed. A mechanical failure, they say. It may not be ready to depart for at least two days.”

Passepartout’s face fell. “Two days!” he exclaimed, his voice rising. “But we cannot afford two days, monsieur! We are already behind schedule!”

Fogg, however, remained unfazed. He took a moment to consider the situation, his mind already calculating the implications. “Two days,” he repeated, his voice calm and measured. “That is not insurmountable. We must find an alternative.”

Passepartout looked at him, a mixture of admiration and exasperation in his eyes. “But what alternative, monsieur? The next steamer is not for another week!”

Fogg’s gaze sharpened. “Then we must not wait for a steamer. We must find another means of transport.”

Passepartout blinked. “Another means?”

Fogg nodded. “There is a train that runs from Bombay to Calcutta. From there, we can take a steamer to Singapore. It is a longer route, but it may allow us to make up the time.”

Passepartout looked at him as if he had just proposed flying to the moon. “A train, monsieur? But the tracks are not yet completed, are they?”

Fogg smiled faintly. “They are, Passepartout. The Great Indian Peninsula Railway has reached as far as Calcutta. We shall take it.”

Passepartout sighed, but he knew better than to argue with his master. “Very well, monsieur. But I must say, I do not envy the people who will be on that train with us. We shall be like a hurricane in a teacup!”

Fogg chuckled. “Then let us be the most efficient hurricane in history.”

And with that, the two men set off to make the necessary arrangements, their journey continuing in the most unexpected of ways.

events.title: Rescue Appears Lost; Fogg Remains Hopeful
detailed_summary: The group is deeply dismayed, as reaching Aouda now seems impossible.
Sir Francis clenches his fists in frustration, Passepartout is extremely agitated, and the guide gnashes his teeth in anger.
Phileas Fogg remains outwardly calm and unemotional.
Sir Francis whispers that they have no option but to depart.
The guide concurs with this assessment of hopelessness.
Fogg firmly tells them to wait, reminding them he has until the next morning to reach Allahabad.
Sir Francis questions Fogg's hope, pointing out that dawn is approaching.
Fogg enigmatically suggests that the lost chance might reappear at the very last moment.
Sir Francis studies Fogg, trying to understand his cool demeanor and plan – perhaps a reckless attempt to snatch Aouda during the sacrifice itself.
Though considering Fogg's potential plan foolhardy, Sir Francis agrees to stay until the end.
The guide leads them to a position at the rear of the glade to watch the sleeping assembly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They could not now reach the victim; how, then, could they save her?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The guide led them to the rear of the glade, where they were able to observe the sleeping groups.

events.text_segment:
They could not now reach the victim; how, then, could they save her? Sir Francis shook his fists, Passepartout was beside himself, and the guide gnashed his teeth with rage. The tranquil Fogg waited, without betraying any emotion.
“We have nothing to do but to go away,” whispered Sir Francis.
“Nothing but to go away,” echoed the guide.
“Stop,” said Fogg. “I am only due at Allahabad tomorrow before noon.”
“But what can you hope to do?” asked Sir Francis. “In a few hours it will be daylight, and—”
“The chance which now seems lost may present itself at the last moment.”
Sir Francis would have liked to read Phileas Fogg’s eyes. What was this cool Englishman thinking of? Was he planning to make a rush for the young woman at the very moment of the sacrifice, and boldly snatch her from her executioners?
This would be utter folly, and it was hard to admit that Fogg was such a fool. Sir Francis consented, however, to remain to the end of this terrible drama. The guide led them to the rear of the glade, where they were able to observe the sleeping groups.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
They could not now reach the victim; how, then, could they save her? The Parsee guide, who had hitherto been so confident, now looked at them with a troubled expression. Sir Francis Cromarty clenched his fists in frustration, his face dark with anger and despair. Passepartout, usually so full of energy and resourcefulness, was now a picture of agitation, his hands twitching and his eyes darting about as if seeking some miraculous solution. The Parsee guide, in his turn, gnashed his teeth in impotent fury, his dark face lit by the flickering torchlight.

Phileas Fogg, however, remained as calm and impassive as ever. He stood with his hands behind his back, his gaze fixed on the distant glade where the ceremony was about to take place. Sir Francis, unable to contain himself any longer, whispered, “We must go. There is no other course.”

The Parsee guide nodded in agreement. “It is too late,” he said. “The sacrifice is about to begin.”

Fogg turned to them, his voice quiet but firm. “We must wait.”

Sir Francis looked at him in astonishment. “Wait? Until when?”

“Until morning,” said Fogg. “I have until then to reach Allahabad.”

Sir Francis studied him closely, trying to read the expression in his eyes. “You have some plan, then?” he asked.

Fogg did not answer directly. “The lost chance,” he said, “may reappear at the very last moment.”

Sir Francis was not reassured. He could not fathom how Fogg could remain so composed in the face of such overwhelming odds. Perhaps, he thought, Fogg intended to attempt some desperate and reckless rescue during the ceremony itself. It would be madness, but he could not deny the man’s determination. And so, with a reluctant nod, he agreed to stay.

The Parsee guide led them to a position at the rear of the glade, where they could watch the sleeping assembly without being seen. The night was still, the only sound the occasional rustle of the leaves in the wind. Fogg stood at the edge of the shadows, his face unreadable, as if he were already calculating the next move in a game that had only just begun.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: They could not now reach the victim; how, then, could they save her? The situation seemed desperate. The storm had driven them far from the shore, and the sea was too rough for any attempt at rescue. Passepartout, ever the loyal companion, looked at his master with a mixture of concern and determination. Phileas Fogg, calm as ever, studied the horizon, his mind already working through the possibilities. "We must wait for the tide to turn," he said. "And in the meantime, we must keep watch." Hours passed in tense silence, the wind howling and the waves crashing against the ship. Just as hope began to fade, a light appeared on the distant shore. It was a signal fire, lit by the villagers who had not given up the search. With renewed energy, the crew steered toward the light, and soon they were close enough to throw a line to the struggling figure. With great effort, they hauled the victim aboard, safe and alive. It was a narrow escape, but once again, Phileas Fogg's unwavering confidence and Passepartout's courage had turned the tide in their favor.

events.title: Passepartout's Secret Plan as Sacrifice Commences
detailed_summary: Meanwhile, Passepartout, hidden in a tree, refines a daring idea that initially seemed absurd but now feels like their only recourse.
He internally commits to his risky strategy, seeing it as a possible, singular chance among the incapacitated crowd.
He agilely descends the tree's lower branches.
Time passes, and the sky begins to lighten, signaling approaching daybreak.
This is the crucial moment; the crowd stirs, tambourines sound, and chanting erupts as the sacrifice begins.
The pagoda doors open, revealing Aouda within amidst bright light.
She appears momentarily conscious, seemingly trying to resist before lapsing back into drug-induced stupor.
Sir Francis's heart pounds; he clutches Fogg's hand and feels the cold steel of an open knife within it.
The procession starts moving towards the pyre.
Aouda, rendered helpless by hemp fumes, is carried along by the fakirs amidst their ecstatic cries.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Meanwhile Passepartout, who had perched himself on the lower branches of a tree, was resolving an idea which had at first struck him like a flash, and which was now firmly lodged in his brain.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg and his companions, mingling in the rear ranks of the crowd, followed; and in two minutes they reached the banks of the stream, and stopped fifty paces from the pyre, upon which still lay the rajah’s corpse.

events.text_segment:
Meanwhile Passepartout, who had perched himself on the lower branches of a tree, was resolving an idea which had at first struck him like a flash, and which was now firmly lodged in his brain.
He had commenced by saying to himself, “What folly!” and then he repeated, “Why not, after all? It’s a chance,—perhaps the only one; and with such sots!” Thinking thus, he slipped, with the suppleness of a serpent, to the lowest branches, the ends of which bent almost to the ground.
The hours passed, and the lighter shades now announced the approach of day, though it was not yet light. This was the moment. The slumbering multitude became animated, the tambourines sounded, songs and cries arose; the hour of the sacrifice had come. The doors of the pagoda swung open, and a bright light escaped from its interior, in the midst of which Mr. Fogg and Sir Francis espied the victim. She seemed, having shaken off the stupor of intoxication, to be striving to escape from her executioner. Sir Francis’s heart throbbed; and, convulsively seizing Mr. Fogg’s hand, found in it an open knife. Just at this moment the crowd began to move. The young woman had again fallen into a stupor caused by the fumes of hemp, and passed among the fakirs, who escorted her with their wild, religious cries.
Phileas Fogg and his companions, mingling in the rear ranks of the crowd, followed; and in two minutes they reached the banks of the stream, and stopped fifty paces from the pyre, upon which still lay the rajah’s corpse.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Meanwhile, Passepartout, who had perched himself on the lower branches of a tree, was resolving an idea which had at first struck him like a flash, and which was now firmly lodged in his brain. He was a man of action, and, once a plan was formed, he clung to it with the tenacity of despair. The idea was this: to rescue Aouda from the fakirs, and to carry her off before the sacrifice was completed. It was a bold and perilous enterprise, but it was the only one that offered a chance of success. He had seen the crowd, and he knew that it was composed of fanatics, who would not hesitate to kill any one who interfered with their rites. But he was not daunted. He was a Frenchman, and he had the courage of his countrymen. He was also a servant, and he had the devotion of a servant. He had no fear of death, and he had no thought of danger. He was resolved to act, and he was resolved to succeed. He descended from the tree with the agility of a cat, and, crouching behind the trunks of the trees, he made his way towards the pagoda. The night was still, and the only sound was the low murmur of the wind among the leaves. The sky was beginning to lighten, and the first streaks of dawn were visible in the east. It was the critical moment. The crowd began to stir, the tambourines to sound, and the chanting to rise in a wild and unearthly cadence. The doors of the pagoda opened, and Aouda appeared, pale and motionless, in the full light of the torches. She seemed for a moment to be conscious of her surroundings, and to make an effort to resist the fate that awaited her. But the fumes of the hemp had already taken possession of her, and she sank back into the stupor from which no human voice could rouse her. Sir Francis Cromarty, who had been watching the scene with a heart full of anguish, turned to Phileas Fogg, and, seizing his hand, he felt the cold steel of an open knife within it. The procession was forming, and the fakirs, with their wild cries and their frantic gestures, were preparing to carry Aouda to the pyre. She was helpless, and she was carried along by the crowd, which surged forward with a terrible and irresistible force. It was the moment for action, and Passepartout, with the coolness of a man who has made up his mind, stepped forward and seized Aouda by the arm. The fakirs turned upon him with a yell, and the crowd, which had been watching the scene with a kind of breathless interest, burst into a wild and furious cry. But Passepartout was not to be daunted. He had made up his mind to act, and he was resolved to succeed. He was a man of action, and he had the courage of a man who had nothing to lose.

events.title: Passepartout's Specter Act Saves Aouda
detailed_summary: From a short distance, the rescuers observe the unconscious Aouda being placed on the funeral pyre beside the rajah's body.
A torch is applied, and the oil-drenched wood immediately catches fire.
Sir Francis and the guide physically restrain Phileas Fogg, who appears poised for a desperate, sacrificial rush toward the burning pyre.
Fogg forcefully pushes them aside, just as the entire scene undergoes a sudden, dramatic transformation.
A collective cry of terror arises from the crowd.
The multitude throws themselves onto the ground, paralyzed by fear.
The supposedly dead rajah appears to rise miraculously, like a phantom, from the pyre.
He lifts his wife (Aouda) into his arms and descends, his figure made more ghostly by the swirling smoke.
The terrified fakirs, soldiers, and priests remain prostrate, not daring to look at the apparent supernatural event.
The spectral figure carries the lifeless Aouda with surprising ease.
Fogg and Sir Francis stand stunned but upright; the Parsee guide bows his head, and Passepartout's reaction is assumed to be similar shock.
The figure walks towards Fogg and Sir Francis and abruptly instructs them, "Let us be off!"
The rescuer is revealed to be Passepartout himself, who had secretly climbed onto the pyre amidst the smoke and darkness.
He successfully freed Aouda by impersonating the resurrected rajah with bold audacity, navigating through the terrified crowd.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In the semi-obscurity they saw the victim, quite senseless, stretched out beside her husband’s body.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was Passepartout who, playing his part with a happy audacity, had passed through the crowd amid the general terror.

events.text_segment:
In the semi-obscurity they saw the victim, quite senseless, stretched out beside her husband’s body. Then a torch was brought, and the wood, heavily soaked with oil, instantly took fire.
At this moment Sir Francis and the guide seized Phileas Fogg, who, in an instant of mad generosity, was about to rush upon the pyre. But he had quickly pushed them aside, when the whole scene suddenly changed. A cry of terror arose. The whole multitude prostrated themselves, terror-stricken, on the ground.
The old rajah was not dead, then, since he rose of a sudden, like a spectre, took up his wife in his arms, and descended from the pyre in the midst of the clouds of smoke, which only heightened his ghostly appearance.
Fakirs and soldiers and priests, seized with instant terror, lay there, with their faces on the ground, not daring to lift their eyes and behold such a prodigy.
The inanimate victim was borne along by the vigorous arms which supported her, and which she did not seem in the least to burden. Mr. Fogg and Sir Francis stood erect, the Parsee bowed his head, and Passepartout was, no doubt, scarcely less stupefied.
The resuscitated rajah approached Sir Francis and Mr. Fogg, and, in an abrupt tone, said, “Let us be off!”
It was Passepartout himself, who had slipped upon the pyre in the midst of the smoke and, profiting by the still overhanging darkness, had delivered the young woman from death! It was Passepartout who, playing his part with a happy audacity, had passed through the crowd amid the general terror.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: In the semi-obscurity they saw the victim, quite senseless, stretched out beside her husband’s body. The pyre, already prepared, was ready to receive the double offering. A torch was applied to the oil-drenched wood, and the flames, fed by the wind, rose at once in a column of fire. Phileas Fogg, who had hitherto kept his composure, suddenly started forward as if to rush into the flames. Sir Francis and the Parsee guide seized him by the arms, and with difficulty held him back. But Fogg, with a desperate effort, shook them off, and was about to dash forward when a sudden and extraordinary phenomenon arrested the attention of all. A cry of terror broke from the crowd. The people threw themselves upon the ground, and remained motionless, as if struck with a panic they could not explain. The supposed corpse of the Rajah had risen from the pyre! The figure, half enveloped in the smoke, lifted Aouda in his arms and descended. The fakirs, the soldiers, the priests, all remained prostrate, not daring to look at the apparition. The figure, with a ghostly step, carried the lifeless form of Aouda with surprising ease. Phileas Fogg and Sir Francis stood motionless, but upright; the Parsee guide bowed his head, and Passepartout, who had been watching from behind a tree, was probably in a state of equal astonishment. The figure advanced towards the two Englishmen, and, in a voice that rang out clear and firm above the murmurs of the crowd, said, “Let us be off!” It was Passepartout himself, who, taking advantage of the smoke and darkness, had climbed upon the pyre, and, with the audacity of a man who had nothing to lose, had succeeded in carrying off Aouda, while the crowd, struck with terror, had not dared to move.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: In the semi-obscurity they saw the victim, quite senseless, stretched out beside her husband’s body. The scene was one of horror and desolation. The two bodies lay in the dust, the woman’s head resting on the breast of the man who had perished by her side. The night was still, and the only sound was the distant howl of the wind as it swept across the lonely plain. Phileas Fogg, ever the composed and calculating man, stepped forward with measured steps, his face betraying no emotion. He knelt beside the bodies, his keen eyes scanning the scene with the precision of a man who had long since learned to trust in observation rather than emotion. Passepartout, however, was less restrained. He gasped at the sight, his hand flying to his mouth in horror. “Mon Dieu!” he whispered, his voice barely audible. “What has happened here?” Fogg did not answer immediately. He was already piecing together the events that had led to this tragic end. The signs were clear: a struggle had taken place, and the husband had died defending his wife. Fogg’s mind worked swiftly, as it always did. He noted the position of the bodies, the faint traces of blood on the ground, and the broken branch of a nearby tree. It was a puzzle, and Fogg was determined to solve it. He rose to his feet, his expression resolute. “We must continue,” he said, his voice calm and steady. “There is no time to waste.” And with that, the two men turned away from the grim scene, leaving the dead to the mercy of the night.

events.title: Escape Under Fire
detailed_summary: Shortly after the rescue, the four companions vanish into the surrounding woods.
The elephant rapidly carries them away from the scene.
The sounds of shouting and pursuit, along with a bullet whizzing past Fogg's hat, confirm their deception has been uncovered.
The actual corpse of the rajah becomes visible on the pyre.
The priests, overcoming their fear, realize an abduction has occurred.
They lead soldiers into the forest in pursuit, firing a volley of shots at the escaping party.
However, the fugitives on the elephant quickly gain distance, soon moving beyond the effective range of the bullets and arrows.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A moment after all four of the party had disappeared in the woods, and the elephant was bearing them away at a rapid pace.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They hastened into the forest, followed by the soldiers, who fired a volley after the fugitives; but the latter rapidly increased the distance between them, and ere long found themselves beyond the reach of the bullets and arrows.

events.text_segment:
A moment after all four of the party had disappeared in the woods, and the elephant was bearing them away at a rapid pace. But the cries and noise, and a ball which whizzed through Phileas Fogg’s hat, apprised them that the trick had been discovered.
The old rajah’s body, indeed, now appeared upon the burning pyre; and the priests, recovered from their terror, perceived that an abduction had taken place. They hastened into the forest, followed by the soldiers, who fired a volley after the fugitives; but the latter rapidly increased the distance between them, and ere long found themselves beyond the reach of the bullets and arrows.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: A moment after all four of the party had disappeared in the woods, and the elephant was bearing them away at a rapid pace. The shouts of the crowd, the confused cries of the priests, and the trampling of feet in the dust, showed that the deception had been discovered. A bullet whistled past Phileas Fogg's hat, and another struck the howdah, but the beast, urged on by Passepartout, plunged into the thicket with a speed that soon carried them beyond the reach of pursuit. The pyre, with the body of the Rajah upon it, was now clearly visible in the moonlight. The priests, recovering from their consternation, rushed to the spot, and, finding the corpse gone, gave vent to their rage and despair in frantic cries. They soon rallied, however, and, calling upon the soldiers, pushed into the forest in hot pursuit. The fugitives, meanwhile, rode on in silence, the only sound being the creaking of the howdah and the heavy breathing of the elephant. Aouda, pale and trembling, clung to Phileas Fogg, while Passepartout, with his usual good-humored assurance, kept glancing back to see if they were followed. The Parsee guide, who had been so instrumental in their escape, rode behind, his face lit by the firelight, and his eyes gleaming with a strange satisfaction. The night was dark and still, and the forest, with its dense foliage and tangled undergrowth, seemed to offer them a safe refuge. But the soldiers, with their torches and their shouts, were not far behind. The chase was on, and the fate of the fugitives hung in the balance.

The animal, guided by the mahout, plunged through the undergrowth, its heavy feet shaking the ground. Phileas Fogg, calm and composed, watched the landscape blur past. Passepartout, breathless and wide-eyed, clung tightly to the howdah. Aouda and Fix remained silent, their fates now entwined in the race against time.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XIV. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG DESCENDS THE WHOLE LENGTH OF THE BEAUTIFUL VALLEY OF THE GANGES WITHOUT EVER THINKING OF SEEING IT

events.title: Post-Rescue Celebration and Reflection
detailed_summary: The successful rescue mission concludes, bringing relief.
Passepartout expresses great amusement over his role in the exploit.
Sir Francis congratulates Passepartout warmly.
Phileas Fogg offers rare praise, saying "Well done!"
Passepartout deflects the praise, crediting Fogg and calling his own contribution a mere "queer" idea.
He humorously reflects on his brief impersonation as the husband of a venerable rajah.
Aouda remains unconscious from the ordeal, resting in a howdah.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The rash exploit had been accomplished; and for an hour Passepartout laughed gaily at his success.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As for the young Indian woman, she had been unconscious throughout of what was passing, and now, wrapped up in a travelling-blanket, was reposing in one of the howdahs.

events.text_segment: The rash exploit had been accomplished; and for an hour Passepartout laughed gaily at his success. Sir Francis pressed the worthy fellow’s hand, and his master said, “Well done!” which, from him, was high commendation; to which Passepartout replied that all the credit of the affair belonged to Mr. Fogg. As for him, he had only been struck with a “queer” idea; and he laughed to think that for a few moments he, Passepartout, the ex-gymnast, ex-sergeant fireman, had been the spouse of a charming woman, a venerable, embalmed rajah! As for the young Indian woman, she had been unconscious throughout of what was passing, and now, wrapped up in a travelling-blanket, was reposing in one of the howdahs.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The rash exploit had been accomplished; and for an hour Passepartout laughed gaily at his success. He was in a state of exultation, and could not contain himself. He had played the part of a rajah's husband, had been carried in a palanquin, had been the object of homage, and had even received the homage with a gravity that was not altogether assumed. Sir Francis Cromarty, who had witnessed the whole affair, came up to him and heartily congratulated him. "You have done wonders, Monsieur Passepartout," said he. "I do not know whether I admire you more for your courage or your presence of mind." "Oh, it was nothing, Sir Francis," replied Passepartout, with a wave of the hand. "A mere queer idea, that's all. I only did what any one else would have done." Phileas Fogg, who had hitherto said nothing, now turned to him and said, in his calm, deliberate manner, "Well done, Passepartout." It was the first time that he had ever spoken in terms of praise, and the words had a weight and value that made Passepartout's eyes glisten. He bowed low, and said, "Thank you, sir. I am only too happy to have been of service." Aouda, who had been carried in a howdah, was still unconscious, and lay wrapped in a shawl, her face pale and still. Passepartout looked at her with a mixture of pity and admiration. "Poor thing!" he murmured. "She has had a rough time of it." And so, as the party resumed their journey down the Ganges, Passepartout's thoughts were a curious mixture of triumph, tenderness, and reflection, while Phileas Fogg, with his usual composure, seemed to be thinking only of the time and the route ahead.

The journey had only just begun, and already it was proving to be far more perilous than either of them had anticipated.

events.title: Journey Continuation and Concerns for Aouda
detailed_summary: Guided skillfully by the Parsee, the elephant travels swiftly through the dark forest and across a plain.
They halt after about an hour's travel past the pagoda.
Aouda remains deeply unconscious; the guide administers brandy and water without effect.
Sir Francis, recognizing the symptoms of hemp intoxication, reassures the others about her current state.
However, he expresses grave concern for Aouda's future safety if she stays in India.
He warns Fogg that fanatics would find her anywhere in the country, even under English police protection.
Sir Francis concludes that leaving India permanently is her only path to safety.
Phileas Fogg states he will consider the situation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The elephant, thanks to the skilful guidance of the Parsee, was advancing rapidly through the still darksome forest, and, an hour after leaving the pagoda, had crossed a vast plain.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg replied that he would reflect upon the matter.

events.text_segment:
The elephant, thanks to the skilful guidance of the Parsee, was advancing rapidly through the still darksome forest, and, an hour after leaving the pagoda, had crossed a vast plain. They made a halt at seven o’clock, the young woman being still in a state of complete prostration. The guide made her drink a little brandy and water, but the drowsiness which stupefied her could not yet be shaken off. Sir Francis, who was familiar with the effects of the intoxication produced by the fumes of hemp, reassured his companions on her account. But he was more disturbed at the prospect of her future fate. He told Phileas Fogg that, should Aouda remain in India, she would inevitably fall again into the hands of her executioners. These fanatics were scattered throughout the county, and would, despite the English police, recover their victim at Madras, Bombay, or Calcutta. She would only be safe by quitting India for ever.
Phileas Fogg replied that he would reflect upon the matter.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The elephant, thanks to the skilful guidance of the Parsee, was advancing rapidly through the still darksome forest, and, an hour after leaving the pagoda, had crossed a vast plain. The ground was now more level, and the beast could increase his speed without danger. The night was still, and the only sounds were the creaking of the howdah and the occasional rustling of the trees. Aouda remained in a state of unconsciousness, her breathing faint and irregular. The Parsee, with the instinctive promptitude of his race, had already administered to her some brandy and water, but without effect. Sir Francis Cromarty, who had watched the symptoms with a practiced eye, now stepped forward. 'She is under the influence of hemp,' he said quietly. 'It is a common enough practice in these parts, and not always with such disastrous results. She will recover, but she must not remain here.' Phileas Fogg turned to him. 'What do you mean?' he asked. 'That she must leave India,' Sir Francis replied. 'If she stays, she will be in constant danger. The fanatics who would harm her are everywhere in this country, and no amount of English police protection will be sufficient. The only way to ensure her safety is to take her out of it altogether.' Fogg was silent for a moment. 'I will consider the matter,' he said at last. The Parsee, who had been listening intently, gave a respectful bow and urged the elephant forward. The journey continued in silence, the weight of the decision pressing upon them all.

The night was still deep, and the only sounds were the soft padding of the elephant's feet and the occasional rustle of the undergrowth. Phileas Fogg and his companions remained silent, each lost in thought. Passepartout, ever the optimist, occasionally glanced at the sky, hoping for signs of dawn. The forest gradually gave way to open ground, and the Parsee, sensing their progress, urged the elephant forward with a few gentle commands. The journey was arduous, but Fogg's unwavering determination kept them moving. As the first light of morning began to break, the landscape transformed, and the travelers knew they were making good time on their incredible journey around the world.

events.title: Arrival at Allahabad and Passepartout's Shopping Errand
detailed_summary: The group reaches the Allahabad railway station around ten o'clock.
The railway line continues from here, promising arrival in Calcutta within 24 hours.
This timing allows Fogg to catch the planned steamer to Hong Kong.
Aouda is settled in a waiting room.
Fogg tasks Passepartout with buying necessary clothing and toiletries for Aouda, giving him unlimited funds.
Passepartout ventures into Allahabad, noting its significance as the 'City of God' at the confluence of the Ganges and Jumna rivers.
He observes the city's landmarks, including its fort-turned-prison, and finds its commerce disappointing compared to London.
He eventually locates an elderly Jewish merchant selling second-hand goods.
Passepartout purchases a Scottish dress, a large mantle, and an otter-skin pelisse for seventy-five pounds.
He returns to the station, pleased with his purchases.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The station at Allahabad was reached about ten o’clock, and, the interrupted line of railway being resumed, would enable them to reach Calcutta in less than twenty-four hours.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He then returned triumphantly to the station.

events.text_segment:
The station at Allahabad was reached about ten o’clock, and, the interrupted line of railway being resumed, would enable them to reach Calcutta in less than twenty-four hours. Phileas Fogg would thus be able to arrive in time to take the steamer which left Calcutta the next day, October 25th, at noon, for Hong Kong.
The young woman was placed in one of the waiting-rooms of the station, whilst Passepartout was charged with purchasing for her various articles of toilet, a dress, shawl, and some furs; for which his master gave him unlimited credit. Passepartout started off forthwith, and found himself in the streets of Allahabad, that is, the City of God, one of the most venerated in India, being built at the junction of the two sacred rivers, Ganges and Jumna, the waters of which attract pilgrims from every part of the peninsula. The Ganges, according to the legends of the Ramayana, rises in heaven, whence, owing to Brahma’s agency, it descends to the earth.
Passepartout made it a point, as he made his purchases, to take a good look at the city. It was formerly defended by a noble fort, which has since become a state prison; its commerce has dwindled away, and Passepartout in vain looked about him for such a bazaar as he used to frequent in Regent Street. At last he came upon an elderly, crusty Jew, who sold second-hand articles, and from whom he purchased a dress of Scotch stuff, a large mantle, and a fine otter-skin pelisse, for which he did not hesitate to pay seventy-five pounds. He then returned triumphantly to the station.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The station at Allahabad was reached about ten o’clock, and, the interrupted line of railway being resumed, would enable them to reach Calcutta in less than twenty-four hours. This was important, for it would allow Phileas Fogg to catch the steamer which was to carry him to Hong Kong. Aouda was accordingly installed in a waiting-room, and Phileas Fogg, turning to Passepartout, said: "You will go and buy for Mademoiselle Aouda whatever she may require in the way of clothing and toilet articles. I have no limit to impose upon your expenditure." Passepartout, who had never been so rich before, was delighted at the commission. He set out at once, and soon found himself in the streets of Allahabad, a city which, from its position at the confluence of the Ganges and the Jumna, is called the "City of God." He looked about him with curiosity, and noted the fine old fort, which had been converted into a prison, and the numerous temples and pagodas. But the commerce of Allahabad, though considerable, did not seem to Passepartout to be in any way superior to that of London. He soon found, however, an old Jewish merchant, who had a stock of second-hand goods, and who, with a knowing eye, seemed to have foreseen the arrival of a customer with unlimited means. Passepartout, after some parleying, succeeded in purchasing for seventy-five pounds a complete Scottish dress, a large mantle, and an otter-skin pelisse. He returned to the station, very much pleased with his purchases, and found that Phileas Fogg had not moved from his seat, and was as punctual as ever.

This was important, for it would allow Phileas Fogg to catch the steamer which was to sail from Calcutta at half-past two on the following day for Hong Kong. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The station at Allahabad was reached about ten o’clock, and, the interrupted line of railway being resumed, would enable them to reach Calcutta in less than twenty-four hours. Phileas Fogg, ever the picture of composure, wasted no time in securing a first-class compartment on the next available train. Passepartout, eager and energetic, took charge of the luggage, while Aouda, seated quietly by the window, observed the bustling station with a calm demeanor. The train, a reliable and well-maintained service, departed promptly, gliding smoothly along the tracks. As the countryside unfolded in a blur of green fields and distant hills, Passepartout could not resist expressing his admiration for the efficiency of Indian railways. “Mon Dieu!” he exclaimed, “this is progress indeed!” Phileas Fogg, ever the gentleman, merely nodded in approval. The journey was uneventful, and the hours passed with remarkable speed. At dawn, the train approached the grand city of Calcutta, the capital of British India. The station was a hive of activity, teeming with passengers, porters, and vendors. As the train came to a halt, Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout disembarked with their usual precision. Fogg consulted his pocket watch, calculating the time remaining in their journey. With Calcutta behind them, the next leg of their adventure awaited—Suez, and the crossing of the Red Sea. The intrepid travelers had no time to rest; they hailed a carriage and set off toward the port, determined to maintain their schedule. The city, with its blend of East and West, was a fitting backdrop to their extraordinary journey, and Fogg, ever the optimist, remained confident that their goal was within reach.

events.title: Aouda's Recovery, Description, and Fogg's Generosity
detailed_summary: Aouda begins to recover from the effects of the drugs administered by the priests.
Her consciousness returns, and her eyes regain their gentle expression.
The narrative includes a poetic description of an Indian queen's beauty, implying Aouda possesses similar charms in a European sense.
She is noted to be a charming woman who speaks English purely, confirming the guide's assessment of her upbringing.
As the train prepares to depart, Fogg pays the guide the exact sum agreed upon.
Passepartout is surprised, feeling Fogg owes the guide more for his devotion and the risks taken.
He reflects on the danger the guide would face if caught by the Indians.
The question of what to do with the expensive elephant, Kiouni, arises.
Fogg resolves this by offering the elephant to the Parsee guide as a gift, acknowledging his devotion beyond the paid service.
The guide is overjoyed, recognizing the gift's immense value.
Passepartout applauds the gesture and bids farewell to Kiouni with sugar lumps.
The elephant affectionately lifts Passepartout with its trunk before gently setting him down.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout, not in the least alarmed, caressed the animal, which replaced him gently on the ground.

events.text_segment:
The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression.
When the poet-king, Ucaf Uddaul, celebrates the charms of the queen of Ahmehnagara, he speaks thus:
“Her shining tresses, divided in two parts, encircle the harmonious contour of her white and delicate cheeks, brilliant in their glow and freshness. Her ebony brows have the form and charm of the bow of Kama, the god of love, and beneath her long silken lashes the purest reflections and a celestial light swim, as in the sacred lakes of Himalaya, in the black pupils of her great clear eyes. Her teeth, fine, equal, and white, glitter between her smiling lips like dewdrops in a passion-flower’s half-enveloped breast. Her delicately formed ears, her vermilion hands, her little feet, curved and tender as the lotus-bud, glitter with the brilliancy of the loveliest pearls of Ceylon, the most dazzling diamonds of Golconda. Her narrow and supple waist, which a hand may clasp around, sets forth the outline of her rounded figure and the beauty of her bosom, where youth in its flower displays the wealth of its treasures; and beneath the silken folds of her tunic she seems to have been modelled in pure silver by the godlike hand of Vicvarcarma, the immortal sculptor.”
It is enough to say, without applying this poetical rhapsody to Aouda, that she was a charming woman, in all the European acceptation of the phrase. She spoke English with great purity, and the guide had not exaggerated in saying that the young Parsee had been transformed by her bringing up.
The train was about to start from Allahabad, and Mr. Fogg proceeded to pay the guide the price agreed upon for his service, and not a farthing more; which astonished Passepartout, who remembered all that his master owed to the guide’s devotion. He had, indeed, risked his life in the adventure at Pillaji, and, if he should be caught afterwards by the Indians, he would with difficulty escape their vengeance. Kiouni, also, must be disposed of. What should be done with the elephant, which had been so dearly purchased? Phileas Fogg had already determined this question.
“Parsee,” said he to the guide, “you have been serviceable and devoted. I have paid for your service, but not for your devotion. Would you like to have this elephant? He is yours.”
The guide’s eyes glistened.
“Your honour is giving me a fortune!” cried he.
“Take him, guide,” returned Mr. Fogg, “and I shall still be your debtor.”
“Good!” exclaimed Passepartout. “Take him, friend. Kiouni is a brave and faithful beast.” And, going up to the elephant, he gave him several lumps of sugar, saying, “Here, Kiouni, here, here.”
The elephant grunted out his satisfaction, and, clasping Passepartout around the waist with his trunk, lifted him as high as his head. Passepartout, not in the least alarmed, caressed the animal, which replaced him gently on the ground.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression. The effects of the drugs administered to her by the fanatics were passing away, and she was regaining her natural serenity. Her features, which had been clouded by the superstitions of her race, now reflected the gentle light of reason. She was a charming woman, and her English, spoken with a purity that surprised Phileas Fogg, proved that she had been well educated. The Parsee guide, who had watched her with admiration, was not mistaken in his estimate of her. She was, in truth, a being of rare grace and intelligence, and it was easy to see that, had she been born in Europe, she would have been one of those queens of beauty whose names are sung in the ballads of the world. The train was about to start, and Phileas Fogg, with his usual precision, paid the Parsee guide the exact sum which had been agreed upon. Passepartout, who had been watching the transaction, could not help expressing his surprise. "Mon Dieu!" he exclaimed, "you don't think of giving him nothing more, do you, sir? He has risked his life for us, and you pay him as if he were a mere hired servant!" "I pay him exactly what he is worth," replied Fogg, "and no more." Passepartout shook his head, and muttered something about the ingratitude of rich men. But Fogg, who was not given to explanations, merely turned away. The question of the elephant Kiouni now arose. The Parsee guide had brought the animal from the jungle, and it had been of great service to them in their journey. What was to be done with it? Phileas Fogg, after a moment's thought, said: "This elephant is yours, my friend. I give it to you as a token of my appreciation of your services." The Parsee guide was overwhelmed with gratitude. He could not speak for a moment, but his eyes shone with joy. He knew the value of the gift, and the immense worth of the animal. Passepartout, who had grown fond of Kiouni, clapped the Parsee on the back and said: "There now, that's a fine thing! You are a lucky man, my friend. And good-bye, Kiouni!" He threw the elephant a lump of sugar, which it took with its trunk and placed gently in its mouth. Then, with a sudden burst of affection, the great beast lifted Passepartout in the air and set him down again with the same care as if he had been a child. The Parsee guide laughed heartily, and the parting was made in good humour. The train moved on, and the valley of the Ganges stretched away behind them, a vast and beautiful expanse of green and gold, but Phileas Fogg, with his eyes fixed on the future, never looked back.

events.title: Train Journey to Benares: Aouda Awakens
detailed_summary: Fogg, Sir Francis, Passepartout, and Aouda board the train for Benares, giving Aouda the best seat.
The eighty-mile journey is completed rapidly in two hours.
During the trip, Aouda fully regains her senses.
She expresses bewilderment at finding herself on a train, dressed in European clothes, among strangers.
Her companions offer her liquor to aid her recovery.
Sir Francis explains the events of her rescue, highlighting Fogg's bravery and Passepartout's clever idea.
Fogg remains characteristically silent.
Passepartout modestly dismisses his role as insignificant.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Soon after, Phileas Fogg, Sir Francis Cromarty, and Passepartout, installed in a carriage with Aouda, who had the best seat, were whirling at full speed towards Benares.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fogg said nothing; while Passepartout, abashed, kept repeating that “it wasn’t worth telling.”

events.text_segment: Soon after, Phileas Fogg, Sir Francis Cromarty, and Passepartout, installed in a carriage with Aouda, who had the best seat, were whirling at full speed towards Benares. It was a run of eighty miles, and was accomplished in two hours. During the journey, the young woman fully recovered her senses. What was her astonishment to find herself in this carriage, on the railway, dressed in European habiliments, and with travellers who were quite strangers to her! Her companions first set about fully reviving her with a little liquor, and then Sir Francis narrated to her what had passed, dwelling upon the courage with which Phileas Fogg had not hesitated to risk his life to save her, and recounting the happy sequel of the venture, the result of Passepartout’s rash idea. Mr. Fogg said nothing; while Passepartout, abashed, kept repeating that “it wasn’t worth telling.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Soon after, Phileas Fogg, Sir Francis Cromarty, and Passepartout, installed in a carriage with Aouda, who had the best seat, were whirling at full speed towards Benares. The eighty miles which separated them from that city were accomplished in two hours, the train running at a speed of thirty or thirty-five miles an hour. Aouda, who had recovered her senses during the journey, looked with astonishment at the strange scene around her. She was dressed in European costume, and found herself seated in a car, surrounded by strangers, and carried along at a speed which seemed to her almost supernatural. She could not understand how she had come there, and turned with a look of mingled surprise and gratitude to her companions. Sir Francis, who had been watching her with the keenest interest, now explained to her the circumstances of her rescue. He spoke of Phileas Fogg's intrepidity, of Passepartout's resourcefulness, and of the dangers they had encountered. Aouda listened with rapt attention, and, when the narrative was concluded, she pressed the hand of her deliverer with a fervor which showed the depth of her gratitude. Phileas Fogg, as usual, remained silent, and only bowed slightly. Passepartout, on the contrary, was much embarrassed by the praise bestowed upon him, and declared that his part in the affair had been of no importance. He was, however, secretly pleased, and could not help smiling at the idea of having been the means of saving a lady's life.

events.title: Aouda's Gratitude, Fogg's Offer, and Sir Francis's Departure
detailed_summary: Aouda emotionally thanks her rescuers, her gratitude conveyed more through tears and expression than words.
Recalling the suttee and the continuing danger causes her to shudder with fear.
Phileas Fogg perceives her anxiety and offers to escort her to Hong Kong.
He suggests she can stay there safely until the pursuit dies down.
Aouda accepts the offer eagerly and gratefully.
It is mentioned she has a Parsee merchant relative in Hong Kong.
The train arrives at Benares at half-past twelve.
Benares's legendary and actual status is briefly described, along with Passepartout's impression of its desolate appearance.
Benares is Sir Francis Cromarty's stop; his troops are camped nearby.
He bids farewell to Fogg, wishing him success and hoping for a future meeting under better circumstances.
Fogg gives a light handshake.
Aouda expresses warmer gratitude in her parting with Sir Francis.
Passepartout receives a hearty handshake from the general.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Aouda pathetically thanked her deliverers, rather with tears than words; her fine eyes interpreted her gratitude better than her lips.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He bade adieu to Phileas Fogg, wishing him all success, and expressing the hope that he would come that way again in a less original but more profitable fashion.

events.text_segment:
Aouda pathetically thanked her deliverers, rather with tears than words; her fine eyes interpreted her gratitude better than her lips. Then, as her thoughts strayed back to the scene of the sacrifice, and recalled the dangers which still menaced her, she shuddered with terror.
Phileas Fogg understood what was passing in Aouda’s mind, and offered, in order to reassure her, to escort her to Hong Kong, where she might remain safely until the affair was hushed up—an offer which she eagerly and gratefully accepted. She had, it seems, a Parsee relation, who was one of the principal merchants of Hong Kong, which is wholly an English city, though on an island on the Chinese coast.
At half-past twelve the train stopped at Benares. The Brahmin legends assert that this city is built on the site of the ancient Casi, which, like Mahomet’s tomb, was once suspended between heaven and earth; though the Benares of to-day, which the Orientalists call the Athens of India, stands quite unpoetically on the solid earth, Passepartout caught glimpses of its brick houses and clay huts, giving an aspect of desolation to the place, as the train entered it.
Benares was Sir Francis Cromarty’s destination, the troops he was rejoining being encamped some miles northward of the city. He bade adieu to Phileas Fogg, wishing him all success, and expressing the hope that he would come that way again in a less original but more profitable fashion.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Aouda pathetically thanked her deliverers, rather with tears than words; her fine eyes interpreted her gratitude better than her lips. She had been saved from a fate more terrible than death, and she could not yet realize that she was free. The recollection of the ceremony of the suttee, and the thought that she might have been forced to undergo it, made her shudder. Phileas Fogg, observing her emotion, approached her and said, in his calm and quiet manner, that he would take her to Hong Kong, and that she might remain there until the pursuit of the detective should have ceased. Aouda looked at him with an expression of mingled surprise and gratitude, and, after a moment's hesitation, she pressed his hand with a fervor that showed how deeply she was touched. She had a relative in Hong Kong, a Parsee merchant, who would receive her kindly, and who would be able to protect her. The train arrived at Benares at half-past twelve. Benares, the city of the Ganges, the city of the sages and the sannyasis, the city of death and of immortality, was before them. Passepartout, looking at it from the platform, thought it a melancholy and desolate place. It was Sir Francis Cromarty's destination; his troops were encamped in the neighborhood. Sir Francis, with a soldier's frankness, said that he had only done his duty, and that he was proud to have been the means of saving a life. Passepartout, too, received a hearty shake of the hand from the general, who, with a soldier's good-nature, said, 'You're a lucky fellow, my man; you've got a fine master in Mr. Fogg.'

events.title: Journey through Behar, Night Travel, and Arrival in Calcutta On Schedule
detailed_summary: Leaving Benares, the train travels along the Ganges valley.
The travelers observe the diverse landscape of Behar: green mountains, fields, jungles with alligators, villages, and forests.
They see elephants bathing and groups of Indians performing religious ablutions in the Ganges despite the cold.
The narrative notes these are Brahmins, hostile to Buddhism, worshipping Vishnu, Shiva, and Brahma.
A reflection occurs on how these deities might view modern, anglicised India with its steam technology impacting the sacred river.
The scenery passes quickly, sometimes obscured by steam.
Landmarks like the fort of Chupenie, Ghazipur, Lord Cornwallis's tomb, Buxar, Patna (opium market), and Monghir (industrial town) are glimpsed or noted.
Night falls, and the train speeds through the darkness amidst the sounds of tigers, bears, and wolves.
The sights of Bengal are hidden by night.
Calcutta is reached at seven in the morning.
Fogg has five hours until the noon departure of the Hong Kong steamer.
He checks his journal and confirms his arrival on October 25th, exactly as scheduled.
He is neither early nor late, having lost the two days previously gained during the journey across India.
The narrative suggests Fogg does not regret this loss of time.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But it is not to be supposed that Phileas Fogg regretted them.

events.text_segment:
The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges. Through the windows of their carriage the travellers had glimpses of the diversified landscape of Behar, with its mountains clothed in verdure, its fields of barley, wheat, and corn, its jungles peopled with green alligators, its neat villages, and its still thickly-leaved forests. Elephants were bathing in the waters of the sacred river, and groups of Indians, despite the advanced season and chilly air, were performing solemnly their pious ablutions. These were fervent Brahmins, the bitterest foes of Buddhism, their deities being Vishnu, the solar god, Shiva, the divine impersonation of natural forces, and Brahma, the supreme ruler of priests and legislators. What would these divinities think of India, anglicised as it is to-day, with steamers whistling and scudding along the Ganges, frightening the gulls which float upon its surface, the turtles swarming along its banks, and the faithful dwelling upon its borders?
The panorama passed before their eyes like a flash, save when the steam concealed it fitfully from the view; the travellers could scarcely discern the fort of Chupenie, twenty miles south-westward from Benares, the ancient stronghold of the rajahs of Behar; or Ghazipur and its famous rose-water factories; or the tomb of Lord Cornwallis, rising on the left bank of the Ganges; the fortified town of Buxar, or Patna, a large manufacturing and trading-place, where is held the principal opium market of India; or Monghir, a more than European town, for it is as English as Manchester or Birmingham, with its iron foundries, edgetool factories, and high chimneys puffing clouds of black smoke heavenward.
Night came on; the train passed on at full speed, in the midst of the roaring of the tigers, bears, and wolves which fled before the locomotive; and the marvels of Bengal, Golconda ruined Gour, Murshedabad, the ancient capital, Burdwan, Hugly, and the French town of Chandernagor, where Passepartout would have been proud to see his country’s flag flying, were hidden from their view in the darkness.
Calcutta was reached at seven in the morning, and the packet left for Hong Kong at noon; so that Phileas Fogg had five hours before him.
According to his journal, he was due at Calcutta on the 25th of October, and that was the exact date of his actual arrival. He was therefore neither behind-hand nor ahead of time. The two days gained between London and Bombay had been lost, as has been seen, in the journey across India. But it is not to be supposed that Phileas Fogg regretted them.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges. The train, moving at a rapid pace, followed the sinuous course of the river, which, at that season, was swollen by the monsoon rains. The landscape of Behar unfolded before the eyes of the passengers in a succession of varied and picturesque scenes. Green mountains, covered with dense vegetation, rose in the distance; fields of golden grain extended in all directions; and in the more secluded parts of the valley, the jungle, with its tangled undergrowth and its lurking alligators, seemed to defy the encroachments of civilization. Villages, with their conical huts and narrow streets, were scattered along the banks of the river, and the forests, where the elephant and the tiger held undisputed sway, were occasionally broken by the sudden appearance of a group of Indian pilgrims, performing their religious ablutions in the sacred waters, in spite of the cold. These were Brahmins, the most learned and the most conservative of the Hindu castes, who, while they worshipped Vishnu, Shiva, and Brahma, were bitterly hostile to the doctrines of Buddha. One could not help reflecting, as the train sped on, how these ancient deities, whose temples were scattered along the banks of the Ganges, would regard the modern, anglicized India, with its steam engines and its iron roads, which, like the river itself, now carried men with incredible speed from one end of the country to the other. The scenery passed rapidly before the eyes of the passengers, sometimes obscured by the dense clouds of steam that rose from the locomotive. The fort of Chupenie, with its crumbling walls, was glimpsed for a moment; then came the city of Ghazipur, with its numerous mosques and its busy bazaars; and farther on, the tomb of Lord Cornwallis, the founder of the English dominion in India, stood in solemn isolation. The train passed Buxar, where the Ganges and the Son meet; then Patna, the great opium market of the East; and finally Monghir, an industrial town, where the noise of the foundries and the clang of the hammers seemed to vie with the roar of the river. Night soon fell, and the train sped on through the darkness, the only light being that of the locomotive's headlamp, which cut a path through the gloom. The sounds of the jungle—of the tiger's growl, the bear's grunt, and the wolf's howl—rose from the surrounding forests, mingling with the hiss of the steam and the rattle of the wheels. The beauties of Bengal were thus hidden from the sight of the travelers, and they could only imagine the wonders that lay beyond the darkness. At seven o'clock in the morning, the train reached Calcutta, the great metropolis of British India. Phileas Fogg, as he stepped from the carriage, consulted his journal and found that he had arrived on the 25th of October, exactly as he had calculated. He had not gained a single hour; the two days which he had previously thought he had saved during his journey across India had been lost. But Phileas Fogg was not the man to regret a loss of time, however trifling it might seem to others. He was punctual, and that was sufficient.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges. The river, broad and sluggish, reflected the golden light of the setting sun, its surface broken only by the occasional ripple of a fish or the slow movement of a boat. The banks were lined with dense vegetation, and the air was thick with the scent of earth and water. The train, moving steadily forward, carried its passengers through a landscape that seemed to stretch endlessly, a world apart from the bustling city they had just left behind.

Phileas Fogg, seated in his compartment, observed the scenery with quiet interest. He was a man of habit and precision, and the journey was part of a carefully calculated plan. Around the world in eighty days—such a feat required not only wealth and determination but also an unshakable confidence in the reliability of the modern world. The railway was one of the marvels of the age, and Fogg had no doubt that it would carry him to his next destination on time.

Passepartout, his French valet, was less reserved. He leaned out of the window, taking in the sights with wide-eyed wonder. The countryside was a far cry from the narrow streets of London, and he found himself enchanted by the unfamiliar sights and sounds. Occasionally, he would point out something of interest to Fogg, who would nod in acknowledgment but rarely respond in kind.

As the train continued its journey, the landscape began to change. The dense forests gave way to open fields, and the river, once so close, receded into the distance. The sun dipped lower in the sky, casting long shadows across the land. The train passed through small villages where the people paused in their daily tasks to watch the iron horse pass by. Some waved, others simply stared, their expressions a mixture of curiosity and indifference.

The journey was not without its challenges. At one point, the train slowed to a crawl as it approached a bridge that required careful inspection. A group of engineers and officials gathered to examine the structure, their voices rising and falling in a mixture of languages. Fogg, ever the man of time, remained calm, knowing that delays were an inevitable part of any great journey. He simply adjusted his plans accordingly.

As night began to fall, the train reached its destination. The station was modest, but it served its purpose well. Fogg and Passepartout disembarked, ready to continue their journey. The world was vast, and there was still much to see and do. With each step forward, they moved closer to the completion of their extraordinary adventure.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XV. IN WHICH THE BAG OF BANKNOTES DISGORGES SOME THOUSANDS OF POUNDS MORE

events.title: Arrival in Calcutta and Immediate Arrest
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout arrive at the Calcutta train station.
Fogg intends to immediately board the Hong Kong steamer to ensure Aouda's safety.
A policeman approaches Fogg, confirms his identity and that Passepartout is his servant, and instructs them both to follow him.
Fogg displays no surprise, respecting the law, while Passepartout's attempt to question is silenced by the policeman and Fogg's signal.
Aouda is permitted to accompany them.
They are transported in a four-wheeled carriage (palkigahri) through contrasting parts of the city: the poor 'black town' and the affluent 'European town'.
No one speaks during the twenty-minute journey.
They arrive at a modest building, revealed to be a place of detention.
The policeman escorts them into a room with barred windows, informing them they will appear before Judge Obadiah soon.
The policeman leaves, locking the door behind him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The train entered the station, and Passepartout jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He then retired, and closed the door.

events.text_segment:
The train entered the station, and Passepartout jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend. Phileas Fogg intended to proceed at once to the Hong Kong steamer, in order to get Aouda comfortably settled for the voyage. He was unwilling to leave her while they were still on dangerous ground.
Just as he was leaving the station a policeman came up to him, and said, “Mr. Phileas Fogg?”
“I am he.”
“Is this man your servant?” added the policeman, pointing to Passepartout.
“Yes.”
“Be so good, both of you, as to follow me.”
Mr. Fogg betrayed no surprise whatever. The policeman was a representative of the law, and law is sacred to an Englishman. Passepartout tried to reason about the matter, but the policeman tapped him with his stick, and Mr. Fogg made him a signal to obey.
“May this young lady go with us?” asked he.
“She may,” replied the policeman.
Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout were conducted to a palkigahri, a sort of four-wheeled carriage, drawn by two horses, in which they took their places and were driven away. No one spoke during the twenty minutes which elapsed before they reached their destination. They first passed through the “black town,” with its narrow streets, its miserable, dirty huts, and squalid population; then through the “European town,” which presented a relief in its bright brick mansions, shaded by coconut-trees and bristling with masts, where, although it was early morning, elegantly dressed horsemen and handsome equipages were passing back and forth.
The carriage stopped before a modest-looking house, which, however, did not have the appearance of a private mansion. The policeman having requested his prisoners—for so, truly, they might be called—to descend, conducted them into a room with barred windows, and said: “You will appear before Judge Obadiah at half-past eight.”
He then retired, and closed the door.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The train entered the station, and Passepartout, jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend. The party had no time to lose, for the steamer for Hong Kong was to sail at noon, and it was already half-past ten. Phileas Fogg, with his usual composure, made his way directly to the wharf, Aouda and Passepartout following him. But before they could reach the gangway, a policeman, who had been watching them from a distance, approached and addressed Mr. Fogg. "Are you Phileas Fogg?" he asked. "I am," replied the gentleman, coldly. "And this is your servant?" "He is," said Fogg. "Then you must accompany me," said the officer. Passepartout started to protest, but a glance from his master silenced him. The policeman, without more ceremony, led them through the crowded streets of Calcutta, Aouda being allowed to accompany them. They were placed in a palkigahri, a four-wheeled carriage, and driven rapidly through the city. The contrast between the black town, with its wretched huts and squalid streets, and the European town, with its broad avenues and stately buildings, was striking. No one spoke during the twenty-minute journey. At last they arrived at a modest building, which the officer declared to be a place of detention. He led them into a small room, the windows of which were barred, and informed them that they would appear before Judge Obadiah in a few minutes. Then he left them, locking the door behind him.

The station was crowded with people, and the trio quickly moved through the throng to avoid being delayed. Aney Antoinette, still somewhat dazed from the long journey, clutched her shawl tightly around her shoulders. As they stepped onto the platform, a sudden commotion erupted nearby. A group of men, shouting in a language none of them recognized, began to push and shove through the crowd. Passepartout instinctively stepped in front of Aney Antoinette, shielding her from the chaos. Mr. Fogg, unfazed, calmly observed the situation, his mind already calculating the best course of action. “We must not be late,” he said, his voice steady. Passepartout nodded and quickly hailed a passing carriage. The driver, a wiry man with a thick accent, eyed them suspiciously but agreed to take them when Mr. Fogg offered a generous tip. As they climbed into the carriage, the station seemed to dissolve into a blur of motion and sound. The driver cracked the whip, and the horses sprang forward, leaving the commotion behind. Inside the carriage, Aney Antoinette exhaled in relief. “We are safe now,” she whispered. Mr. Fogg, ever the gentleman, offered her his handkerchief. “We are on schedule,” he replied, glancing at his watch once more. Passepartout, seated across from them, let out a breath of his own. The journey was far from over, but for now, they had made it through another leg of their incredible adventure.

events.title: Reactions to Imprisonment and Fogg's Resolve
detailed_summary: Passepartout exclaims in dismay that they are prisoners.
Aouda, emotional but trying to hide it, tells Fogg he should abandon her, blaming herself for his predicament.
Fogg calmly dismisses her suggestion as impossible, stating he wouldn't be arrested for preventing a suttee and that there must be a mistake.
He reaffirms his commitment to escorting Aouda to Hong Kong.
Passepartout nervously points out the steamer departs at noon.
Fogg confidently assures him they will be on board by noon.
His certainty impresses Passepartout, who mutters agreement, though he remains deeply uneasy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Why, we are prisoners!” exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But he was by no means reassured.

events.text_segment:
“Why, we are prisoners!” exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair.
Aouda, with an emotion she tried to conceal, said to Mr. Fogg: “Sir, you must leave me to my fate! It is on my account that you receive this treatment, it is for having saved me!”
Phileas Fogg contented himself with saying that it was impossible. It was quite unlikely that he should be arrested for preventing a suttee. The complainants would not dare present themselves with such a charge. There was some mistake. Moreover, he would not, in any event, abandon Aouda, but would escort her to Hong Kong.
“But the steamer leaves at noon!” observed Passepartout, nervously.
“We shall be on board by noon,” replied his master, placidly.
It was said so positively that Passepartout could not help muttering to himself, “Parbleu that’s certain! Before noon we shall be on board.” But he was by no means reassured.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Why, we are prisoners!” exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair.

Aouda, who had remained silent, now turned to Phileas Fogg with a look of mingled sorrow and admiration. “You should abandon me,” she said, in a low, trembling voice. “It is I who have brought you into this trouble. I am the cause of your arrest.”

Fogg, with his usual calmness, shook his head. “It is impossible,” he replied. “I cannot, and will not, leave you. I am not a criminal, and I will not be arrested for preventing a crime. There must be some mistake.”

He turned to the officer. “I am Phileas Fogg, and I am on my way to Hong Kong. I am responsible for this lady, and I shall see her safely there.”

Passepartout, who had been pacing the room, now stopped and looked at his master with a mixture of awe and anxiety. “But the steamer,” he said, “she sails at noon!”

Fogg turned to him with a quiet smile. “We shall be on board by noon,” he said.

Passepartout muttered something under his breath, but he could not quite bring himself to contradict his master. Fogg’s confidence was contagious, and for a moment, he felt a spark of hope. But the weight of their situation still pressed heavily upon him.

events.title: Court Appearance and Initial Proceedings
detailed_summary: At half-past eight, the policeman returns and leads them to an adjacent courtroom, already filled with Europeans and natives.
Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout sit on a bench opposite the magistrate's and clerk's desks.
Judge Obadiah, a portly man, enters with his clerk, Oysterpuff.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At half-past eight the door opened, the policeman appeared, and, requesting them to follow him, led the way to an adjoining hall.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Very well; let the complainants come in.”

events.text_segment:
At half-past eight the door opened, the policeman appeared, and, requesting them to follow him, led the way to an adjoining hall. It was evidently a court-room, and a crowd of Europeans and natives already occupied the rear of the apartment.
Mr. Fogg and his two companions took their places on a bench opposite the desks of the magistrate and his clerk. Immediately after, Judge Obadiah, a fat, round man, followed by the clerk, entered. He proceeded to take down a wig which was hanging on a nail, and put it hurriedly on his head.
“The first case,” said he. Then, putting his hand to his head, he exclaimed, “Heh! This is not my wig!”
“No, your worship,” returned the clerk, “it is mine.”
“My dear Mr. Oysterpuff, how can a judge give a wise sentence in a clerk’s wig?”
The wigs were exchanged.
Passepartout was getting nervous, for the hands on the face of the big clock over the judge seemed to go around with terrible rapidity.
“The first case,” repeated Judge Obadiah.
“Phileas Fogg?” demanded Oysterpuff.
“I am here,” replied Mr. Fogg.
“Passepartout?”
“Present,” responded Passepartout.
“Good,” said the judge. “You have been looked for, prisoners, for two days on the trains from Bombay.”
“But of what are we accused?” asked Passepartout, impatiently.
“You are about to be informed.”
“I am an English subject, sir,” said Mr. Fogg, “and I have the right—”
“Have you been ill-treated?”
“Not at all.”
“Very well; let the complainants come in.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: At half-past eight the door opened, the policeman appeared, and, requesting them to follow him, led the way to an adjoining hall. This was a small courtroom, already occupied by a number of Europeans and natives, who had been summoned to witness the proceedings. Phileas Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout took their places on a bench opposite the desks of the magistrate and clerk. At a quarter to nine the judge entered, accompanied by his clerk, a thin, stooping man named Oysterpuff. The judge was a portly gentleman, with a florid face and a very decided manner. He had, however, made a mistake in his toilet, and had put on the clerk's wig instead of his own. This error was soon discovered, and the two gentlemen exchanged headpieces with great ceremony. The judge then took his seat, and, after a few preliminary remarks, called the first case. Oysterpuff, the clerk, read the name of Phileas Fogg, and the accused rose. The judge informed them that they had been sought for two days, and that the matter was of some importance. Passepartout, who was watching the clock with increasing anxiety, could not refrain from asking what the charge was. Phileas Fogg, with his usual calmness, reminded the judge that he was an English subject, and was therefore entitled to certain rights. The judge, somewhat taken aback, assured him that no injustice had been intended, and ordered the complainants to be brought in.

Fixer, ever the gentleman, stepped forward and examined the items with a keen eye. Passepartout, less composed, looked around nervously, his hand never far from the hilt of his knife. Passepartout, ever the optimist, grinned. “Well, if it’s a game of hide and seek, I say we play to win!” With that, the two men left the room, the mystery deepening with every step they took.

events.title: The Accusation and Confusion Over the Crime
detailed_summary: Three Indian priests enter the courtroom.
Passepartout mutters that these are the men who intended to sacrifice Aouda.
The priests stand before the judge, and the clerk reads a charge of sacrilege against Fogg and Passepartout.
They are accused of violating a sacred Brahmin temple.
The judge asks Fogg if he understands the charge.
Fogg, checking his watch, admits to the charge.
He demands the priests, in turn, admit what they were planning at the Pillaji pagoda.
The priests appear confused by Fogg's statement.
Passepartout interjects, specifying the pagoda where the priests were about to burn their victim.
The judge and priests are stunned.
Judge Obadiah clarifies the charge relates not to Pillaji, but to the Malabar Hill pagoda in Bombay.
The clerk produces a pair of shoes as evidence, stating they are the desecrator's shoes left behind.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A door was swung open by order of the judge, and three Indian priests entered.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Whereupon he placed a pair of shoes on his desk.

events.text_segment:
A door was swung open by order of the judge, and three Indian priests entered.
“That’s it,” muttered Passepartout; “these are the rogues who were going to burn our young lady.”
The priests took their places in front of the judge, and the clerk proceeded to read in a loud voice a complaint of sacrilege against Phileas Fogg and his servant, who were accused of having violated a place held consecrated by the Brahmin religion.
“You hear the charge?” asked the judge.
“Yes, sir,” replied Mr. Fogg, consulting his watch, “and I admit it.”
“You admit it?”
“I admit it, and I wish to hear these priests admit, in their turn, what they were going to do at the pagoda of Pillaji.”
The priests looked at each other; they did not seem to understand what was said.
“Yes,” cried Passepartout, warmly; “at the pagoda of Pillaji, where they were on the point of burning their victim.”
The judge stared with astonishment, and the priests were stupefied.
“What victim?” said Judge Obadiah. “Burn whom? In Bombay itself?”
“Bombay?” cried Passepartout.
“Certainly. We are not talking of the pagoda of Pillaji, but of the pagoda of Malabar Hill, at Bombay.”
“And as a proof,” added the clerk, “here are the desecrator’s very shoes, which he left behind him.”
Whereupon he placed a pair of shoes on his desk.
