events.title: Fix's Dilemma and Contingency Plan
detailed_summary: Passepartout's 'sly dog' comment unsettled Fix, who wondered if the Frenchman had discerned his true identity or purpose.
He questioned how Passepartout could possibly know he was a detective.
Fix felt Passepartout's words carried a hidden meaning.
The following day, Passepartout continued his teasing, asking Fix if they would unfortunately part ways in Hong Kong.
Fix answered evasively, slightly flustered.
Passepartout pressed further, suggesting Fix, as a supposed Peninsular Company agent, shouldn't stop his journey partway, noting Fix had already gone past his stated destination of Bombay.
He playfully suggested America and Europe were just short hops away.
Fix observed Passepartout's calm demeanor and laughed along, though inwardly troubled.
Passepartout continued to probe, asking if Fix's current 'occupation' was profitable.
Fix gave a noncommittal answer about luck but admitted he wasn't traveling at his own expense.
Passepartout laughed heartily, confirming Fix's admission.
Confused and suspecting his cover was blown, Fix retreated to his cabin to think.
He worried Passepartout might have informed Fogg, questioned the servant's role (accomplice or innocent?), and feared his mission was compromised.
After considering options, Fix resolved to confront Passepartout directly in Hong Kong if arresting Fogg there proved impossible and Fogg planned to leave British territory.
His plan was to reveal everything to Passepartout, hoping that if the servant was innocent of the robbery, his self-interest would lead him to abandon Fogg.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: This expression rather disturbed Fix, without his knowing why.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Such was the situation between Fix and Passepartout.

events.text_segment:
This expression rather disturbed Fix, without his knowing why. Had the Frenchman guessed his real purpose? He knew not what to think. But how could Passepartout have discovered that he was a detective? Yet, in speaking as he did, the man evidently meant more than he expressed.
Passepartout went still further the next day; he could not hold his tongue.
“Mr. Fix,” said he, in a bantering tone, “shall we be so unfortunate as to lose you when we get to Hong Kong?”
“Why,” responded Fix, a little embarrassed, “I don’t know; perhaps—”
“Ah, if you would only go on with us! An agent of the Peninsular Company, you know, can’t stop on the way! You were only going to Bombay, and here you are in China. America is not far off, and from America to Europe is only a step.”
Fix looked intently at his companion, whose countenance was as serene as possible, and laughed with him. But Passepartout persisted in chaffing him by asking him if he made much by his present occupation.
“Yes, and no,” returned Fix; “there is good and bad luck in such things. But you must understand that I don’t travel at my own expense.”
“Oh, I am quite sure of that!” cried Passepartout, laughing heartily.
Fix, fairly puzzled, descended to his cabin and gave himself up to his reflections. He was evidently suspected; somehow or other the Frenchman had found out that he was a detective. But had he told his master? What part was he playing in all this: was he an accomplice or not? Was the game, then, up? Fix spent several hours turning these things over in his mind, sometimes thinking that all was lost, then persuading himself that Fogg was ignorant of his presence, and then undecided what course it was best to take.
Nevertheless, he preserved his coolness of mind, and at last resolved to deal plainly with Passepartout. If he did not find it practicable to arrest Fogg at Hong Kong, and if Fogg made preparations to leave that last foothold of English territory, he, Fix, would tell Passepartout all. Either the servant was the accomplice of his master, and in this case the master knew of his operations, and he should fail; or else the servant knew nothing about the robbery, and then his interest would be to abandon the robber.
Such was the situation between Fix and Passepartout.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
This expression rather disturbed Fix, without his knowing why. He could not understand how Passepartout had discovered his real name, or what he was in reality. The Frenchman's words had a hidden meaning, which the detective was at a loss to fathom. Was it possible that Passepartout had guessed his mission? Had he, perhaps, discovered that he was a detective? These thoughts passed rapidly through Fix's mind, and he felt a vague uneasiness, which he could not account for.

The next day, Passepartout, with his usual good-humoured air, again alluded to the subject. 'I suppose,' said he, 'that we shall not be long in Hong Kong, and that you will not be sorry to leave us there, monsieur Fix.'

'Why, no,' replied the detective, somewhat embarrassed; 'I have no particular reason for remaining with you.'

'Ah!' said Passepartout, 'but you are not going to stop at Hong Kong, I suppose? You are not going to stop at Bombay, either, since you have already passed it. You are going on to America, perhaps, or to Europe, which are but a short voyage from here.'

Fix laughed, but his laugh was constrained. 'You are very shrewd, Passepartout,' said he; 'but I am not going to America, I assure you.'

'No?' said the Frenchman, with a sly smile. 'Then you are going to Europe, perhaps?'

'I am going where I can find employment,' replied Fix, evasively.

'Ah! That is a very uncertain journey,' said Passepartout. 'But I suppose you are not going at your own expense.'

'No,' said Fix, a little sharply; 'I am not.'

'Ah!' said Passepartout, with a knowing air, 'then you are not a very rich man, monsieur Fix.'

Fix was now thoroughly disconcerted. He saw that Passepartout was playing with him, and that the Frenchman's questions were not idle. He retired to his cabin, and there, for the first time, seriously considered the position in which he was placed. Had Passepartout discovered his secret? Had he informed Phileas Fogg? Was he an accomplice, or was he merely a servant, who had stumbled upon the truth by accident? Fix could not decide. But he resolved that, if it were necessary, he would arrest Phileas Fogg in Hong Kong, and that, if not, he would at least confront Passepartout, and make him understand that he was playing a dangerous game. If the Frenchman was innocent, he would, perhaps, be induced to abandon his master, whose interests, after all, were not identical with his own.

It was not that he feared Phileas Fogg, for he was a man of no particular timidity, but there was something in the Englishman's calm and assured manner that was disconcerting. And so, with a heavy heart and a determined mind, Fix set out to find Phileas Fogg. He did not know where he was, or what he was doing, but he knew that he had to find him. And he knew that it would not be easy. But he was a man of the law, and he had a duty to see that justice was done. And so, with a heavy heart and a determined mind, Fix set out to find Phileas Fogg.

events.title: Fogg's Detachment and Passepartout's Perplexity
detailed_summary: While Fix and Passepartout navigated their suspicions, Phileas Fogg remained completely unaware and indifferent, continuing his journey with methodical precision.
He seemed unaffected by the potential 'disturbing star' nearby, represented by Aouda.
Passepartout was greatly surprised that Aouda's charms seemed to have no effect on Fogg's heart.
He believed any emotional disturbances within Fogg were imperceptible.
Passepartout increasingly marveled at Fogg's apparent heartlessness, contrasting it with the deep gratitude he saw in Aouda's eyes.
He could find no sign that the journey evoked any sentiment in Fogg, while Passepartout himself was lost in daydreams.
One day, while observing the ship's engine, a sudden lurch caused the screw propeller to lift out of the water.
Steam hissed from the valves, angering Passepartout.
He complained about the insufficient pressure and lack of speed, criticizing the English engineering.
He declared that an American ship, while potentially riskier, would certainly be faster.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Meanwhile Phileas Fogg moved about above them in the most majestic and unconscious indifference.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “If this was an American craft, we should blow up, perhaps, but we should at all events go faster!”

events.text_segment:
Meanwhile Phileas Fogg moved about above them in the most majestic and unconscious indifference. He was passing methodically in his orbit around the world, regardless of the lesser stars which gravitated around him. Yet there was near by what the astronomers would call a disturbing star, which might have produced an agitation in this gentleman’s heart. But no! the charms of Aouda failed to act, to Passepartout’s great surprise; and the disturbances, if they existed, would have been more difficult to calculate than those of Uranus which led to the discovery of Neptune.
It was every day an increasing wonder to Passepartout, who read in Aouda’s eyes the depths of her gratitude to his master. Phileas Fogg, though brave and gallant, must be, he thought, quite heartless. As to the sentiment which this journey might have awakened in him, there was clearly no trace of such a thing; while poor Passepartout existed in perpetual reveries.
One day he was leaning on the railing of the engine-room, and was observing the engine, when a sudden pitch of the steamer threw the screw out of the water. The steam came hissing out of the valves; and this made Passepartout indignant.
“The valves are not sufficiently charged!” he exclaimed. “We are not going. Oh, these English! If this was an American craft, we should blow up, perhaps, but we should at all events go faster!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Meanwhile Phileas Fogg moved about above them in the most majestic and unconscious indifference. He was as imperturbable as ever, and the presence of Aouda, which might have been a disturbing star in the heavens of his heart, seemed to produce no effect upon him. Passepartout, on the contrary, was greatly surprised that the charms of the young woman had not made some impression on his master's countenance. He could not perceive the least emotion in the impassable features of Phileas Fogg. He was convinced that no sentiment, not even gratitude, stirred within that heart. And yet Aouda looked at Fogg with such deep and touching eyes! Passepartout, who was himself so susceptible, could not understand how his master could remain so cold. He, for his part, was full of dreams and fancies, and he could not help thinking of the future. He imagined himself already married to Aouda, and living in some pretty house in the Faubourg Saint-Germain. But Phileas Fogg, as if he had no soul, went on with his journey with the same precision and regularity. One day, while Passepartout was watching the engine, a sudden lurch of the ship caused the screw to lift out of the water, and the steam hissed violently from the valves. Passepartout was furious. 'What a wretched speed!' he exclaimed. 'This English engine is a disgrace! An American ship, though perhaps less safe, would at least be twice as fast!'

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XVIII. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG, PASSEPARTOUT, AND FIX GO EACH ABOUT HIS BUSINESS

events.title: Storm Delays the Rangoon and Elicits Varied Reactions
detailed_summary: Persistent north-west gales significantly slowed the steamer 'Rangoon' during the last part of its voyage.
Passengers grew restless due to the heavy rolling caused by large waves.
A fierce storm hit on November 3rd, forcing the ship to reef its sails and slow down further.
The captain predicted arriving in Hong Kong at least twenty hours late, possibly more if the storm continued.
Phileas Fogg observed the tumultuous sea with unwavering calmness, displaying no emotion despite the potential loss of his wager due to the likely missed connection to Yokohama.
His composure appeared almost as if the storm was an expected part of his plan.
Aouda was struck by Fogg's persistent serenity.
Conversely, Fix welcomed the storm, seeing the delay as beneficial to his goal of detaining Fogg in Hong Kong.
He found satisfaction in the setback, viewing the weather as an ally, despite suffering from seasickness.
Passepartout reacted with intense anger and frustration to the bad weather, which threatened the previously smooth journey.
He felt personally invested, as if his own money was at stake.
He felt a strong urge to somehow compel the sea to calm down.
Fix shrewdly hid his own contentment from Passepartout, fearing a violent reaction if his true feelings were revealed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The weather was bad during the latter days of the voyage.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Poor fellow! Fix carefully concealed from him his own satisfaction, for, had he betrayed it, Passepartout could scarcely have restrained himself from personal violence.

events.text_segment:
The weather was bad during the latter days of the voyage. The wind, obstinately remaining in the north-west, blew a gale, and retarded the steamer. The “Rangoon” rolled heavily and the passengers became impatient of the long, monstrous waves which the wind raised before their path. A sort of tempest arose on the 3rd of November, the squall knocking the vessel about with fury, and the waves running high. The “Rangoon” reefed all her sails, and even the rigging proved too much, whistling and shaking amid the squall. The steamer was forced to proceed slowly, and the captain estimated that she would reach Hong Kong twenty hours behind time, and more if the storm lasted.
Phileas Fogg gazed at the tempestuous sea, which seemed to be struggling especially to delay him, with his habitual tranquillity. He never changed countenance for an instant, though a delay of twenty hours, by making him too late for the Yokohama boat, would almost inevitably cause the loss of the wager. But this man of nerve manifested neither impatience nor annoyance; it seemed as if the storm were a part of his programme, and had been foreseen. Aouda was amazed to find him as calm as he had been from the first time she saw him.
Fix did not look at the state of things in the same light. The storm greatly pleased him. His satisfaction would have been complete had the “Rangoon” been forced to retreat before the violence of wind and waves. Each delay filled him with hope, for it became more and more probable that Fogg would be obliged to remain some days at Hong Kong; and now the heavens themselves became his allies, with the gusts and squalls. It mattered not that they made him sea-sick—he made no account of this inconvenience; and, whilst his body was writhing under their effects, his spirit bounded with hopeful exultation.
Passepartout was enraged beyond expression by the unpropitious weather. Everything had gone so well till now! Earth and sea had seemed to be at his master’s service; steamers and railways obeyed him; wind and steam united to speed his journey. Had the hour of adversity come? Passepartout was as much excited as if the twenty thousand pounds were to come from his own pocket. The storm exasperated him, the gale made him furious, and he longed to lash the obstinate sea into obedience. Poor fellow! Fix carefully concealed from him his own satisfaction, for, had he betrayed it, Passepartout could scarcely have restrained himself from personal violence.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The weather was bad during the latter days of the voyage. A persistent north-west gale, which had been blowing for several days, had considerably retarded the progress of the steamer Rangoon. The passengers, who had hitherto enjoyed a smooth and rapid passage, were now tossed about with some discomfort, and the rolling of the vessel became so violent that many of them found it difficult to keep their feet. On the 3rd of November a fresh gale, accompanied by heavy rain, burst upon them, and the Rangoon was obliged to reef her sails and reduce her speed. The captain, who had already been compelled to alter his course to avoid a field of ice, now declared that he should not reach Hong Kong before the 21st at the earliest, and that if the gale continued he might not arrive before the 22nd. Phileas Fogg, seated on a locker in the saloon, observed the tumultuous sea with the same calmness as if he had been looking at a picture. He did not seem to care whether the vessel was driven to windward or not, and his countenance was as serene as if he had no stake in the matter. Aouda, who was watching him, was struck by the singular composure of the man, who, in the midst of the storm, seemed to be thinking of something else. Fix, on the contrary, was delighted. The delay was precisely what he wanted. He had no fear of the sea, and though he was suffering from the rolling of the vessel, he was rejoicing at the thought of the twenty hours' delay which would enable him to carry out his plans. He looked at the sky with a satisfied air, and seemed to consider the gale as a friend. Passepartout, however, was in a state of violent excitement. He was furious at the idea of the delay, and could not understand how M. Fogg could remain so indifferent. He was ready to fly at the waves and compel them to subside. He was so much agitated that Fix, who was watching him, thought it prudent to conceal his own satisfaction, for fear of provoking some violent outburst.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The weather was bad during the latter days of the voyage. The stormy seas tossed the ship about, making it difficult for the passengers to keep their balance, let alone enjoy the scenery. Phileas Fogg, ever the composed gentleman, remained unfazed by the turbulence. He continued his daily routine with the same precision and punctuality, as if the storm outside had no bearing on his world. Passepartout, on the other hand, was not so calm. The young Frenchman, who had been so full of energy and enthusiasm at the beginning of the journey, now found himself battling the sea’s wrath. He spent much of his time below deck, trying to stave off the effects of the motion sickness that plagued him. A number of other passengers were similarly afflicted, and the once lively atmosphere on board had turned somber. The captain and his crew worked tirelessly to keep the ship on course, their faces grim as they battled the elements. The storm lasted for several days, and during that time, communication with the outside world was nearly impossible. The ship’s progress was slowed, and there were murmurs of concern among the passengers about whether they would make their scheduled port of call on time. Fogg, however, remained confident. He had planned for delays and had built in a margin of safety in his calculations. He believed that as long as the ship did not suffer any serious damage, they would still be on track to complete their journey within the eighty days. When the storm finally passed, the skies cleared, and the sun broke through the clouds, the passengers emerged from their cabins, refreshed and invigorated by the return of calm. The sea, once a violent and unpredictable force, now stretched out before them in a vast expanse of blue. Fogg, ever the gentleman, offered his arm to Mrs. Aouda, who had also been affected by the storm. He walked with her to the deck, where they stood in silence, watching the horizon. The storm had tested their resolve, but it had not broken them. They had weathered the worst of it, and now, with the sun shining once more, they were ready to continue their journey around the world.

events.title: Storm Abates but Arrival in Hong Kong is Severely Delayed
detailed_summary: Unable to stay calm below deck during the storm, Passepartout stayed on deck.
He attempted to 'help' the crew and peppered the captain, officers, and sailors with questions about the storm's duration, amusing them with his impatience.
He was directed to check the barometer, which showed no signs of improving weather.
Passepartout physically shook the barometer, but neither this nor his complaints had any effect.
On November 4th, the sea calmed, the storm weakened, and the wind shifted favorably to the south.
Passepartout's mood improved along with the weather.
Sails were unfurled, and the 'Rangoon' increased speed, but the lost time could not be made up.
Land was finally sighted on the morning of November 6th, a full day later than the scheduled arrival on the 5th.
Phileas Fogg was now twenty-four hours behind schedule, seemingly guaranteeing he would miss the Yokohama steamer.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout remained on deck as long as the tempest lasted, being unable to remain quiet below, and taking it into his head to aid the progress of the ship by lending a hand with the crew.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg was twenty-four hours behind-hand, and the Yokohama steamer would, of course, be missed.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout remained on deck as long as the tempest lasted, being unable to remain quiet below, and taking it into his head to aid the progress of the ship by lending a hand with the crew. He overwhelmed the captain, officers, and sailors, who could not help laughing at his impatience, with all sorts of questions. He wanted to know exactly how long the storm was going to last; whereupon he was referred to the barometer, which seemed to have no intention of rising. Passepartout shook it, but with no perceptible effect; for neither shaking nor maledictions could prevail upon it to change its mind.
On the 4th, however, the sea became more calm, and the storm lessened its violence; the wind veered southward, and was once more favourable. Passepartout cleared up with the weather. Some of the sails were unfurled, and the “Rangoon” resumed its most rapid speed. The time lost could not, however, be regained. Land was not signalled until five o’clock on the morning of the 6th; the steamer was due on the 5th. Phileas Fogg was twenty-four hours behind-hand, and the Yokohama steamer would, of course, be missed.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Passepartout remained on deck as long as the tempest lasted, being unable to remain quiet below, and taking it into his head to aid the progress of the ship by lending a hand with the crew. He was, however, more of a hindrance than a help, and the sailors, though laughing at his impatience, were obliged to keep a watchful eye upon him. He was constantly asking the captain and officers when the storm would cease, and how long it would last, as if he could not endure the suspense. The captain, a man of few words, merely shrugged his shoulders, while the officers smiled at the young man's anxiety. At last, Passepartout, in a fit of despair, went to the binnacle and took up the barometer, shaking it violently as if it were to blame for the continuance of the gale. The barometer, however, remained unmoved, and Passepartout's complaints were of no avail. On the morning of the 4th of November, the sea began to subside, the wind changed to the south, and the storm, which had raged so furiously, began to abate. Passepartout's countenance brightened with the improvement in the weather, and he was soon to be seen in high spirits, running about the deck and congratulating the crew on the change. The sails were soon unfurled, and the Rangoon, with renewed speed, made for the land which was now visible on the horizon. But the time lost during the storm could not be recovered, and the vessel did not reach the port of Yokohama until the morning of the 6th, a day later than had been expected. Phileas Fogg, who had so carefully calculated his journey, now found himself twenty-four hours behind schedule, and the Yokohama steamer, which he had counted upon taking, had already sailed.

The storm raged with fury, waves crashing against the vessel, and the wind howling like a beast in torment. Passepartout, though no sailor, was undeterred. He moved about the deck with surprising agility, helping to secure the rigging and pass supplies to the exhausted men. His master, Phileas Fogg, observed this from the cabin, a faint smile playing on his lips. Passepartout’s energy and loyalty were a source of comfort in the chaos. The crew, impressed by his determination, began to accept his help. As the storm gradually subsided, the ship emerged battered but intact. Passepartout, soaked and weary, returned below to find Fogg waiting. “You did well,” Fogg said simply, offering a nod of approval. It was a rare moment of praise, but it meant more to Passepartout than words could express.

events.title: Unexpected Reprieve: Yokohama Steamer Departure Postponed
detailed_summary: At six o'clock, a pilot boarded to guide the 'Rangoon' into Hong Kong harbor.
Passepartout anxiously wanted to ask the pilot about the Yokohama steamer but restrained himself to maintain a sliver of hope.
He shared his worries with Fix, who deceitfully suggested Fogg could just take the next boat, which only angered Passepartout.
Mr. Fogg calmly approached the pilot directly.
He asked when the next steamer for Yokohama would depart.
The pilot informed him it would leave the following morning at high tide.
Fogg received the news without any outward sign of surprise.
Passepartout overheard this and was ecstatic, feeling immense relief, while Fix was furious at this unexpected turn.
Fogg inquired about the steamer's name, learning it was the 'Carnatic'.
He confirmed that it should have departed the previous day.
The pilot explained the departure was postponed until the next day due to necessary boiler repairs.
Fogg thanked the pilot and calmly went down to the saloon.
Overjoyed, Passepartout enthusiastically shook the pilot's hand, calling him the 'best of good fellows'.
The pilot remained unaware of the reason for such a warm reception as he returned to the bridge to navigate through the busy harbor.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The pilot went on board at six, and took his place on the bridge, to guide the “Rangoon” through the channels to the port of Hong Kong.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He remounted the bridge, and guided the steamer through the flotilla of junks, tankas, and fishing boats which crowd the harbour of Hong Kong.

events.text_segment:
The pilot went on board at six, and took his place on the bridge, to guide the “Rangoon” through the channels to the port of Hong Kong. Passepartout longed to ask him if the steamer had left for Yokohama; but he dared not, for he wished to preserve the spark of hope, which still remained till the last moment. He had confided his anxiety to Fix who—the sly rascal!—tried to console him by saying that Mr. Fogg would be in time if he took the next boat; but this only put Passepartout in a passion.
Mr. Fogg, bolder than his servant, did not hesitate to approach the pilot, and tranquilly ask him if he knew when a steamer would leave Hong Kong for Yokohama.
“At high tide to-morrow morning,” answered the pilot.
“Ah!” said Mr. Fogg, without betraying any astonishment.
Passepartout, who heard what passed, would willingly have embraced the pilot, while Fix would have been glad to twist his neck.
“What is the steamer’s name?” asked Mr. Fogg.
“The ‘Carnatic.’”
“Ought she not to have gone yesterday?”
“Yes, sir; but they had to repair one of her boilers, and so her departure was postponed till to-morrow.”
“Thank you,” returned Mr. Fogg, descending mathematically to the saloon.
Passepartout clasped the pilot’s hand and shook it heartily in his delight, exclaiming, “Pilot, you are the best of good fellows!”
The pilot probably does not know to this day why his responses won him this enthusiastic greeting. He remounted the bridge, and guided the steamer through the flotilla of junks, tankas, and fishing boats which crowd the harbour of Hong Kong.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The pilot went on board at six, and took his place on the bridge, to guide the “Rangoon” through the channels to the port of Hong Kong. Passepartout, who had been watching the time with the impatience of a man whose fate depends on it, was about to ask the pilot if the steamer from Yokohama had arrived, but he checked himself, unwilling to give up the last thread of hope that still remained. He turned to Fix, and said, in a tone of dejection, “It is not here, I suppose?” Fix, who was not without a certain amount of curiosity to see how the affair would end, replied, “No; but there is another steamer, which leaves to-morrow.” “To-morrow!” cried Passepartout, “and we shall not reach Yokohama before the 10th!” “Well,” said Fix, “Mr. Fogg can take that.” “That!” exclaimed Passepartout, “and lose the wager!” Phileas Fogg, who had overheard this conversation, now approached the pilot, and, in his calm, deliberate manner, asked, “When does the next steamer for Yokohama leave?” The pilot looked at his watch, and replied, “To-morrow morning, at high tide.” Mr. Fogg bowed, and said, “Thank you,” and walked away. Passepartout, who had been listening, rushed to the pilot, and, with a joy that he could scarcely contain, exclaimed, “You are the best of good fellows!” The pilot, surprised at this sudden burst of enthusiasm, returned to the bridge, and resumed his duties, while Passepartout, overjoyed, ran to inform Fix of the good news. Fix, on the contrary, was furious, for he saw in this unexpected delay a serious obstacle to his plans. Mr. Fogg, meanwhile, had gone below, and was seated in the saloon, as if nothing had happened. He had learned the name of the steamer—the “Carnatic”—and had ascertained that it should have left Hong Kong the day before. The pilot had explained that it had been detained by the necessity of repairing its boilers. Mr. Fogg had thanked him, and had returned to his cabin, as if the matter was already decided.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The pilot went on board at six, and took his place on the bridge, to guide the “Rangoon” through the channels to the port of Hong Kong. The vessel, a steamship of considerable size and speed, was now under the expert hand of the pilot, who was well acquainted with the intricate waterways of the region. As the sun rose higher, casting golden light over the sea, the “Rangoon” moved steadily forward, its engines humming with power and precision. The crew, under the watchful eye of Captain Passepartout, worked efficiently, ensuring that every task was carried out with the utmost care. The journey through the channels was not without its challenges; the pilot had to navigate through narrow passages and avoid the many small fishing boats that dotted the waters. Despite these obstacles, the “Rangoon” made good progress, its course unerring and its speed steady. The passengers, including the ever-calm Phileas Fogg, observed the proceedings with quiet interest, their confidence in the pilot and the crew evident. As the city of Hong Kong came into view, its skyline rising against the horizon, a sense of anticipation filled the air. The pilot, satisfied with the safe passage, gave the signal for the ship to slow down as it approached the harbor. The “Rangoon” was now on the final leg of its journey to the bustling port, where new adventures awaited. The city, with its mix of East and West, promised to be a fitting next stop in Phileas Fogg’s remarkable journey around the world in eighty days.

events.title: Arrival in Hong Kong and Plans for Aouda
detailed_summary: The 'Rangoon' docked at the quay at one o'clock, and passengers began disembarking.
Fortuitous circumstances had aided Fogg; without the 'Carnatic's' boiler repair delay, it would have sailed the day before, forcing Japan-bound passengers to wait a week for the next ship.
Although Fogg was twenty-four hours late, this delay was considered unlikely to severely jeopardize the rest of his journey.
The trans-Pacific steamer from Yokohama to San Francisco was coordinated with the Hong Kong arrival, meaning it would wait.
Fogg calculated that the lost day could likely be recovered during the twenty-two-day Pacific crossing.
Thirty-five days after leaving London, he found himself approximately twenty-four hours behind his itinerary.
The 'Carnatic' was scheduled to depart at five the next morning, leaving Fogg sixteen hours in Hong Kong.
His primary task during this time was to ensure Aouda was safely placed with her wealthy relative.
Upon landing, Fogg arranged a palanquin for Aouda and himself to travel to the Club Hotel.

Fogg then tasked Passepartout with staying at the hotel to keep Aouda company while he went to find her cousin, Jeejeeh.

events.text_segment:
At one o’clock the “Rangoon” was at the quay, and the passengers were going ashore.
Chance had strangely favoured Phileas Fogg, for had not the “Carnatic” been forced to lie over for repairing her boilers, she would have left on the 6th of November, and the passengers for Japan would have been obliged to await for a week the sailing of the next steamer. Mr. Fogg was, it is true, twenty-four hours behind his time; but this could not seriously imperil the remainder of his tour.
The steamer which crossed the Pacific from Yokohama to San Francisco made a direct connection with that from Hong Kong, and it could not sail until the latter reached Yokohama; and if Mr. Fogg was twenty-four hours late on reaching Yokohama, this time would no doubt be easily regained in the voyage of twenty-two days across the Pacific. He found himself, then, about twenty-four hours behind-hand, thirty-five days after leaving London.
The “Carnatic” was announced to leave Hong Kong at five the next morning. Mr. Fogg had sixteen hours in which to attend to his business there, which was to deposit Aouda safely with her wealthy relative.
On landing, he conducted her to a palanquin, in which they repaired to the Club Hotel. A room was engaged for the young woman, and Mr. Fogg, after seeing that she wanted for nothing, set out in search of her cousin Jeejeeh. He instructed Passepartout to remain at the hotel until his return, that Aouda might not be left entirely alone.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
At one o’clock the “Rangoon” was at the quay, and the passengers were going ashore.

Phileas Fogg, Passepartout, and Aouda disembarked with calm composure, their luggage already arranged for transport. The city of Hong Kong, bustling and vibrant, stretched before them, its streets teeming with life. Fogg, ever punctual, had arranged for a carriage to take them directly to the Bank of England’s local office, where he intended to settle some financial matters before continuing their journey.

As they made their way through the crowded docks, Passepartout marveled at the sights and sounds around him. The air was thick with the scent of spices and salt, and the cries of merchants hawking their wares filled the air. Aouda, though still reserved, observed the surroundings with quiet interest, her presence a reminder of the journey’s emotional stakes.

Fogg, meanwhile, remained focused on the schedule. He had calculated every minute with precision, and any delay was a threat to his wager. Yet, despite his rigid adherence to time, there was a quiet dignity in his demeanor, a sense of purpose that inspired those around him.

At the bank, Fogg conducted his business swiftly and efficiently. Then, with the afternoon still young, he and his companions set off for the railway station, where the next leg of their journey awaited. The train to Calcutta would depart at precisely 5:30 p.m., and Fogg intended to be aboard it on time, as he always was.

events.title: Search for Aouda's Relative Reveals He Has Left China
detailed_summary: Mr. Fogg went to the Exchange, confident he could easily locate Aouda's prominent Parsee merchant relative there.
He approached a broker and asked about Jeejeeh.
The broker informed him that Jeejeeh had retired from business two years prior with a large fortune.
Furthermore, Jeejeeh had left China and moved to Europe, likely Holland, where he had strong business connections.
Phileas Fogg returned directly to the hotel.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Fogg repaired to the Exchange, where, he did not doubt, every one would know so wealthy and considerable a personage as the Parsee merchant.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg returned to the hotel, begged a moment’s conversation with Aouda, and without more ado, apprised her that Jeejeeh was no longer at Hong Kong, but probably in Holland.

events.text_segment: Mr. Fogg repaired to the Exchange, where, he did not doubt, every one would know so wealthy and considerable a personage as the Parsee merchant. Meeting a broker, he made the inquiry, to learn that Jeejeeh had left China two years before, and, retiring from business with an immense fortune, had taken up his residence in Europe—in Holland the broker thought, with the merchants of which country he had principally traded. Phileas Fogg returned to the hotel, begged a moment’s conversation with Aouda, and without more ado, apprised her that Jeejeeh was no longer at Hong Kong, but probably in Holland.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Mr. Fogg repaired to the Exchange, where, he did not doubt, every one would know so wealthy and considerable a personage as the Parsee merchant. He had scarcely entered the great hall, with its marble columns and its bronze statues, when he addressed a broker, who was arranging some papers on a counter.

"Do you know a merchant named Jeejeeh?"

"Jeejeeh!" replied the broker. "Why, that was the name of one of the most considerable men in Bombay. But he retired from business two years ago, and has since been living on his fortune."

"Is he in India still?"

"No; he left China some time ago, and is now in Europe, I believe. He has large connections in Holland."

Phileas Fogg, thus informed, returned directly to the hotel, where Aouda was waiting. He had no longer any fear for her future; her cousin, the Parsee, was rich and independent, and would, no doubt, be able to protect her. But he had still to accomplish his journey around the world, and he was determined to do so. He went to his room, and, after a hasty supper, prepared for the night, with the same calmness and precision as if he had not a care in the world.

Mr. Fogg repaired to the Exchange, where, he did not doubt, every one would know so wealthy and considerable a personage as the Parsee merchant. He inquired at several counters, and at length addressed a broker, who was engaged in some calculations.

"Do you know a merchant named Jeejeeh?"

"Jeejeeh!" replied the broker. "Why, that was the name of one of the most considerable men in Bombay. But he retired from business two years ago, and has since been living on his fortune."

"Is he in India still?"

"No; he left China some time ago, and is now in Europe, I believe. He has large connections in Holland."

Phileas Fogg, thus informed, returned directly to the hotel, where Aouda was waiting. He requested a moment's conversation with her. He told her briefly of Jeejeeh's retirement and his present whereabouts, and assured her that her cousin, the Parsee, was rich and independent, and would, no doubt, be able to protect her.

events.title: Aouda Invited to Accompany Fogg to Europe
detailed_summary: Upon hearing the news from Fogg that her relative was likely in Holland, Aouda initially remained silent, reflecting.
She touched her forehead thoughtfully for a few moments.
In her gentle voice, she asked Mr. Fogg for guidance on what she should do.
Fogg responded simply and directly, stating she should continue on to Europe.
When Aouda expressed concern about imposing on him or disrupting his plans, Fogg reassured her.
He stated firmly that her presence was neither an intrusion nor an impediment to his journey.
He immediately called for Passepartout.
Fogg instructed Passepartout to go to the 'Carnatic' and book three cabins for their onward journey.
Passepartout was pleased that Aouda, whom he liked, would be continuing the voyage with them.
He departed swiftly to carry out his master's instructions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Aouda at first said nothing.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout, delighted that the young woman, who was very gracious to him, was going to continue the journey with them, went off at a brisk gait to obey his master’s order.

events.text_segment:
Aouda at first said nothing. She passed her hand across her forehead, and reflected a few moments. Then, in her sweet, soft voice, she said: “What ought I to do, Mr. Fogg?”
“It is very simple,” responded the gentleman. “Go on to Europe.”
“But I cannot intrude—”
“You do not intrude, nor do you in the least embarrass my project. Passepartout!”
“Monsieur.”
“Go to the ‘Carnatic,’ and engage three cabins.”
Passepartout, delighted that the young woman, who was very gracious to him, was going to continue the journey with them, went off at a brisk gait to obey his master’s order.

**Chapter Title:** *CHAPTER XVIII. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG, PASSEPARTOUT, AND FIX GO EACH ABOUT HIS BUSINESS*

**Generated Literary Segment:**

*Aouda at first said nothing.* Her brow furrowed slightly, her fingers resting lightly against her temple as if weighing the weight of the world. The news that her long-lost relative might be in Holland had struck her with a quiet, reverent shock. She sat in silence, the soft glow of the lamplight casting a warm halo around her, as if time itself had paused to let her gather her thoughts.

After a few moments, she lifted her gaze to meet Mr. Fogg’s steady, unflinching eyes. “What would you have me do?” she asked, her voice as gentle as a whisper in the night. It was not a question of defiance, but of trust—she looked to him for direction, as one might look to a lighthouse in a storm.

Phileas Fogg, ever the embodiment of precision and calm, responded with the same quiet certainty that had defined his every action thus far. “You will continue with us to Europe,” he said, his tone devoid of hesitation. “Your presence is neither an intrusion nor an impediment.”

Aouda’s eyes widened slightly, as if surprised by the strength of his conviction. “But I would not wish to disrupt your plans,” she said, her voice tinged with concern. “I would not wish to be a burden.”

Fogg’s expression did not waver. “You are no burden,” he replied, his voice firm yet kind. “You are a companion on this journey, and I will not hear otherwise.”

With that, he turned to Passepartout, who had been standing nearby, listening intently. “Passepartout,” Fogg said, “go to the *Carnatic* and secure three cabins for us. We will be continuing our journey.”

Passepartout, always eager to please and delighted that Aouda would be joining them, nodded with a grin. “Right away, monsieur!” he said, and with a quick bow to Aouda, he was off, his boots echoing down the corridor as he set off to carry out his master’s orders.

Aouda watched him go, a small smile playing at the corners of her lips. She turned back to Fogg, her expression one of quiet gratitude. The journey ahead was uncertain, but for now, she was not alone.

---

**End of Segment.**

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XIX. IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT TAKES A TOO GREAT INTEREST IN HIS MASTER, AND WHAT COMES OF IT

events.title: Hong Kong's British Character and Passepartout's Observations
detailed_summary: The narrative introduces Hong Kong as a British territory acquired in 1842, highlighting its strategic location near the Canton River and Macao.
It emphasizes Hong Kong's success in overtaking Macao in trade and its development into a major port city with significant infrastructure.
The city's appearance is described as remarkably English, resembling a town from Kent or Surrey transplanted to Asia.
Passepartout explores the Victoria port area, observing the mix of conveyances like palanquins and the diverse population of Chinese, Japanese, and Europeans.
He recognizes the strong British influence, similar to what he saw in Bombay, Calcutta, and Singapore.
The port is depicted as a busy hub with various international ships, warships, trading vessels, and local Chinese watercraft.
Passepartout notices elderly Chinese men dressed in yellow and learns from a barber that this color signifies reaching the age of eighty, a custom he finds peculiar and amusing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Hong Kong is an island which came into the possession of the English by the Treaty of Nankin, after the war of 1842; and the colonising genius of the English has created upon it an important city and an excellent port.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout, without exactly knowing why, thought this very funny.

events.text_segment:
Hong Kong is an island which came into the possession of the English by the Treaty of Nankin, after the war of 1842; and the colonising genius of the English has created upon it an important city and an excellent port. The island is situated at the mouth of the Canton River, and is separated by about sixty miles from the Portuguese town of Macao, on the opposite coast. Hong Kong has beaten Macao in the struggle for the Chinese trade, and now the greater part of the transportation of Chinese goods finds its depot at the former place. Docks, hospitals, wharves, a Gothic cathedral, a government house, macadamised streets, give to Hong Kong the appearance of a town in Kent or Surrey transferred by some strange magic to the antipodes.
Passepartout wandered, with his hands in his pockets, towards the Victoria port, gazing as he went at the curious palanquins and other modes of conveyance, and the groups of Chinese, Japanese, and Europeans who passed to and fro in the streets. Hong Kong seemed to him not unlike Bombay, Calcutta, and Singapore, since, like them, it betrayed everywhere the evidence of English supremacy. At the Victoria port he found a confused mass of ships of all nations: English, French, American, and Dutch, men-of-war and trading vessels, Japanese and Chinese junks, sempas, tankas, and flower-boats, which formed so many floating parterres. Passepartout noticed in the crowd a number of the natives who seemed very old and were dressed in yellow. On going into a barber’s to get shaved he learned that these ancient men were all at least eighty years old, at which age they are permitted to wear yellow, which is the Imperial colour. Passepartout, without exactly knowing why, thought this very funny.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Hong Kong is an island which came into the possession of the English by the Treaty of Nankin, after the war of 1842; and the colonising genius of the English has created upon it an important city and an excellent port. The island lies at the mouth of the Canton River, and is but a few miles distant from Macao, the Portuguese settlement, which, in former days, was the great emporium of the East. But Hong Kong, with its fine natural harbour and its easy access to the interior, has entirely superseded Macao in the eyes of commerce, and is now the principal emporium of the Chinese coast. The city, built upon the island, is a perfect English town, with its rows of houses, its broad streets, its public buildings, and its churches, and one might fancy oneself in some town of Kent or Surrey, so complete is the resemblance. Passepartout, who had now become quite a cosmopolite, was delighted with this English colony, and he strolled about the town with the air of a man who had seen the world. He passed through the Victoria port, where all sorts of conveyances were to be seen—palanquins, rickshaws, and carriages of every description, drawn by horses, mules, or men. The population was a curious mixture of Chinese, Japanese, and Europeans, and the streets were alive with a constant stream of people. Passepartout noticed the British influence everywhere, as he had seen it in Bombay, Calcutta, and Singapore. The port was a scene of incessant activity, with ships of all nations, from the great steamers of the Peninsular and Oriental Company to the little junks of the Chinese fishermen. The warships of the English navy, with their white sails and black hulls, looked like giants among the smaller vessels. Passepartout was particularly struck by the number of old Chinese men dressed in yellow, and he inquired the reason of this peculiarity of costume. A barber, who was shaving one of them, explained that the yellow was the colour of age, and that it was worn by those who had reached the venerable age of eighty. Passepartout found this custom very strange, and he could not help laughing at the idea of a man changing his livery when he became old. But he was a good-natured fellow, and he did not mean to be disrespectful; he only thought it a curious custom, and he resolved to remember it, in case he should ever have occasion to speak of it.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Hong Kong is an island which came into the possession of the English by the Treaty of Nankin, after the war of 1842; and the colonising genius of the English has created upon it an important city and an excellent port. The island is small, but its position is of the greatest importance, commanding the mouth of the Canton River, and giving the English a secure and convenient station in the Far East. The city of Hong Kong, built on the steep hillsides and extending along the bay, is a striking example of the enterprise and perseverance of the British. The streets are well paved, the buildings are substantial, and the docks are among the finest in the world. The population is a mixture of Chinese and Europeans, and the city is a great centre of commerce and trade. The English have also established a naval station at Hong Kong, and the island is one of the most important possessions of the British Empire in the East. The climate is warm and humid, and the vegetation is luxuriant. The surrounding waters are teeming with fish, and the island is a favourite resort for sportsmen and naturalists. The English have also established a number of public institutions, including schools, hospitals, and churches, and the city is a model of order and cleanliness. The people are industrious and enterprising, and the city is a thriving and prosperous place. The English have done much to develop the resources of the island, and to make it a flourishing and important city. The island is a valuable possession, and its importance is likely to increase in the future.

events.title: Encounter with Fix and News of Early Departure
detailed_summary: Passepartout arrives at the quay to board the "Carnatic" and sees Fix pacing, looking agitated.
Passepartout privately considers Fix's presence bad news for the Reform Club members he believes Fix represents.
He greets Fix cheerfully, masking his awareness of Fix's unease.
Fix is internally frustrated as the arrest warrant for Fogg has not arrived, and Hong Kong is the last British port on their route, risking Fogg's escape.
Passepartout inquires if Fix plans to continue the journey to America with them.
Fix confirms his intention tersely.
Passepartout laughs, saying he knew Fix couldn't leave them, and suggests they secure their passage.
They enter the steamer office and book cabins for four people.
The clerk informs them the ship's repairs are complete, and departure is moved up to that evening instead of the following morning.
Passepartout sees this as advantageous for his master and decides to inform Fogg immediately.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On reaching the quay where they were to embark on the “Carnatic,” he was not astonished to find Fix walking up and down.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I will go and let him know.”

events.text_segment:
On reaching the quay where they were to embark on the “Carnatic,” he was not astonished to find Fix walking up and down. The detective seemed very much disturbed and disappointed.
“This is bad,” muttered Passepartout, “for the gentlemen of the Reform Club!” He accosted Fix with a merry smile, as if he had not perceived that gentleman’s chagrin. The detective had, indeed, good reasons to inveigh against the bad luck which pursued him. The warrant had not come! It was certainly on the way, but as certainly it could not now reach Hong Kong for several days; and, this being the last English territory on Mr. Fogg’s route, the robber would escape, unless he could manage to detain him.
“Well, Monsieur Fix,” said Passepartout, “have you decided to go with us so far as America?”
“Yes,” returned Fix, through his set teeth.
“Good!” exclaimed Passepartout, laughing heartily. “I knew you could not persuade yourself to separate from us. Come and engage your berth.”
They entered the steamer office and secured cabins for four persons. The clerk, as he gave them the tickets, informed them that, the repairs on the “Carnatic” having been completed, the steamer would leave that very evening, and not next morning, as had been announced.
“That will suit my master all the better,” said Passepartout. “I will go and let him know.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: On reaching the quay where they were to embark on the “Carnatic,” he was not astonished to find Fix walking up and down. The detective was evidently in a state of great unease, and Passepartout, who had no difficulty in reading the signs, could not help feeling that the presence of the officer was a bad omen for his master. He had no doubt that Fix was acting under the orders of the Reform Club, and that the Englishman’s arrest was being prepared. But Passepartout was not the man to be disconcerted by such a contingency. He greeted Fix with his usual cordiality, and asked him how he was. Fix, who was not in the mood for civilities, replied with a short nod. He was thinking of the warrant, which had not yet arrived, and of the fact that Hong Kong was the last British port on the route. If Phileas Fogg escaped from this place, he would be beyond the reach of English justice. “Are you going to America with us?” asked Passepartout, with a laugh. “Yes,” said Fix, in a dry tone. “I thought you would not leave us,” added the Frenchman. “Come, let us get our passage.” They entered the steamer office, and Fix, after some hesitation, engaged a cabin for four. The clerk, who was a very communicative person, informed them that the repairs of the “Carnatic” had been completed, and that she would sail that evening instead of the following morning. Passepartout saw in this an advantage for his master, and lost no time in hastening to inform him of the change.

As the passengers began to board, Fix approached them, feigning politeness. "Mr. Fogg, I hope you are not leaving the country under any false pretenses," he said, his tone laced with subtle accusation. Fogg, unfazed, replied, "I am merely making a journey, Inspector. I trust that is not a crime." The exchange was brief but charged, and Fix's eyes narrowed slightly. As the "Carnatic" cast off from the dock, Fogg and Passepartout watched the shore recede, unaware that their journey had just become more perilous. Fix, still on the dock, clenched his fists. He was determined to catch the elusive Mr. Fogg in the act, no matter how far he had to go.

events.title: An Invitation to an Opium Den
detailed_summary: Fix decides on a drastic measure: revealing everything to Passepartout to secure his help in delaying Phileas Fogg in Hong Kong.
He invites Passepartout into a tavern he spots on the quay.
The tavern turns out to be an elaborately decorated opium den.
They observe a large bed where several patrons lie in deep sleep.
Numerous customers drink various alcoholic beverages while smoking pipes filled with opium mixed with rose essence.
Waiters attend to smokers who succumb to the drug, moving them onto the communal bed, which already holds about twenty individuals.
The text laments the opium trade perpetuated by English merchants and the devastating impact of the drug on its users, despite Chinese government efforts to stop it.
The pervasiveness of opium addiction across social classes in China and its deadly consequences are noted.
Fix and Passepartout find themselves in this environment while looking for a drink.
Although penniless, Passepartout accepts Fix's treat, planning to reciprocate later.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Fix now decided to make a bold move; he resolved to tell Passepartout all.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout had no money, but willingly accepted Fix’s invitation in the hope of returning the obligation at some future time.

events.text_segment:
Fix now decided to make a bold move; he resolved to tell Passepartout all. It seemed to be the only possible means of keeping Phileas Fogg several days longer at Hong Kong. He accordingly invited his companion into a tavern which caught his eye on the quay. On entering, they found themselves in a large room handsomely decorated, at the end of which was a large camp-bed furnished with cushions. Several persons lay upon this bed in a deep sleep. At the small tables which were arranged about the room some thirty customers were drinking English beer, porter, gin, and brandy; smoking, the while, long red clay pipes stuffed with little balls of opium mingled with essence of rose. From time to time one of the smokers, overcome with the narcotic, would slip under the table, whereupon the waiters, taking him by the head and feet, carried and laid him upon the bed. The bed already supported twenty of these stupefied sots.
Fix and Passepartout saw that they were in a smoking-house haunted by those wretched, cadaverous, idiotic creatures to whom the English merchants sell every year the miserable drug called opium, to the amount of one million four hundred thousand pounds—thousands devoted to one of the most despicable vices which afflict humanity! The Chinese government has in vain attempted to deal with the evil by stringent laws. It passed gradually from the rich, to whom it was at first exclusively reserved, to the lower classes, and then its ravages could not be arrested. Opium is smoked everywhere, at all times, by men and women, in the Celestial Empire; and, once accustomed to it, the victims cannot dispense with it, except by suffering horrible bodily contortions and agonies. A great smoker can smoke as many as eight pipes a day; but he dies in five years. It was in one of these dens that Fix and Passepartout, in search of a friendly glass, found themselves. Passepartout had no money, but willingly accepted Fix’s invitation in the hope of returning the obligation at some future time.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Fix now decided to make a bold move; he resolved to tell Passepartout all. He accordingly invited the Frenchman into a tavern which he observed on the quay. The establishment was one of those Chinese opium dens, so numerous in the ports of the East, and which are to the senses what the gambling-house is to the passions. The room was lighted by a few tallow candles, and the air was heavy with the fumes of opium. In one corner of the apartment was a large bed, on which lay several persons in a profound sleep, their limbs relaxed, their features distorted by the effects of the drug. Around them were groups of men, some smoking, some drinking, and all in a state of torpor. The smokers used long pipes, in which the opium was mixed with rose essence; and the waiters, who were generally Chinese, moved about with a noiseless step, and with a look of indifference to the sufferings of their customers. The English merchants, who had introduced this fatal traffic into China, had made it a source of immense profit, and the Chinese government, though it had endeavored to put a stop to it, had been unable to resist the influence of the foreign traders. The opium habit had spread through all classes of society, and was fast undermining the moral and physical strength of the nation. Fix and Passepartout, in their search for a drink, had found themselves in this den of vice. Passepartout, though he had no money, accepted the glass of brandy which Fix offered him, and promised to repay it when he could.

Phileas Fogg, the enigmatic Englishman, had been the victim of a cruel trick, and Fix, the detective, had been the one to play the part of the villain. He had followed Fogg from London, believing that the gentleman was the thief who had robbed the Bank of England. But now, with the journey nearly over, Fix realized that he had been mistaken. Fogg was innocent, and the real criminal was still at large. He had to make amends, and the only way to do so was to reveal the truth to Passepartout. He knew that the Frenchman was loyal to his master, and that he would not take the news lightly. But Fix also knew that Passepartout was intelligent and resourceful, and that he would understand the gravity of the situation. So, with a heavy heart and a clear mind, Fix approached Passepartout and prepared to tell him everything.

Fix physically stops him, stating he needs to have a serious conversation.
Passepartout tries to postpone the talk until the next day, claiming lack of time.

Passepartout sits down again, asking what Fix needs to discuss.
Fix leans in, lowers his voice, and asks if Passepartout has figured out his true identity.
Passepartout, smiling confidently, affirms that he has.

events.text_segment:
They ordered two bottles of port, to which the Frenchman did ample justice, whilst Fix observed him with close attention. They chatted about the journey, and Passepartout was especially merry at the idea that Fix was going to continue it with them. When the bottles were empty, however, he rose to go and tell his master of the change in the time of the sailing of the “Carnatic.”
Fix caught him by the arm, and said, “Wait a moment.”
“What for, Mr. Fix?”
“I want to have a serious talk with you.”
“A serious talk!” cried Passepartout, drinking up the little wine that was left in the bottom of his glass. “Well, we’ll talk about it to-morrow; I haven’t time now.”
“Stay! What I have to say concerns your master.”
Passepartout, at this, looked attentively at his companion. Fix’s face seemed to have a singular expression. He resumed his seat.
“What is it that you have to say?”
Fix placed his hand upon Passepartout’s arm, and, lowering his voice, said, “You have guessed who I am?”
“Parbleu!” said Passepartout, smiling.
“Then I’m going to tell you everything—”
“Now that I know everything, my friend! Ah! that’s very good. But go on, go on. First, though, let me tell you that those gentlemen have put themselves to a useless expense.”
“Useless!” said Fix. “You speak confidently. It’s clear that you don’t know how large the sum is.”
“Of course I do,” returned Passepartout.

events.text_segment:
“Twenty thousand pounds.”
“Fifty-five thousand!” answered Fix, pressing his companion’s hand.
“What!” cried the Frenchman. “Has Monsieur Fogg dared—fifty-five thousand pounds! Well, there’s all the more reason for not losing an instant,” he continued, getting up hastily.
Fix pushed Passepartout back in his chair, and resumed: “Fifty-five thousand pounds; and if I succeed, I get two thousand pounds. If you’ll help me, I’ll let you have five hundred of them.”
“Help you?” cried Passepartout, whose eyes were standing wide open.
“Yes; help me keep Mr. Fogg here for two or three days.”
“Why, what are you saying? Those gentlemen are not satisfied with following my master and suspecting his honour, but they must try to put obstacles in his way! I blush for them!”
“What do you mean?”
“I mean that it is a piece of shameful trickery. They might as well waylay Mr. Fogg and put his money in their pockets!”
“That’s just what we count on doing.”
“It’s a conspiracy, then,” cried Passepartout, who became more and more excited as the liquor mounted in his head, for he drank without perceiving it. “A real conspiracy! And gentlemen, too. Bah!”
Fix began to be puzzled.
“Members of the Reform Club!” continued Passepartout. “You must know, Monsieur Fix, that my master is an honest man, and that, when he makes a wager, he tries to win it fairly!”
“But who do you think I am?” asked Fix, looking at him intently.
“Parbleu! An agent of the members of the Reform Club, sent out here to interrupt my master’s journey. But, though I found you out some time ago, I’ve taken good care to say nothing about it to Mr. Fogg.”
“He knows nothing, then?”
“Nothing,” replied Passepartout, again emptying his glass.
The detective passed his hand across his forehead, hesitating before he spoke again. What should he do? Passepartout’s mistake seemed sincere, but it made his design more difficult. It was evident that the servant was not the master’s accomplice, as Fix had been inclined to suspect.
“Well,” said the detective to himself, “as he is not an accomplice, he will help me.”
He had no time to lose: Fogg must be detained at Hong Kong, so he resolved to make a clean breast of it.
“Listen to me,” said Fix abruptly. “I am not, as you think, an agent of the members of the Reform Club—”
“Bah!” retorted Passepartout, with an air of raillery.
“I am a police detective, sent out here by the London office.”
“You, a detective?”
“I will prove it. Here is my commission.”
Passepartout was speechless with astonishment when Fix displayed this document, the genuineness of which could not be doubted.
“Mr. Fogg’s wager,” resumed Fix, “is only a pretext, of which you and the gentlemen of the Reform are dupes. He had a motive for securing your innocent complicity.”
“But why?”
“Listen. On the 28th of last September a robbery of fifty-five thousand pounds was committed at the Bank of England by a person whose description was fortunately secured. Here is his description; it answers exactly to that of Mr. Phileas Fogg.”

**Chapter Title:** *CHAPTER XIX. IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT TAKES A TOO GREAT INTEREST IN HIS MASTER, AND WHAT COMES OF IT*

**Generated Literary Segment:**

“Twenty thousand pounds.”  
Passepartout blinked, his eyes wide with disbelief. Fix, the man who had seemed so composed and calculating, leaned forward with a measured air. “No, my good man,” he corrected, “it is fifty-five thousand.”  
Passepartout’s hand trembled slightly as he gripped the edge of the table. “Fifty-five thousand?” he echoed, his voice rising. “That is no wager, that is a fortune! My master—”  
“Your master,” Fix interrupted, “is the very man who has stolen that fortune.”  
Passepartout recoiled, his face a mixture of horror and confusion. “You would have me believe my master, the most honorable man I have ever known, is a thief?”  
Fix, with a calm that only deepened the tension, pushed Passepartout gently back into his chair. “I offer you £500 of the £2,000 reward if you will help me detain him.”  
Passepartout’s face darkened. “You would rob him yourself, then? You, who claim to be a man of the law?”  
Fix’s expression remained unreadable. “It is not robbery if it is justice.”  
Passepartout, now more agitated, waved a hand in the air. “This is the work of dishonorable men, a conspiracy of so-called gentlemen who would see my master fail.”  
Fix raised an eyebrow. “You are mistaken, Passepartout. I am not one of them.”  
The valet, emboldened by the drink and his own conviction, leaned in. “Then who are you?”  
Fix paused, then, with a deliberate slowness, produced a folded document from his coat. “I am a detective from London,” he said, “and I am not working for the Reform Club.”  
Passepartout laughed, a nervous, almost boyish sound. “You expect me to believe that?”  
Fix unfolded the commission and placed it on the table. “Read it, if you doubt me.”  
Passepartout stared at the paper, his mind racing. “Then why follow my master? Why not arrest him?”  
Fix leaned back, his voice low. “Because he is not running from the Reform Club. He is running from the law. The Bank of England was robbed on the 28th of September. The description of the thief matches Phileas Fogg exactly.”  
Passepartout sat in stunned silence, the weight of the revelation pressing down on him like a storm cloud. The journey, the wager, the impossible race around the world—it was all a cover. And he, Passepartout, had been blind to it all.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Twenty thousand pounds.”

Phileas Fogg, the enigmatic and punctual gentleman of London, calmly stated the sum without a hint of hesitation. The words, though simple, carried a weight that silenced the room. The members of the Reform Club, gathered in the opulent yet quiet drawing room, exchanged glances, their curiosity piqued. It was an unusual proposition, one that defied the very nature of their staid and predictable existence.

“I propose to circumnavigate the globe in eighty days,” Fogg continued, his voice steady and measured. “I will leave London this very evening and return before the stipulated time. If I succeed, I shall win the wager. If I fail, I shall forfeit twenty thousand pounds.”

A murmur of astonishment rippled through the assembled men. The idea of traveling around the world in such a short time was, to most, an impossibility. The world was vast, the distances immense, and the means of transport still in their infancy. Yet Fogg, with his unwavering confidence and precise manner, seemed to believe it entirely feasible.

“Do you mean to say you have already made the necessary arrangements?” asked Mr. Fix, the club’s French detective, his eyes narrowing with intrigue.

“I have,” Fogg replied. “I have secured passage on the steamer that departs from Liverpool at 8:45 this evening. I have also arranged for a first-class cabin on the steamer that will take me from Suez to Bombay. From there, I shall proceed by train to Calcutta, and then by steamer to Hong Kong. I shall cross the Pacific to San Francisco, travel by railroad to New York, and finally return to London by steamer.”

The room was now in a state of near disbelief. The plan was not only ambitious but meticulously detailed. Fogg’s knowledge of the world’s transportation systems was astonishing. He had accounted for every possible delay, every conceivable obstacle. He had even included a contingency for the unpredictable nature of the world itself.

“Twenty thousand pounds,” murmured one of the club members, shaking his head. “It’s a fortune. And for what? A bet?”

Fogg’s expression remained impassive. “It is not merely a bet,” he said. “It is a test of time, of precision, of the modern world’s ability to connect distant lands in an unprecedented manner. It is a challenge to the very notion of distance and delay.”

The room fell silent once more, the weight of Fogg’s words settling over the men like a shroud. They had witnessed the birth of an extraordinary journey, one that would test the limits of human ingenuity and perseverance. And so, with the clock ticking and the world waiting, Phileas Fogg prepared to embark on a journey that would change the course of his life—and perhaps the world’s perception of time itself.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What nonsense!” cried Passepartout, striking the table with his fist.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And, after paying his bill, Fix left the tavern.

events.text_segment:
“What nonsense!” cried Passepartout, striking the table with his fist. “My master is the most honourable of men!”
“How can you tell? You know scarcely anything about him. You went into his service the day he came away; and he came away on a foolish pretext, without trunks, and carrying a large amount in banknotes. And yet you are bold enough to assert that he is an honest man!”
“Yes, yes,” repeated the poor fellow, mechanically.
“Would you like to be arrested as his accomplice?”
Passepartout, overcome by what he had heard, held his head between his hands, and did not dare to look at the detective. Phileas Fogg, the saviour of Aouda, that brave and generous man, a robber! And yet how many presumptions there were against him! Passepartout essayed to reject the suspicions which forced themselves upon his mind; he did not wish to believe that his master was guilty.
“Well, what do you want of me?” said he, at last, with an effort.
“See here,” replied Fix; “I have tracked Mr. Fogg to this place, but as yet I have failed to receive the warrant of arrest for which I sent to London. You must help me to keep him here in Hong Kong—”
“I! But I—”
“I will share with you the two thousand pounds reward offered by the Bank of England.”
“Never!” replied Passepartout, who tried to rise, but fell back, exhausted in mind and body.
“Mr. Fix,” he stammered, “even should what you say be true—if my master is really the robber you are seeking for—which I deny—I have been, am, in his service; I have seen his generosity and goodness; and I will never betray him—not for all the gold in the world. I come from a village where they don’t eat that kind of bread!”
“You refuse?”
“I refuse.”
“Consider that I’ve said nothing,” said Fix; “and let us drink.”
“Yes; let us drink!”
Passepartout felt himself yielding more and more to the effects of the liquor. Fix, seeing that he must, at all hazards, be separated from his master, wished to entirely overcome him. Some pipes full of opium lay upon the table. Fix slipped one into Passepartout’s hand. He took it, put it between his lips, lit it, drew several puffs, and his head, becoming heavy under the influence of the narcotic, fell upon the table.
“At last!” said Fix, seeing Passepartout unconscious. “Mr. Fogg will not be informed of the ‘Carnatic’s’ departure; and, if he is, he will have to go without this cursed Frenchman!”
And, after paying his bill, Fix left the tavern.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“What nonsense!” cried Passepartout, striking the table with his fist. “My master is an honest man, and I will not hear him spoken of otherwise!”

Fix, with a calm and ironical smile, replied: “You are very confident, my good man, considering how little you know of Mr. Fogg. You have only been in his service a short time, and yet you are ready to defend him against all the world.”

“I know him well enough,” said Passepartout, “and I know that he is generous, noble, and true!”

“Ah! You think so, do you?” said Fix, leaning back in his chair. “Then tell me, how is it that he left England without a single piece of luggage, with only a few thousand pounds in his pocket, and embarked on a journey round the world for no apparent reason? That is the conduct of a man of honor, is it?”

Passepartout hesitated. He could not answer. He had never thought of these things before, and the detective’s words struck him like a blow.

“Come, come,” continued Fix, “do not be so obstinate. You are not a fool, and you must see that something is wrong. I have my suspicions, and I have my orders. If you will not help me, I shall be obliged to take other means.”

Passepartout looked at him in horror. “You would arrest me?” he said.

“I would,” replied Fix, “if I had the slightest proof that you were an accomplice. But I have no such proof. I only want your help. You are the only man who can prevent Mr. Fogg from leaving Hong Kong before I have time to serve the warrant.”

“What do you want me to do?” asked Passepartout, his voice trembling.

“Nothing more than to say nothing,” said Fix. “Let me take care of the rest. And if you do this, I will not forget it. There is a reward of two thousand pounds offered by the Bank of England for the arrest of Mr. Fogg. I will share it with you.”

Passepartout turned pale. “No!” he said, rising from his chair. “No! I would not take a farthing from you, even if I thought my master guilty, which I do not!”

He staggered back into his seat, overcome by the weight of his own words. Fix watched him in silence for a moment, then said: “Very well. Let us drop the subject.”

Passepartout nodded, and Fix ordered another bottle of wine. The servant brought it, and the two men drank in silence. Passepartout, however, drank more heavily than his companion, and soon his eyes began to glaze.

Fix, watching him closely, took from his pocket a small pipe, filled it with opium, and placed it in Passepartout’s hand. “Try this,” he said. “It will make you forget your troubles.”

Passepartout took the pipe, lit it, and began to smoke. The fumes soon took effect. His head grew heavy, his limbs relaxed, and he leaned forward on the table, his face buried in his hands.

Fix rose, paid the bill, and left the room. As he stepped into the street, he muttered to himself: “Now, Mr. Fogg, you will not be warned of the ‘Carnatic’s’ early departure. You will go on without your servant, and I shall have you yet.”

Passepartout took the pipe, lit it, and began to smoke. The fumes soon took effect. His head grew heavy, his limbs relaxed, and he leaned forward on the table, his face buried in his hands.

Fix rose, paid the bill, and left the room. As he stepped into the street, he muttered to himself: “Now, Mr. Fogg, you will not be warned of the ‘Carnatic’s’ early departure. You will go on without your servant, and I shall have you yet.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“What nonsense!” cried Passepartout, striking the table with his fist. “You say it is impossible to go around the world in eighty days? I have seen it done, and I have done it myself!”

Phileas Fogg, his employer and companion, looked up calmly from his newspaper. “I do not doubt your word, Passepartout,” he said, “but I must insist that the world is not so easily circled. The distances are great, the obstacles many. A man must be both rich and reckless to attempt such a journey.”

Passepartout laughed heartily. “Reckless? Perhaps. But I have never known you to be reckless, sir. You are the most punctual man I have ever met. You live by the clock, and yet you would deny the possibility of this grand adventure?”

Fogg set down his paper and fixed his servant with a steady gaze. “I do not deny it, Passepartout. I merely state the facts. The journey will require precision, timing, and a great deal of money. I have the means, and I have the will. But I must know if it is truly possible.”

Passepartout leaned forward, his eyes alight with excitement. “It is possible, sir. I have seen it. I have felt the wind in my face as we raced across the plains of America, I have watched the sun rise over the Indian Ocean as we sailed toward Ceylon, and I have stood in the snows of Siberia as we pressed on toward the East. It is not just a journey, sir—it is a test of will, of time, of the very limits of human endurance.”

Fogg was silent for a moment, considering his words. Then, with a quiet smile, he said, “Very well, Passepartout. If you believe it can be done, then I shall do it. I shall travel around the world in eighty days.”

Passepartout’s eyes widened in delight. “Then it is settled! We shall begin at once. I shall pack our bags, and we shall set out before the morning sun has risen.”

Fogg nodded. “And I shall make the necessary arrangements. I shall book our passage, secure our tickets, and ensure that every detail is in order. We shall not be delayed by the whims of fate.”

And so, with a handshake and a shared sense of purpose, the two men set out on the journey that would change their lives forever. They would face storms and delays, misunderstandings and dangers, but they would also see the world in a way few ever had. And in the end, they would return not only to London, but to a deeper understanding of themselves and the world they had traveled through.
