events.title: Race Across America by Train and Final Disappointment
detailed_summary: Omaha serves as the terminus for the Pacific Railroad and connects eastward via the Chicago and Rock Island Railroad.
Upon reaching the Omaha station, Fogg and his party find a train ready to depart and board immediately.
They forgo any sightseeing in Omaha, prioritizing speed.
The train travels swiftly through Iowa (Council Bluffs, Des Moines, Iowa City), crosses the Mississippi River at Davenport during the night, and enters Illinois via Rock Island.
They arrive in Chicago, depicted as rebuilt and thriving, on the afternoon of the 10th.
With nine hundred miles remaining to New York, Fogg immediately transfers to the Pittsburgh, Fort Wayne, and Chicago Railway train.
The train speeds through Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey, passing rapidly through towns.
Finally, the Hudson River comes into view.
At 11:15 PM on the evening of the 11th, the train arrives at the New York station, right beside the Cunard line pier.
They learn immediately that the Liverpool steamer, the "China," had departed just 45 minutes earlier.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Pacific Railroad proper finds its terminus at this important Nebraska town.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The “China,” for Liverpool, had started three-quarters of an hour before!

events.text_segment:
The Pacific Railroad proper finds its terminus at this important Nebraska town. Omaha is connected with Chicago by the Chicago and Rock Island Railroad, which runs directly east, and passes fifty stations.
A train was ready to start when Mr. Fogg and his party reached the station, and they only had time to get into the cars. They had seen nothing of Omaha; but Passepartout confessed to himself that this was not to be regretted, as they were not travelling to see the sights.
The train passed rapidly across the State of Iowa, by Council Bluffs, Des Moines, and Iowa City. During the night it crossed the Mississippi at Davenport, and by Rock Island entered Illinois. The next day, which was the 10th, at four o’clock in the evening, it reached Chicago, already risen from its ruins, and more proudly seated than ever on the borders of its beautiful Lake Michigan.
Nine hundred miles separated Chicago from New York; but trains are not wanting at Chicago. Mr. Fogg passed at once from one to the other, and the locomotive of the Pittsburgh, Fort Wayne, and Chicago Railway left at full speed, as if it fully comprehended that that gentleman had no time to lose. It traversed Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey like a flash, rushing through towns with antique names, some of which had streets and car-tracks, but as yet no houses. At last the Hudson came into view; and, at a quarter-past eleven in the evening of the 11th, the train stopped in the station on the right bank of the river, before the very pier of the Cunard line.
The “China,” for Liverpool, had started three-quarters of an hour before!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The Pacific Railroad proper finds its terminus at this important Nebraska town. Omaha is the great distributing centre of the West, and thence the Chicago and Rock Island Railroad extends eastward. Phileas Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout, on arriving at the Omaha station, found a train in readiness to start, and lost no time in embarking upon it. They did not even think of visiting the city, which, though of considerable size, was not worth a moment's delay. The train ran rapidly through the State of Iowa, passing successively by Council Bluffs, Des Moines, and Iowa City. It crossed the Mississippi at Davenport during the night, and entered Illinois by Rock Island. The next afternoon, the 10th of December, they reached Chicago, which, though still bearing traces of the great fire, was already rebuilt and presented a lively and prosperous appearance. Phileas Fogg, without stopping to admire the city, took the train of the Pittsburgh, Fort Wayne, and Chicago Railway, which was to carry him eastward. The train ran with extraordinary speed through Indiana, Ohio, and Pennsylvania, and passed rapidly through the principal towns of these States. The Hudson River was soon in view, and at a quarter past eleven in the evening of the 11th, the train arrived at the New York station, which stood on the very pier of the Cunard line. Phileas Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout alighted, and immediately inquired for the steamship "China," which had just left the dock forty-five minutes before.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The Pacific Railroad proper finds its terminus at this important Nebraska town. Phileas Fogg, accompanied by Passepartout, arrived at this point with the intention of continuing their journey by steamer to San Francisco. However, they were informed that the last steamer for California had already departed. This unexpected delay threatened to jeopardize Fogg's carefully calculated schedule, as he was determined to complete his journey around the world in eighty days. Undeterred, Fogg decided to proceed by the overland route, hiring a private express train to take them westward. The journey across the American plains was arduous, marked by the vast, unbroken expanse of the prairie and the challenges of the frontier. As they traveled, Passepartout marveled at the scenery, while Fogg remained as composed and punctual as ever. The journey was not without its dangers; they encountered a band of hostile Native Americans, who attempted to derail the train. However, the travelers were protected by a group of armed guards, and the threat was quickly dispelled. After several days of travel, they finally reached San Francisco, where Fogg was able to continue his journey by steamer to Japan. The incident in Nebraska had tested Fogg's resolve, but he remained steadfast in his determination to complete his journey on time. His calm and methodical approach, even in the face of unexpected obstacles, was a testament to his character. The events in Nebraska served as a reminder of the unpredictable nature of travel and the importance of adaptability. Fogg's ability to remain composed and find alternative solutions was crucial to the success of his journey. As they departed San Francisco, Fogg and Passepartout were one step closer to completing their remarkable adventure around the world.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXXII. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG ENGAGES IN A DIRECT STRUGGLE WITH BAD FORTUNE

events.title: Missed Steamer and Passepartout's Guilt
detailed_summary: The departure of the steamship "China" dashes Phileas Fogg's most apparent chance of crossing the Atlantic in time.
Consulting his "Bradshaw" guide confirms that alternative steamers from French, Hamburg, or Inman lines are unsuitable due to destinations or schedules, rendering Fogg's efforts potentially futile.
Passepartout feels utterly crushed, blaming himself for the missed connection and other obstacles he feels he placed in his master's path throughout their journey.
He reflects on the significant sums of money spent, partly due to his own errors, and the immense financial ruin Fogg faces if the wager is lost.
Despite Passepartout's self-reproach, Phileas Fogg remains calm, does not blame him, and suggests they postpone decision-making until the following day.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The “China,” in leaving, seemed to have carried off Phileas Fogg’s last hope.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Come.”

events.text_segment:
The “China,” in leaving, seemed to have carried off Phileas Fogg’s last hope. None of the other steamers were able to serve his projects. The “Pereire,” of the French Transatlantic Company, whose admirable steamers are equal to any in speed and comfort, did not leave until the 14th; the Hamburg boats did not go directly to Liverpool or London, but to Havre; and the additional trip from Havre to Southampton would render Phileas Fogg’s last efforts of no avail. The Inman steamer did not depart till the next day, and could not cross the Atlantic in time to save the wager.
Mr. Fogg learned all this in consulting his “Bradshaw,” which gave him the daily movements of the transatlantic steamers.
Passepartout was crushed; it overwhelmed him to lose the boat by three-quarters of an hour. It was his fault, for, instead of helping his master, he had not ceased putting obstacles in his path! And when he recalled all the incidents of the tour, when he counted up the sums expended in pure loss and on his own account, when he thought that the immense stake, added to the heavy charges of this useless journey, would completely ruin Mr. Fogg, he overwhelmed himself with bitter self-accusations. Mr. Fogg, however, did not reproach him; and, on leaving the Cunard pier, only said: “We will consult about what is best to-morrow. Come.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The “China,” in leaving, seemed to have carried off Phileas Fogg’s last hope. The steamer, which had been the only means of transport that could have brought him across the Atlantic in time, had just departed without him, and the opportunity was irretrievably lost. Passepartout, who had been watching the vessel disappear into the mist, turned to his master with a look of despair. “It’s all my fault, sir,” he said, his voice trembling. “I have been the cause of all these delays, all these mishaps. I have brought ruin upon you.” Phileas Fogg, however, remained as calm and composed as ever. He took a deep breath and looked at his companion with a steady gaze. “Do not blame yourself, Passepartout,” he said. “Fortune has played a cruel trick upon us, but we must not give up. There is still time, and I am not one to surrender to misfortune.” He then consulted his Bradshaw guide, searching for any possible alternative routes. The French, Hamburg, and Inman steamers were either bound for the wrong ports or left at inconvenient hours, none of which would allow them to make up the lost time. Passepartout, seeing the futility of their situation, felt his heart sink. He thought of the vast sums of money that had been spent, the many obstacles that had been placed in their path, and the ruin that would follow if the wager was lost. “What can we do, sir?” he asked, his voice barely above a whisper. “I do not know,” Phileas Fogg replied, “but we will find a way. We must. There is still one day left, and I will not give up until the last moment.”

I have brought ruin upon you.” Phileas Fogg, however, remained as calm and composed as ever. He took a deep breath and looked at his companion with a steady gaze. “Do not blame yourself, Passepartout,” he said. “Fortune has played a cruel trick upon us, but we must not give up. There is still time, and I am not one to surrender to misfortune.” He then consulted his Bradshaw guide, searching for any possible alternative routes. The French, Hamburg, and Inman steamers were either bound for the wrong ports or left at inconvenient hours, none of which would allow them to make up the lost time. Passepartout, seeing the futility of their situation, felt his heart sink. He thought of the vast sums of money that had been spent, the many obstacles that had been placed in their path, and the ruin that would follow if the wager was lost. “What can we do, sir?” he asked, his voice barely above a whisper. “I do not know,” Phileas Fogg replied, “but we will find a way. We must. There is still one day left, and I will not give up until the last moment.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The “China,” in leaving, seemed to have carried off Phileas Fogg’s last hope. He had lost the steamer, and with it the only means of reaching London in time to save himself from the penalty of his wager. Yet Phileas Fogg, ever the master of his emotions, did not betray the slightest sign of discouragement. He merely looked at Passepartout, who was in despair, and said, “Come, Passepartout, we must find another way.”

Phileas Fogg was a man of method and precision, and he was not one to be easily defeated. He had already made up his mind to continue his journey by land, and he was determined to reach London by any means necessary. He had no money left, but he had his reputation, and that was enough for him. He had always played the game of life with a cool and calculating mind, and he was not about to change now.

Passepartout, on the other hand, was a man of impulse and emotion. He was not used to thinking for himself, and he was now left to rely on the guidance of his master. He had no idea what to do, and he looked to Phileas Fogg for direction. He was a man of action, but without a plan, he was lost.

Phileas Fogg, however, was not a man to be lost. He had a plan, and he was going to see it through, no matter what the cost. He was going to make it to London, and he was going to win his wager, no matter what the odds were against him.

events.title: An Anxious Night and Calculated Odds
detailed_summary: The group travels by ferry from Jersey City across the Hudson River and takes a carriage to the St. Nicholas Hotel on Broadway.
They secure rooms for the night.
Phileas Fogg sleeps soundly, apparently unaffected by the setback.
In contrast, Aouda and the others (including Passepartout and likely Fix) are too agitated and worried to rest properly.
The narrative marks the date as December 12th and calculates the precise time remaining: nine days, thirteen hours, and forty-five minutes until the deadline at 8:45 PM on December 21st.
It explicitly states that catching the "China" would have allowed Fogg to reach Liverpool and London within the required timeframe.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If Phileas Fogg had left in the “China,” one of the fastest steamers on the Atlantic, he would have reached Liverpool, and then London, within the period agreed upon.

events.text_segment:
The party crossed the Hudson in the Jersey City ferryboat, and drove in a carriage to the St. Nicholas Hotel, on Broadway. Rooms were engaged, and the night passed, briefly to Phileas Fogg, who slept profoundly, but very long to Aouda and the others, whose agitation did not permit them to rest.
The next day was the 12th of December. From seven in the morning of the 12th to a quarter before nine in the evening of the 21st there were nine days, thirteen hours, and forty-five minutes. If Phileas Fogg had left in the “China,” one of the fastest steamers on the Atlantic, he would have reached Liverpool, and then London, within the period agreed upon.

He slept soundly, and was not disturbed by the least anxiety. Aouda, Passepartout, and Fix, on the contrary, were in a state of the greatest uneasiness. The loss of twenty-four hours was a serious matter. The time was now nine days, thirteen hours, and forty-five minutes. The "China" was the only steamer that could bring them to Liverpool in time. If they missed her, all was lost. The "China" was to sail at ten o'clock in the morning. It was now only a little past midnight. There was still time to reach her, but it was necessary to be on the alert. Passepartout, in his excitement, could not sleep, and walked the floor of his room. Aouda, too, was unable to rest, and Fix, who had no interest in the journey except to follow Phileas Fogg, was yet disturbed by the idea that the detective might be on the track of the robber. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The party crossed the Hudson in the Jersey City ferryboat, and drove in a carriage to the St. Nicholas Hotel, on Broadway. Phileas Fogg, Passepartout, and Aouda arrived just in time for the evening train to New York. Fogg was determined to keep to his schedule, and nothing would deter him. Passepartout, ever the loyal servant, followed his master's lead, while Aouda observed with quiet admiration. The journey continued, each step bringing them closer to their goal, and the clock ticking ever onward.

events.title: Fogg's Solo Search for Passage
detailed_summary: Fogg leaves the hotel by himself.
He instructs Passepartout to stay behind and ensure Aouda is prepared for a potentially sudden departure.
Fogg proceeds to the banks of the Hudson River.
He meticulously scans the numerous vessels moored or anchored, searching for one suitable for immediate departure.
He notes that while many ships are preparing to leave with the morning tide, demonstrating the port's busyness, most are sailing ships.
Fogg recognizes that sailing vessels lack the necessary speed and are therefore useless for his purpose.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Fogg left the hotel alone, after giving Passepartout instructions to await his return, and inform Aouda to be ready at an instant’s notice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But they were mostly sailing vessels, of which, of course, Phileas Fogg could make no use.

events.text_segment: Mr. Fogg left the hotel alone, after giving Passepartout instructions to await his return, and inform Aouda to be ready at an instant’s notice. He proceeded to the banks of the Hudson, and looked about among the vessels moored or anchored in the river, for any that were about to depart. Several had departure signals, and were preparing to put to sea at morning tide; for in this immense and admirable port there is not one day in a hundred that vessels do not set out for every quarter of the globe. But they were mostly sailing vessels, of which, of course, Phileas Fogg could make no use.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Mr. Fogg left the hotel alone, after giving Passepartout instructions to await his return, and inform Aouda to be ready at an instant’s notice. He was to be back before nightfall. Passepartout, who was not without some uneasiness at this sudden movement, was, however, too well accustomed to his master’s calm and methodical ways to question them. He remained, therefore, in the hotel, watching over Aouda, who was still in a state of great agitation, and endeavoring to soothe her by his usual good-humored talk. Phileas Fogg, on his part, proceeded directly to the banks of the Hudson River. He had no time to lose, and he knew that the only means of reaching England in the time he had allowed himself was by sea. He examined with the most minute attention the numerous vessels moored or anchored in the river, searching for one that might be ready to sail at once. The port was very busy; many ships were preparing to leave with the morning tide. But most of them were sailing vessels, and Fogg knew that these would be of no use to him. He needed speed, and only steam could give it. He was determined to find a steamer, and to start at once, if possible, for Liverpool. He had no doubt that he could do so, and he was not mistaken.

He walked swiftly through the bustling streets, his mind fixed on the race against time. Every minute counted as he made his way to the railway station, determined to keep his promise. The journey had been full of obstacles, but his resolve remained unshaken. He was confident that with careful planning and a bit of luck, they would complete their journey around the world in eighty days.

events.title: Spotting the "Henrietta"
detailed_summary: Just as his hopes seem to dwindle, Fogg observes a trading vessel anchored near the Battery.
The ship possesses a screw propeller and its smoking funnel indicates it is actively preparing to depart soon.
Acting quickly, Fogg hails a small boat.
He gets into the boat and is rowed out to the vessel.
He boards the ship, which is identified as the "Henrietta," noted for its iron hull and wooden upper structure.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He seemed about to give up all hope, when he espied, anchored at the Battery, a cable’s length off at most, a trading vessel, with a screw, well-shaped, whose funnel, puffing a cloud of smoke, indicated that she was getting ready for departure.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He ascended to the deck, and asked for the captain, who forthwith presented himself.

events.text_segment:
He seemed about to give up all hope, when he espied, anchored at the Battery, a cable’s length off at most, a trading vessel, with a screw, well-shaped, whose funnel, puffing a cloud of smoke, indicated that she was getting ready for departure.
Phileas Fogg hailed a boat, got into it, and soon found himself on board the “Henrietta,” iron-hulled, wood-built above. He ascended to the deck, and asked for the captain, who forthwith presented himself.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He seemed about to give up all hope, when he espied, anchored at the Battery, a cable’s length off at most, a trading vessel, with a screw, well-shaped, whose funnel, puffing a cloud of smoke, indicated that she was getting ready for departure. Phileas Fogg, without losing a moment, hailed a passing boat, and, springing into it, was rowed out to the vessel. He was soon on board, and ascertained that she was the Henrietta, an iron-hulled steamer with a wooden superstructure, belonging to the Inman Line, and bound for Liverpool. The Henrietta was a swift vessel, and Fogg, with the promptness that never forsook him, at once determined to take passage in her. He inquired of the captain the time at which she would sail, and was told that she would leave the wharf in an hour. Fogg then hastened to the nearest telegraph office, and sent a message to his servant, James, to meet him at the steamer.

events.title: Confronting Captain Speedy
detailed_summary: Fogg encounters the ship's captain, Andrew Speedy, described as a fifty-year-old, rugged "sea-wolf" type from Cardiff.
Speedy confirms he is the captain and the ship, the "Henrietta," is departing within the hour.
He states his destination is Bordeaux and clarifies he is sailing without freight ("in ballast").
Speedy explicitly states he never takes passengers, finding them inconvenient.
He confirms the vessel's speed capability is between eleven and twelve knots.
Fogg directly requests passage for himself and three others to Liverpool.
Captain Speedy bluntly refuses, reiterating his unchangeable destination is Bordeaux.
Speedy dismisses Fogg's inquiry about cost, indicating money is not a deciding factor.
The captain asserts his sole ownership of the vessel when Fogg attempts to appeal to potential owners.
He rejects Fogg's offers to freight or even buy the ship.
Fogg remains outwardly calm, but recognizes the gravity of the situation, as his usual reliance on money to overcome obstacles has failed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He was a man of fifty, a sort of sea-wolf, with big eyes, a complexion of oxidised copper, red hair and thick neck, and a growling voice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Now money failed.

events.text_segment:
He was a man of fifty, a sort of sea-wolf, with big eyes, a complexion of oxidised copper, red hair and thick neck, and a growling voice.
“The captain?” asked Mr. Fogg.
“I am the captain.”
“I am Phileas Fogg, of London.”
“And I am Andrew Speedy, of Cardiff.”
“You are going to put to sea?”
“In an hour.”
“You are bound for—”
“Bordeaux.”
“And your cargo?”
“No freight. Going in ballast.”
“Have you any passengers?”
“No passengers. Never have passengers. Too much in the way.”
“Is your vessel a swift one?”
“Between eleven and twelve knots. The “Henrietta,” well known.”
“Will you carry me and three other persons to Liverpool?”
“To Liverpool? Why not to China?”
“I said Liverpool.”
“No!”
“No?”
“No. I am setting out for Bordeaux, and shall go to Bordeaux.”
“Money is no object?”
“None.”
The captain spoke in a tone which did not admit of a reply.
“But the owners of the ‘Henrietta’—” resumed Phileas Fogg.
“The owners are myself,” replied the captain. “The vessel belongs to me.”
“I will freight it for you.”
“No.”
“I will buy it of you.”
“No.”
Phileas Fogg did not betray the least disappointment; but the situation was a grave one. It was not at New York as at Hong Kong, nor with the captain of the “Henrietta” as with the captain of the “Tankadere.” Up to this time money had smoothed away every obstacle. Now money failed.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He was a man of fifty, a sort of sea-wolf, with big eyes, a complexion of oxidised copper, red hair and thick neck, and a growling voice. He was dressed in a blue jersey, with a red sash, and his legs were encased in strong canvas trousers. He had the look of a man who had spent his life in the storm and the sea, and who had never known the softness of a drawing-room. Phileas Fogg, who had just entered the captain’s cabin, looked at him with a calm and inquisitive gaze. “You are Captain Andrew Speedy?” he asked. “I am,” replied the captain, in a voice like the growl of a dog. “And this is the Henrietta?” “It is,” said the captain. “And when does she sail?” “In an hour.” “And where is she bound?” “For Bordeaux.” “And is she carrying freight?” “No, she is in ballast.” “And does she take passengers?” “No, never. Passengers are a nuisance to me.” “And what is her speed?” “Between eleven and twelve knots.” “Then I should like to have passage on board for myself and three others, to Liverpool.” “You shall not have it,” said the captain, with a short laugh. “I am not going to Liverpool.” “But I will pay you well,” said Fogg. “I do not care for money,” replied the captain. “I am my own master, and I go where I please.” “And if I were to buy the Henrietta?” “You might do so,” said the captain, “but I should not take you on board.” “And if I were to freight her?” “You might do so,” said the captain, “but I should not take you on board.” Phileas Fogg remained silent for a moment. He was a man who had never known the taste of failure, and who had always found a way out of the most difficult situations. But now, for the first time, he felt the weight of an obstacle that money could not remove.

Passengers are a nuisance to me.” “And what is her speed?” “Between eleven and twelve knots.” “Then I should like to have passage on board for myself and three others, to Liverpool.” “You shall not have it,” said the captain, with a short laugh. “I am not going to Liverpool.” “But I will pay you well,” said Fogg. “I do not care for money,” replied the captain. “I am my own master, and I go where I please.” “And if I were to buy the Henrietta?” “You might do so,” said the captain, “but I should not take you on board.” “And if I were to freight her?” “You might do so,” said the captain, “but I should not take you on board.” Phileas Fogg remained silent for a moment. He was a man who had never known the taste of failure, and who had always found a way out of the most difficult situations. But now, for the first time, he felt the weight of an obstacle that money could not remove.

events.title: A Change of Tactics: Securing Passage to Bordeaux
detailed_summary: Fogg considers the necessity of finding some boat transport across the Atlantic, briefly dismissing the impracticality of balloon travel.
He devises a new strategy and asks Captain Speedy if he would take the party to his intended destination, Bordeaux.
Speedy initially scoffs, saying he wouldn't even for two hundred dollars.
Fogg then makes a substantial offer of two thousand dollars per passenger.
Upon realizing this amounts to eight thousand dollars for the four passengers, Captain Speedy hesitates, scratching his head.
The significant financial incentive overrides his aversion to passengers, whom he now mentally categorizes as valuable cargo rather than nuisances.
Speedy curtly agrees to take them to Bordeaux, confirming the departure time is nine o'clock.
Fogg simply states that he and his party will be on board by then.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Still, some means must be found to cross the Atlantic on a boat, unless by balloon—which would have been venturesome, besides not being capable of being put in practice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “We will be on board at nine o’clock,” replied, no less simply, Mr. Fogg.

events.text_segment:
Still, some means must be found to cross the Atlantic on a boat, unless by balloon—which would have been venturesome, besides not being capable of being put in practice. It seemed that Phileas Fogg had an idea, for he said to the captain, “Well, will you carry me to Bordeaux?”
“No, not if you paid me two hundred dollars.”
“I offer you two thousand.”
“Apiece?”
“Apiece.”
“And there are four of you?”
“Four.”
Captain Speedy began to scratch his head. There were eight thousand dollars to gain, without changing his route; for which it was well worth conquering the repugnance he had for all kinds of passengers. Besides, passengers at two thousand dollars are no longer passengers, but valuable merchandise. “I start at nine o’clock,” said Captain Speedy, simply. “Are you and your party ready?”
“We will be on board at nine o’clock,” replied, no less simply, Mr. Fogg.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Still, some means must be found to cross the Atlantic on a boat, unless by balloon—which would have been venturesome, besides not being capable of being put in practice. Phileas Fogg, therefore, resolved to make inquiries at the shipping offices. He went to the Custom House, and there, after some research, he found that the steamer which had brought him from Liverpool had just arrived at New York, and was about to return to Liverpool. This was the *Columbus*, Captain Andrew Speedy. Mr. Fogg at once sought out the captain, and, after a few preliminary words, asked him if he would take him and his companions to Liverpool. 'Take you to Liverpool!' said Captain Speedy, with a laugh. 'Do you think I run a hotel?' 'No, Captain,' replied Phileas Fogg, 'but I offer you two thousand dollars for each passenger.' 'Two thousand dollars!' repeated the captain, his eyes opening wide. 'That would make eight thousand dollars for four passengers.' 'Exactly,' said Phileas Fogg. The captain scratched his head. 'Well, I never!' he muttered. 'I don't know what to say. I don't mind the money, but I do mind the passengers.' 'You will find them very quiet,' said Phileas Fogg. 'They will not require much attention.' 'Well,' said the captain, 'I'll take you, if you can be on board by nine o'clock to-morrow morning.' 'We shall be on board by that time,' said Phileas Fogg, and he left the captain to his meditations.

events.title: Swift Return and Departure on the "Henrietta"
detailed_summary: It is now half-past eight, leaving only thirty minutes before the scheduled departure.
Fogg executes his plan with remarkable speed and characteristic coolness.
He disembarks the "Henrietta," hails a carriage, speeds back to the St. Nicholas Hotel.
He efficiently gathers Aouda, Passepartout, and the ever-present Fix.
Fogg successfully returns with the entire party to the "Henrietta" just as the ship is preparing to weigh anchor.
Upon learning the cost of this unexpected voyage segment, Passepartout lets out a long, expressive sound of shock.

Fix internally muses that the Bank of England is unlikely to fare well financially in this affair, estimating that Fogg's expenditures will have already surpassed seven thousand pounds by the time they reach England.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was half-past eight.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When they reached England, even if Mr. Fogg did not throw some handfuls of bank-bills into the sea, more than seven thousand pounds would have been spent!

events.text_segment:
It was half-past eight. To disembark from the “Henrietta,” jump into a hack, hurry to the St. Nicholas, and return with Aouda, Passepartout, and even the inseparable Fix was the work of a brief time, and was performed by Mr. Fogg with the coolness which never abandoned him. They were on board when the “Henrietta” made ready to weigh anchor.
When Passepartout heard what this last voyage was going to cost, he uttered a prolonged “Oh!” which extended throughout his vocal gamut.
As for Fix, he said to himself that the Bank of England would certainly not come out of this affair well indemnified. When they reached England, even if Mr. Fogg did not throw some handfuls of bank-bills into the sea, more than seven thousand pounds would have been spent!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It was half-past eight. The *Henrietta* was to sail at nine. There remained thirty minutes, and Phileas Fogg, with the coolness of a man who has never known the pressure of time, set about accomplishing the impossible. He disembarked, and, without a word, hailed a carriage. The vehicle, urged on by a furious trot, bore him back to the St. Nicholas Hotel. He entered, and in a few moments reappeared with Aouda, Passepartout, and Fix. The latter, who had followed him, was not sorry to be once more in his company, and to have the opportunity of watching the course of events. The carriage, still urged on by the same furious trot, reached the dock just as the *Henrietta* was preparing to weigh anchor. The pilot was on the bridge, the steam was up, and the vessel was about to start. Fogg, with his usual precision, landed on board, and the cable was cast off. Passepartout, when he learned the price of this last portion of the journey, uttered a long, expressive sound, which might have been taken for a sigh, a groan, or a song. Fix, on his side, reflected that the Bank of England would not come out of this affair very well, and that Phileas Fogg's expenses must already have exceeded seven thousand pounds.

Phileas Fogg, with his usual composure, checked his pocket watch and adjusted his waistcoat. He was determined to complete his journey around the world in eighty days, and every moment counted. Passepartout, his loyal valet, was already preparing the luggage for their next leg of the trip. The city bustled with life as they made their way to the train station, the rhythmic sound of hooves and carriage wheels echoing through the streets. Fogg's calm demeanor contrasted with the hurried pace of the city, yet he moved with purpose, undeterred by the challenges ahead. The journey had only just begun, but Fogg was confident that time was on his side.

events.title: Fogg Takes Command of the Henrietta
detailed_summary: The Henrietta departs New York City, heading east.
Phileas Fogg is revealed to be commanding the ship from the bridge, not Captain Speedy.
Captain Speedy is confined to his cabin, vocally expressing his fury.
Fogg, initially denied passage to Liverpool by Speedy, had booked for Bordeaux.
During the first thirty hours, Fogg used his money to persuade the temporary crew, who disliked Speedy, to mutiny and follow his orders.
Fogg now directs the ship towards Liverpool, demonstrating considerable seamanship.
Aouda feels apprehensive but remains silent.
Passepartout considers Fogg's takeover a brilliant move.
The ship maintains a speed of eleven to twelve knots as predicted by the former captain.
Potential obstacles like rough seas, adverse winds, or mechanical failures still pose risks to completing the voyage in the required nine days (by December 21st).
The narrator notes that Fogg's actions regarding the ship, combined with the bank robbery suspicion, could lead to future complications.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: An hour after, the “Henrietta” passed the lighthouse which marks the entrance of the Hudson, turned the point of Sandy Hook, and put to sea.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It is true that, once arrived, the affair on board the “Henrietta,” added to that of the Bank of England, might create more difficulties for Mr. Fogg than he imagined or could desire.

events.text_segment:
An hour after, the “Henrietta” passed the lighthouse which marks the entrance of the Hudson, turned the point of Sandy Hook, and put to sea. During the day she skirted Long Island, passed Fire Island, and directed her course rapidly eastward.
At noon the next day, a man mounted the bridge to ascertain the vessel’s position. It might be thought that this was Captain Speedy. Not the least in the world. It was Phileas Fogg, Esquire. As for Captain Speedy, he was shut up in his cabin under lock and key, and was uttering loud cries, which signified an anger at once pardonable and excessive.
What had happened was very simple. Phileas Fogg wished to go to Liverpool, but the captain would not carry him there. Then Phileas Fogg had taken passage for Bordeaux, and, during the thirty hours he had been on board, had so shrewdly managed with his banknotes that the sailors and stokers, who were only an occasional crew, and were not on the best terms with the captain, went over to him in a body. This was why Phileas Fogg was in command instead of Captain Speedy; why the captain was a prisoner in his cabin; and why, in short, the “Henrietta” was directing her course towards Liverpool. It was very clear, to see Mr. Fogg manage the craft, that he had been a sailor.
How the adventure ended will be seen anon. Aouda was anxious, though she said nothing. As for Passepartout, he thought Mr. Fogg’s manœuvre simply glorious. The captain had said “between eleven and twelve knots,” and the “Henrietta” confirmed his prediction.
If, then—for there were “ifs” still—the sea did not become too boisterous, if the wind did not veer round to the east, if no accident happened to the boat or its machinery, the “Henrietta” might cross the three thousand miles from New York to Liverpool in the nine days, between the 12th and the 21st of December. It is true that, once arrived, the affair on board the “Henrietta,” added to that of the Bank of England, might create more difficulties for Mr. Fogg than he imagined or could desire.

**Chapter Title:** *CHAPTER XXXIII. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG SHOWS HIMSELF EQUAL TO THE OCCASION*

An hour after, the “Henrietta” passed the lighthouse which marks the entrance of the Hudson, turned the point of Sandy Hook, and put to sea. The ship, a sturdy steam yacht, cut through the Atlantic with a confidence that belied the tension brewing beneath its polished decks.

Phileas Fogg stood at the helm, his expression as calm and unyielding as the sea itself. The bridge, once the domain of Captain Speedy, now belonged to the enigmatic Englishman. Speedy, confined to his cabin, raged against the betrayal, his voice muffled by the thick oak doors and the roar of the engines. The crew, many of whom had long resented the captain’s brusque manner, had quietly shifted their allegiance to Fogg, swayed by his quiet authority and the generous sums he had discreetly distributed.

Fogg had not merely taken control—he had done so with precision. He had booked the ship for Bordeaux, but now, with the captain sidelined and the crew in his pocket, he steered it toward Liverpool. Aouda, seated quietly in the saloon, watched the proceedings with a mixture of admiration and unease. She had seen Fogg’s resolve before, but never had it manifested so boldly, so unapologetically.

Passepartout, ever the loyal servant, beamed with pride. “He’s a man of action, our Mr. Fogg,” he muttered to a passing sailor, who nodded in agreement. The Henrietta, under Fogg’s command, maintained a steady speed of eleven to twelve knots, a testament to the former captain’s calculations and the new captain’s skill.

Yet, the journey was far from certain. The Atlantic was a fickle mistress, and the days ahead would test Fogg’s mettle. Storms, mechanical failures, or even the sudden appearance of a rival vessel could delay their arrival. And if the bank robbery charge ever caught up with him, Fogg’s bold maneuvering might prove to be a double-edged sword.

But for now, the sea was his ally, and the clock was his only adversary.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: An hour after, the “Henrietta” passed the lighthouse which marks the entrance of the Hudson, turned the point of Sandy Hook, and put to sea. The wind was fair, the sails were set, and the vessel, under the command of Captain Speedy, made good progress down the coast. Phileas Fogg, Passepartout, and Aouda stood on the deck, watching the receding shores of New York with calm interest. The young Frenchman, full of curiosity and admiration for the vastness of the journey before them, could hardly contain his excitement. Aouda, more reserved, observed the scene with a quiet dignity, while Mr. Fogg, as usual, remained composed and unemotional, his mind fixed on the punctual execution of the journey. The “Henrietta” was a swift and reliable steamer, and Captain Speedy, a man of experience and precision, was well aware of the importance of time. He had been informed of the urgency of the journey and had promised to make all possible haste. The passengers were soon settled in their cabins, and the monotony of the sea began to set in. Passepartout, however, was not one to be easily bored. He spent his time exploring the ship, conversing with the crew, and generally making himself agreeable. Aouda, on the other hand, preferred the solitude of her cabin, where she could reflect on the strange and unexpected turn her life had taken. Mr. Fogg, true to his nature, kept to himself, reading his book or watching the horizon with a steady gaze. The days passed in this manner, with the “Henrietta” steadily making her way southward. The weather was fine, the sea calm, and the journey seemed to be proceeding without a hitch. It was as if the universe itself were conspiring to aid Mr. Fogg in his remarkable undertaking. Yet, as all who have read of his adventures know, the greatest journeys are never without their trials, and the road around the world was only just beginning.

events.title: Smooth Sailing and Character Reactions
detailed_summary: The initial part of the voyage proceeds without major issues.
The sea conditions are favorable, the wind holds steady from the north-east, and the ship makes good progress under sail and steam.
Passepartout is overjoyed by his master's bold actions, oblivious to potential negative outcomes.
He becomes very popular with the crew, impressing them with his agility and positive attitude, praising their seamanship and the stokers' efforts.
His cheerful demeanor spreads throughout the ship.
He puts past troubles behind him, focusing solely on the imminent successful conclusion of the journey, occasionally becoming very impatient.
He frequently observes Fix with suspicion but avoids interaction due to their broken relationship.
Fix is utterly bewildered by Fogg's actions – commandeering a ship, bribing a crew, and expertly sailing it.
He speculates that Fogg, having stolen money, might now be acting as a pirate, planning to sail the Henrietta to a safe haven rather than Liverpool.
The detective regrets becoming involved in the pursuit.
Captain Speedy remains locked away, loudly protesting.
Passepartout delivers Speedy's meals cautiously.
Fogg appears completely indifferent to the presence of the imprisoned captain.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: During the first days, they went along smoothly enough.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fogg did not seem even to know that there was a captain on board.

events.text_segment:
During the first days, they went along smoothly enough. The sea was not very unpropitious, the wind seemed stationary in the north-east, the sails were hoisted, and the “Henrietta” ploughed across the waves like a real transatlantic steamer.
Passepartout was delighted. His master’s last exploit, the consequences of which he ignored, enchanted him. Never had the crew seen so jolly and dexterous a fellow. He formed warm friendships with the sailors, and amazed them with his acrobatic feats. He thought they managed the vessel like gentlemen, and that the stokers fired up like heroes. His loquacious good-humour infected everyone. He had forgotten the past, its vexations and delays. He only thought of the end, so nearly accomplished; and sometimes he boiled over with impatience, as if heated by the furnaces of the “Henrietta.” Often, also, the worthy fellow revolved around Fix, looking at him with a keen, distrustful eye; but he did not speak to him, for their old intimacy no longer existed.
Fix, it must be confessed, understood nothing of what was going on. The conquest of the “Henrietta,” the bribery of the crew, Fogg managing the boat like a skilled seaman, amazed and confused him. He did not know what to think. For, after all, a man who began by stealing fifty-five thousand pounds might end by stealing a vessel; and Fix was not unnaturally inclined to conclude that the “Henrietta” under Fogg’s command, was not going to Liverpool at all, but to some part of the world where the robber, turned into a pirate, would quietly put himself in safety. The conjecture was at least a plausible one, and the detective began to seriously regret that he had embarked on the affair.
As for Captain Speedy, he continued to howl and growl in his cabin; and Passepartout, whose duty it was to carry him his meals, courageous as he was, took the greatest precautions. Mr. Fogg did not seem even to know that there was a captain on board.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: During the first days, they went along smoothly enough. The sea was calm, the wind held steadily from the north-east, and the Henrietta made good progress under both sail and steam. Passepartout was in ecstasies at the boldness of his master's conduct, and was quite unconscious of the dangers that might result from it. He was a favorite with the crew, who were delighted with his good-humor and his ready appreciation of their seamanship and the stokers' exertions. His joyousness communicated itself to all on board, and the Henrietta seemed to be animated by a new spirit. He had entirely forgotten the past, and thought only of the approaching success of the journey, which sometimes made him impatient. He watched Fix with a suspicious eye, but avoided him, for the relations between them were broken. Fix, for his part, was quite at a loss to understand Phileas Fogg. He could not account for the manner in which he had taken possession of the vessel, bribed the crew, and conducted the ship with such skill. He began to suspect that Fogg, having stolen the money, was now playing the part of a pirate, and intended to carry the Henrietta to some distant port, where he might elude pursuit. The detective regretted more than ever having become involved in this affair. Captain Speedy, meanwhile, was confined in his cabin, where he raged and protested in a voice that could be heard through the panels. Passepartout, who brought him his meals, did so with a respectful caution, as if he feared the captain might spring upon him. Phileas Fogg, for his part, seemed perfectly indifferent to the presence of the imprisoned man, and gave no sign of concern.

Passepartout was in ecstasies at the boldness of his master's conduct, and was quite unconscious of the dangers that might result from it. He was a favorite with the crew, who were delighted with his good-humor and his ready appreciation of their seamanship and the stokers' exertions. His joyousness communicated itself to all on board, and the Henrietta seemed to be animated by a new spirit. He had entirely forgotten the past, and thought only of the approaching success of the journey, which sometimes made him impatient. He watched Fix with a suspicious eye, but avoided him, for the relations between them were broken. Fix, for his part, was quite at a loss to understand Phileas Fogg. He could not account for the manner in which he had taken possession of the vessel, bribed the crew, and conducted the ship with such skill. He began to suspect that Fogg, having stolen the money, was now playing the part of a pirate, and intended to carry the Henrietta to some distant port, where he might elude pursuit. The detective regretted more than ever having become involved in this affair. Captain Speedy, meanwhile, was confined in his cabin, where he raged and protested in a voice that could be heard through the panels. Passepartout, who brought him his meals, did so with a respectful caution, as if he feared the captain might spring upon him. Phileas Fogg, for his part, seemed perfectly indifferent to the presence of the imprisoned man, and gave no sign of concern.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: During the first days, they went along smoothly enough. Passepartout, ever the optimist, took great delight in managing the train tickets and ensuring that everything was in order. Phileas Fogg, as always, remained calm and composed, never showing any sign of concern, even when the train was delayed or when they had to change locomotives. The journey began in London, and from there they traveled to Paris, where they arrived on time and with no complications. Passepartout, however, was not so lucky when he mistakenly boarded a different train, only to be quickly corrected by a fellow passenger who recognized the famous detective, Fix, watching them closely. Fix had been assigned to investigate the supposed bank robbery, and he was convinced that Fogg was the culprit. He followed them from station to station, always keeping a careful distance, but never letting them out of his sight. The two travelers, unaware of the detective's suspicions, continued their journey with confidence. From Paris, they took a train to Brindisi, and from there they boarded a steamer bound for Suez. The sea voyage was uneventful, and they arrived in Suez without any problems. From Suez, they traveled by train to Bombay, and then to Calcutta, where they encountered their first real difficulty. A monsoon had delayed the steamer that was to take them to Hong Kong, and they were forced to wait for several days. Passepartout, always eager for adventure, took the opportunity to explore the city, while Fogg remained in their hotel, reading the newspaper and keeping track of the time. The delay was a serious problem, as it threatened to throw off their entire schedule. However, Fogg, ever the strategist, quickly found a solution. He arranged for a private steamer to take them to Hong Kong, and they set sail immediately. The journey was long and arduous, but they arrived safely, and with only a few hours to spare before their next train. The race around the world was far from over, but so far, they had managed to stay on course.

events.title: Storm Hits the Atlantic Crossing
detailed_summary: The ship reaches the hazardous Banks of Newfoundland.
Weather conditions deteriorate, foreshadowed by a falling barometer the previous evening.
The temperature drops, and the wind shifts to the south-east.
This shift is problematic, forcing Fogg to furl the sails to stay on course and rely solely on steam.
The ship's speed diminishes due to rough seas with large waves breaking over the stern.
The vessel pitches violently, hindering its progress.
The wind intensifies into a storm, raising concerns about the ship's stability.
Passepartout's mood darkens, and he endures two days of intense fear.
Phileas Fogg, however, proves himself a courageous and skilled mariner, maintaining course and steam power.
The Henrietta often cuts through waves rather than riding over them, frequently washing the deck but remaining intact.
Sometimes the propeller lifts out of the water when the stern is raised by large waves, but the ship maintains its heading.
The storm doesn't reach hurricane intensity but persists.
Crucially, the wind remains fixed in the south-east, making the sails unusable for assisting their eastward journey.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On the 13th they passed the edge of the Banks of Newfoundland, a dangerous locality; during the winter, especially, there are frequent fogs and heavy gales of wind.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It continued fresh, but, unhappily, it remained obstinately in the south-east, rendering the sails useless.

events.text_segment:
On the 13th they passed the edge of the Banks of Newfoundland, a dangerous locality; during the winter, especially, there are frequent fogs and heavy gales of wind. Ever since the evening before the barometer, suddenly falling, had indicated an approaching change in the atmosphere; and during the night the temperature varied, the cold became sharper, and the wind veered to the south-east.
This was a misfortune. Mr. Fogg, in order not to deviate from his course, furled his sails and increased the force of the steam; but the vessel’s speed slackened, owing to the state of the sea, the long waves of which broke against the stern. She pitched violently, and this retarded her progress. The breeze little by little swelled into a tempest, and it was to be feared that the “Henrietta” might not be able to maintain herself upright on the waves.
Passepartout’s visage darkened with the skies, and for two days the poor fellow experienced constant fright. But Phileas Fogg was a bold mariner, and knew how to maintain headway against the sea; and he kept on his course, without even decreasing his steam. The “Henrietta,” when she could not rise upon the waves, crossed them, swamping her deck, but passing safely. Sometimes the screw rose out of the water, beating its protruding end, when a mountain of water raised the stern above the waves; but the craft always kept straight ahead.
The wind, however, did not grow as boisterous as might have been feared; it was not one of those tempests which burst, and rush on with a speed of ninety miles an hour. It continued fresh, but, unhappily, it remained obstinately in the south-east, rendering the sails useless.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: On the 13th they passed the edge of the Banks of Newfoundland, a dangerous locality; during the winter, especially, there are frequent fogs and heavy gales of wind. The barometer had fallen the evening before, and the wind had already begun to shift to the south-east, a change which was not favorable to their course. The temperature had perceptibly dropped, and the sea, which had been so tranquil, now began to swell. The Henrietta, as she advanced, encountered the first heavy waves, which broke over her stern, and she pitched violently, as if she were already in the grip of the storm. The wind increased in violence, and the sky, which had been overcast, became black with clouds. Passepartout, who had hitherto been cheerful and confident, now looked anxious and uneasy. He watched the horizon with a troubled eye, and his face wore an expression of deep uneasiness. Two days of this continued tempest passed, during which the Henrietta was constantly lashed by the waves, and her progress was greatly impeded. Phileas Fogg, however, showed himself equal to the occasion. He remained calm and composed, and gave his orders with the precision of a man who knew exactly what he was about. The sails were furled, and the ship was kept under steam alone. The Henrietta, though frequently submerged by the waves, kept her course with remarkable steadiness. She often cut through the waves rather than riding over them, and the deck was constantly washed by the sea. Sometimes the propeller lifted out of the water when the stern was raised by the force of the waves, but the ship maintained her heading. The storm did not reach the intensity of a hurricane, but it was sufficiently violent to make the Henrietta's progress slow and difficult. The wind, however, remained fixed in the south-east, and the sails could not be used to assist their course. Phileas Fogg, with his usual coolness, kept the ship under steam, and trusted to the power of the engine to carry them through the gale. Passepartout, for his part, could do nothing but wait and hope, and he did so with a heart full of anxiety.

events.title: Coal Shortage Crisis Emerges
detailed_summary: By December 16th, day 75, the voyage is roughly half complete without major delays, despite passing difficult areas.
Success seems likely in summer, but the winter season makes the outcome uncertain.
Passepartout remains hopeful, relying on the steam engines if the wind fails.
The ship's engineer approaches Fogg for a serious discussion.
Passepartout feels a sense of foreboding and strains to overhear their conversation.
He catches Fogg asking the engineer for confirmation of his statement.
The engineer confirms that while they had enough coal for a low-steam trip to Bordeaux, the constant high-steam usage means they lack sufficient coal to reach Liverpool.
Fogg calmly states he will consider the situation.
Passepartout grasps the critical nature of the problem: they are running out of coal.
He mutters that if Fogg can overcome this, he'll truly be remarkable.
He feels compelled to share the news with Fix.
Fix sarcastically asks if Passepartout still believes they are heading to Liverpool.
Passepartout affirms this, to which Fix replies dismissively, calling him an 'Ass'.
Passepartout is initially angered but stops himself, reasoning that Fix is likely bitter and embarrassed by his fruitless pursuit.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The 16th of December was the seventy-fifth day since Phileas Fogg’s departure from London, and the “Henrietta” had not yet been seriously delayed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout was on the point of vigorously resenting the epithet, the reason of which he could not for the life of him comprehend; but he reflected that the unfortunate Fix was probably very much disappointed and humiliated in his self-esteem, after having so awkwardly followed a false scent around the world, and refrained.

events.text_segment:
The 16th of December was the seventy-fifth day since Phileas Fogg’s departure from London, and the “Henrietta” had not yet been seriously delayed. Half of the voyage was almost accomplished, and the worst localities had been passed. In summer, success would have been well-nigh certain. In winter, they were at the mercy of the bad season. Passepartout said nothing; but he cherished hope in secret, and comforted himself with the reflection that, if the wind failed them, they might still count on the steam.
On this day the engineer came on deck, went up to Mr. Fogg, and began to speak earnestly with him. Without knowing why it was a presentiment, perhaps Passepartout became vaguely uneasy. He would have given one of his ears to hear with the other what the engineer was saying. He finally managed to catch a few words, and was sure he heard his master say, “You are certain of what you tell me?”
“Certain, sir,” replied the engineer. “You must remember that, since we started, we have kept up hot fires in all our furnaces, and, though we had coal enough to go on short steam from New York to Bordeaux, we haven’t enough to go with all steam from New York to Liverpool.” “I will consider,” replied Mr. Fogg.
Passepartout understood it all; he was seized with mortal anxiety. The coal was giving out! “Ah, if my master can get over that,” muttered he, “he’ll be a famous man!” He could not help imparting to Fix what he had overheard.
“Then you believe that we really are going to Liverpool?”
“Of course.”
“Ass!” replied the detective, shrugging his shoulders and turning on his heel.
Passepartout was on the point of vigorously resenting the epithet, the reason of which he could not for the life of him comprehend; but he reflected that the unfortunate Fix was probably very much disappointed and humiliated in his self-esteem, after having so awkwardly followed a false scent around the world, and refrained.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The 16th of December was the seventy-fifth day since Phileas Fogg’s departure from London, and the “Henrietta” had not yet been seriously delayed. The voyage was about half completed, and, in the summer season, would have been already finished. But the winter season had set in, and the question of the time to be gained or lost was still an open one. Passepartout, however, was not disheartened. He had full confidence in the steam engines, and, if the wind failed, in the power of the boilers. He was convinced that the “Henrietta” would reach Liverpool in due time, and that his master would accomplish his journey in the prescribed period. But the engineer, who had just come from the hold, was not so sanguine. He had sought Phileas Fogg in his cabin, and the two men were engaged in a serious conversation. Passepartout, who was in the adjoining room, felt a presentiment of some evil, and strained his ears to catch the words. He heard Fogg say, in a calm voice, “You are sure of this?” The engineer replied, “Yes, sir. We have not sufficient coal to reach Liverpool, if we keep on the speed we have maintained.” “And if we reduce the speed?” asked Fogg. “We might reach Bordeaux,” said the engineer, “but not Liverpool.” Phileas Fogg remained silent for a moment, and then said, “I will consider the matter.” Passepartout, who had overheard this conversation, felt a chill run through him. He now understood the gravity of the situation. They were running short of coal, and the “Henrietta” could not keep up the speed necessary to arrive at Liverpool in time. He muttered to himself, “If he can get us there, he is a man indeed!” He then resolved to go and speak to Fix, and to tell him the truth. Fix, who was in the saloon, received him with a sneer. “Well, Passepartout,” he said, “do you still believe that we are going to Liverpool?” “Yes, sir,” replied Passepartout. “You are an ass,” said Fix. Passepartout was about to resent this, but checked himself. He saw that Fix was in a bad humor, and that his anger was only the result of his own mortification at finding himself so completely outwitted.

events.title: Fogg's Audacious Purchase of the Henrietta
detailed_summary: Fogg appears to have decided on a course of action regarding the coal shortage.
That evening, he instructs the engineer to burn coal at maximum rate until it is completely depleted.
Shortly after, the ship's funnel emits massive amounts of smoke as it proceeds under full steam.
On the 18th, the engineer confirms the coal will run out later that day.
Fogg orders the fires kept high and valves filled until the very last moment.
Around noon, after checking their position, Fogg instructs Passepartout to fetch Captain Speedy.
Passepartout reluctantly obeys, anticipating an explosive reaction from the captain.
Captain Speedy bursts onto the deck, furious and demanding their location.
Fogg calmly informs him they are 770 miles from Liverpool.
Speedy calls Fogg a pirate.
Fogg ignores the insult and proposes to buy the ship from Speedy.
Speedy vehemently refuses.
Fogg states he will be forced to burn the ship (the wooden parts) because the coal has run out.
Speedy is aghast at the idea of burning his $50,000 vessel.
Fogg offers $60,000 in cash.
The sight of the money instantly changes Speedy's demeanor, overriding his anger and imprisonment.
He considers the 20-year-old ship and the generous offer.
Speedy notes he will retain the valuable iron hull and engine.
They agree on the sale.
Speedy takes the banknotes, counts them, and pockets the money.
During this exchange, Passepartout is pale with shock, and Fix appears stunned.
The narrator notes the immense expense (£20,000) and that Fogg essentially gave away the most valuable parts of the ship, though £55,000 was stolen from the bank.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And now what course would Phileas Fogg adopt?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When Andrew Speedy had pocketed the money, Mr. Fogg said to him, “Don’t let this astonish you, sir.

events.text_segment:
And now what course would Phileas Fogg adopt? It was difficult to imagine. Nevertheless he seemed to have decided upon one, for that evening he sent for the engineer, and said to him, “Feed all the fires until the coal is exhausted.”
A few moments after, the funnel of the “Henrietta” vomited forth torrents of smoke. The vessel continued to proceed with all steam on; but on the 18th, the engineer, as he had predicted, announced that the coal would give out in the course of the day.
“Do not let the fires go down,” replied Mr. Fogg. “Keep them up to the last. Let the valves be filled.”
Towards noon Phileas Fogg, having ascertained their position, called Passepartout, and ordered him to go for Captain Speedy. It was as if the honest fellow had been commanded to unchain a tiger. He went to the poop, saying to himself, “He will be like a madman!”
In a few moments, with cries and oaths, a bomb appeared on the poop-deck. The bomb was Captain Speedy. It was clear that he was on the point of bursting. “Where are we?” were the first words his anger permitted him to utter. Had the poor man been an apoplectic, he could never have recovered from his paroxysm of wrath.
“Where are we?” he repeated, with purple face.
“Seven hundred and seven miles from Liverpool,” replied Mr. Fogg, with imperturbable calmness.
“Pirate!” cried Captain Speedy.
“I have sent for you, sir—”
“Pickaroon!”
“—sir,” continued Mr. Fogg, “to ask you to sell me your vessel.”
“No! By all the devils, no!”
“But I shall be obliged to burn her.”
“Burn the ‘Henrietta’!”
“Yes; at least the upper part of her. The coal has given out.”
“Burn my vessel!” cried Captain Speedy, who could scarcely pronounce the words. “A vessel worth fifty thousand dollars!”
“Here are sixty thousand,” replied Phileas Fogg, handing the captain a roll of bank-bills. This had a prodigious effect on Andrew Speedy. An American can scarcely remain unmoved at the sight of sixty thousand dollars. The captain forgot in an instant his anger, his imprisonment, and all his grudges against his passenger. The “Henrietta” was twenty years old; it was a great bargain. The bomb would not go off after all. Mr. Fogg had taken away the match.
“And I shall still have the iron hull,” said the captain in a softer tone.
“The iron hull and the engine. Is it agreed?”
“Agreed.”
And Andrew Speedy, seizing the banknotes, counted them and consigned them to his pocket.
During this colloquy, Passepartout was as white as a sheet, and Fix seemed on the point of having an apoplectic fit. Nearly twenty thousand pounds had been expended, and Fogg left the hull and engine to the captain, that is, near the whole value of the craft! It was true, however, that fifty-five thousand pounds had been stolen from the Bank.
When Andrew Speedy had pocketed the money, Mr. Fogg said to him, “Don’t let this astonish you, sir.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: And now what course would Phileas Fogg adopt? The situation was serious. The coal was nearly exhausted, and the steamer could not reach Liverpool with her present supply. The question was, what was to be done? Phileas Fogg, however, appeared to have made up his mind. That evening he gave the engineer orders to burn the coal at the highest rate, and to keep the fires at their maximum intensity until the last lump was consumed. The steamer, accordingly, proceeded under full steam, and the funnel poured out volumes of smoke, as if determined to make up for lost time. On the 18th, the engineer came to Fogg and informed him that the coal would be entirely exhausted that day. Fogg merely replied, “Very well,” and gave orders to keep the fires high and the valves full until the last moment. At noon, after having ascertained their position, Fogg called Passepartout and said to him, “Go and fetch Captain Speedy.” Passepartout obeyed with some hesitation, for he anticipated a scene. Captain Speedy, when summoned, came on deck in a state of violent excitement. “Where are we?” he demanded. “How far are we from Liverpool?” Fogg calmly replied, “We are 770 miles from Liverpool.” “You are a pirate!” exclaimed the captain. “I am not a pirate,” said Fogg, “but I am a gentleman, and I propose to buy your vessel.” “Buy my vessel!” cried Speedy, in astonishment. “You are mad!” “No,” said Fogg, “I am in earnest. I will give you sixty thousand dollars in cash for the steamer.” “You are mad!” repeated the captain. “You would not think of burning your own vessel?” “I should be forced to do so,” replied Fogg, “for the coal is exhausted, and I must reach Liverpool at all hazards.” “You would burn my vessel?” “I would burn it, if necessary, to make the journey.” “But it is worth fifty thousand dollars!” “I will give you sixty thousand,” said Fogg. The captain, struck with the magnitude of the offer, hesitated. The idea of burning his vessel, which had cost him so much, was too painful. But the sight of the banknotes, which Fogg produced and laid on the table, had a magical effect. The captain’s anger vanished, and he began to calculate. “The vessel is twenty years old,” he said, “and the iron hull and engine are still valuable. I will sell.” The bargain was made. Speedy took the banknotes, counted them, and put them in his pocket. Passepartout, pale with astonishment, and Fix, who looked as if he could not believe his eyes, stood by in silence. The narrator cannot help remarking that this transaction cost Phileas Fogg no less than twenty thousand pounds, and that he gave away the most valuable parts of the steamer, while fifty-five thousand pounds had been stolen from the Bank of England. But Fogg, with his usual composure, was equal to the occasion.

The narrator cannot help remarking that this transaction cost Phileas Fogg no less than twenty thousand pounds, and that he gave away the most valuable parts of the steamer, while fifty-five thousand pounds had been stolen from the Bank of England. But Fogg, with his usual composure, was equal to the occasion.

The journey had been begun with the utmost confidence, and it was now threatened with failure. The time was pressing, and the distance remaining was still great. The loss of time was considerable, and the loss of money was even greater. The bank had been drawn upon to the last shilling, and the balance was now dangerously low. events.title: Burning the Ship for Fuel
detailed_summary: Fogg explains his wager to Speedy: he must reach London by 8:45 PM on December 21st or lose £20,000.
He reminds Speedy that his refusal to go to Liverpool necessitated these actions.
Speedy retorts gleefully that Fogg's predicament earned him $40,000.
Speedy compliments Fogg, saying he has 'something of the Yankee' about him.
Fogg confirms his ownership of the vessel's wooden parts.
Fogg orders the crew to dismantle the interior fittings—seats, bunks, frames—to be used as fuel.
Dry wood is needed to maintain high steam pressure.
The poop deck, cabins, bunks, and spare deck structures are sacrificed on the first day.
On December 19th, the masts, rafts, and spars are burned.
The crew works energetically, feeding the fires.
Passepartout joins in the demolition efforts with great vigor.
A frenzied atmosphere of destruction takes hold as they dismantle the ship.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: You must know that I shall lose twenty thousand pounds, unless I arrive in London by a quarter before nine on the evening of the 21st of December.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was a perfect rage for demolition.

events.text_segment:
You must know that I shall lose twenty thousand pounds, unless I arrive in London by a quarter before nine on the evening of the 21st of December. I missed the steamer at New York, and as you refused to take me to Liverpool—”
“And I did well!” cried Andrew Speedy; “for I have gained at least forty thousand dollars by it!” He added, more sedately, “Do you know one thing, Captain—”
“Fogg.”
“Captain Fogg, you’ve got something of the Yankee about you.”
And, having paid his passenger what he considered a high compliment, he was going away, when Mr. Fogg said, “The vessel now belongs to me?”
“Certainly, from the keel to the truck of the masts—all the wood, that is.”
“Very well. Have the interior seats, bunks, and frames pulled down, and burn them.”
It was necessary to have dry wood to keep the steam up to the adequate pressure, and on that day the poop, cabins, bunks, and the spare deck were sacrificed. On the next day, the 19th of December, the masts, rafts, and spars were burned; the crew worked lustily, keeping up the fires. Passepartout hewed, cut, and sawed away with all his might. There was a perfect rage for demolition.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
You must know that I shall lose twenty thousand pounds, unless I arrive in London by a quarter before nine on the evening of the 21st of December."

"I know it," said Andrew Speedy, with a triumphant air. "And I suppose you are not going to make it, Mr. Fogg."

"I am not sure of that," replied Phileas Fogg, coldly. "I have still a chance."

"A chance!" repeated Speedy, laughing. "You have only a few hours left, and you are still hundreds of miles from Liverpool."

"I have made up my mind to reach London by the appointed time," said Fogg, "and I shall do it."

"Well, I congratulate you, Mr. Fogg," said Speedy, with a sneer. "You have something of the Yankee about you, I see."

"I am not a Yankee," said Fogg, "but I am a man of business, and I keep my word."

"That is a rare thing," said Speedy, "and I hope you will keep it."

"I shall," said Fogg, "at any cost."

He then turned to the captain and ordered him to prepare the vessel for immediate departure. The crew were soon at work, and the ship was soon under way. But Fogg had not yet made up his mind to leave the ship as it was. He had a plan in his mind, and he was determined to carry it out.

He ordered the crew to dismantle the interior fittings of the vessel, and to use them as fuel. The seats, the bunks, the frames, everything that could be burned was sacrificed to the fire. The dry wood was needed to maintain the high pressure of steam, and the ship was soon moving at a great speed.

The poop deck, the cabins, the bunks, and the spare deck structures were sacrificed on the first day. On the 19th of December, the masts, the rafts, and the spars were burned. The crew worked with a will, and the fires were fed with a steady hand. Passepartout, too, joined in the demolition with great vigor, and the ship was soon a mass of destruction.

A frenzied atmosphere of destruction took hold of the vessel, and the crew worked with a feverish energy. The ship was no longer a vessel of comfort, but a machine of speed, and every moment was precious. Fogg was determined to reach London by the appointed time, and he was willing to sacrifice everything to do so.

events.title: Reaching Queenstown and Devising a New Strategy
detailed_summary: By December 20th, the ship is reduced to little more than a flat hull as railings and most of the deck are burned.
They sight the Irish coast and Fastnet Light.
By 10 PM, they are passing Queenstown.
Fogg has only 24 hours left to reach London, the time needed just to get to Liverpool at full steam.
The fuel source (the ship itself) is nearly exhausted.
Captain Speedy expresses sympathy, noting their position opposite Queenstown suggests failure.
Fogg confirms the lights indicate Queenstown.
He inquires about entering the harbour.
Speedy states it will take three hours, possible only at high tide.
Fogg calmly pauses, formulating a final, inspired plan to overcome this setback.
Queenstown is identified as the port where transatlantic mails are offloaded.
These mails travel by express train to Dublin and then by fast boat to Liverpool, saving 12 hours compared to the ships.
Fogg intends to use this same mail route.
By taking this route, he aims to reach Liverpool by noon the next day, allowing enough time to travel to London before his deadline.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The railings, fittings, the greater part of the deck, and top sides disappeared on the 20th, and the “Henrietta” was now only a flat hulk.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Instead of arriving at Liverpool the next evening by the “Henrietta,” he would be there by noon, and would therefore have time to reach London before a quarter before nine in the evening.

events.text_segment:
The railings, fittings, the greater part of the deck, and top sides disappeared on the 20th, and the “Henrietta” was now only a flat hulk. But on this day they sighted the Irish coast and Fastnet Light. By ten in the evening they were passing Queenstown. Phileas Fogg had only twenty-four hours more in which to get to London; that length of time was necessary to reach Liverpool, with all steam on. And the steam was about to give out altogether!
“Sir,” said Captain Speedy, who was now deeply interested in Mr. Fogg’s project, “I really commiserate you. Everything is against you. We are only opposite Queenstown.”
“Ah,” said Mr. Fogg, “is that place where we see the lights Queenstown?”
“Yes.”
“Can we enter the harbour?”
“Not under three hours. Only at high tide.”
“Stay,” replied Mr. Fogg calmly, without betraying in his features that by a supreme inspiration he was about to attempt once more to conquer ill-fortune.
Queenstown is the Irish port at which the transatlantic steamers stop to put off the mails. These mails are carried to Dublin by express trains always held in readiness to start; from Dublin they are sent on to Liverpool by the most rapid boats, and thus gain twelve hours on the Atlantic steamers.
Phileas Fogg counted on gaining twelve hours in the same way. Instead of arriving at Liverpool the next evening by the “Henrietta,” he would be there by noon, and would therefore have time to reach London before a quarter before nine in the evening.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The railings, fittings, the greater part of the deck, and top sides disappeared on the 20th, and the “Henrietta” was now only a flat hulk. The fire had devoured everything, and the vessel, reduced to its lowest terms, was scarcely seaworthy. Yet, with the wind at her back and the sea smooth, she still held her course. The Irish coast was now in sight, and the Fastnet Light gleamed in the distance. By ten o’clock in the evening, the ship was passing Queenstown. Phileas Fogg had but twenty-four hours left to reach London, and the time required to reach Liverpool at full steam was just about that. The ship, which had been their means of locomotion, was now nearly their last resource. The fuel was the vessel itself, and that was nearly consumed. Captain Speedy, who had watched the progress of the fire with anxious eyes, now turned to Fogg with a look of sympathy. “We are opposite Queenstown,” he said. “That is evident from the lights.” “Yes,” said Fogg, “and I should like to know if we can enter the harbor.” “It would take three hours,” replied the captain, “and only at high tide.” Fogg paused for a moment, as if considering the difficulty. Then, with the calmness of a man who sees a way out of the most desperate situation, he said: “Queenstown is the port where the transatlantic mails are landed. These mails are carried by express to Dublin, and from thence by steamboat to Liverpool, saving twelve hours compared with the ships. I shall follow the same route.” “You mean to leave the ship?” asked Speedy. “I do,” replied Fogg. “And I shall reach Liverpool by noon to-morrow, and London before the time fixed.”
